posts.title: Don't fall into the anti-AI hype
posts.author: todsacerdoti
posts.title_cn: 别陷入反AI炒作
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“不要陷入反AI炒作”展开，核心话题是开发者对AI编程工具（如LLM）的实用价值与职业影响的看法。多数用户认同AI是工具演进的延续，能提升效率并帮助小型团队，但也存在明显分歧。有人认为AI破坏了编程的“心流”体验，使其变得乏味且需要大量监督，产出代码质量常如初级水平；也有用户指出AI有助于知识民主化，能加速开发并解决实际问题。讨论中提到，部分人担忧AI生成代码导致软件设计质量下降，且过度依赖可能削弱开发者对底层原理的理解。共识在于，开发者应积极测试并谨慎使用AI工具，而非完全拒绝，但对其实际效果与长期职业影响仍持不同立场。

comments.author: embedding-shape
comments.content: > But what was the fire inside you, when you coded till night to see your project working? It was building.I feel like this is not the same for everyone. For some people, the "fire" is literally about "I control a computer", for others "I'm solving a problem for others", and yet for others "I made something that made others smile/cry/feel emotions" and so on.I think there is a section of programmer who actually do like the actual typing of letters, numbers and special characters into a computer, and for them, I understand LLMs remove the fun part. For me, I initially got into programming because I wanted to ruin other people's websites, then I figured out I needed to know how to build websites first, then I found it more fun to create and share what I've done with others, and they tell me what they think of it. That's my "fire". But I've met so many people who doesn't care an iota about sharing what they built with others, it matters nothing to them.I guess the conclusion is, not all programmers program for the same reason, for some of us, LLMs helps a lot, and makes things even more fun. For others, LLMs remove the core part of what makes programming fun for them. Hence we get this constant back and forth of "Can't believe others can work like this!" vs "I can't believe others aren't working like this!", but both sides seems to completely miss the other side.
comments.content_cn: 但当你彻夜编码只为看到项目运行起来时，内心燃烧的火焰究竟是什么？那是创造的激情。我觉得每个人的动力不尽相同：对有些人而言，这种“火焰”纯粹源于“我能操控计算机”；对另一些人则是“我在为他人解决问题”；还有人追求的是“我创造了能让他人欢笑/流泪/产生共鸣的作品”。我认为确实存在一类程序员，他们真心享受在计算机中输入字母、数字和特殊字符的过程，对他们而言，我理解大语言模型确实剥夺了这种乐趣。就我个人而言，最初接触编程是因为想搞垮别人的网站，后来发现需要先学会建站，继而发现创造并与他人分享成果、收获反馈的过程更令人快乐——这就是我的“火焰”。但我也遇到过无数对分享作品毫不在意的人，这对他们毫无意义。我想结论是：并非所有程序员编码的初衷都相同。对我们中的一些人，大语言模型提供了巨大帮助，让编程更有趣；而对另一些人，它却消解了编程乐趣的核心。于是我们不断陷入这样的拉锯战：一边是“难以置信别人竟这样工作！”，另一边是“难以置信别人竟不这样工作！”，但双方似乎都完全忽视了对方的存在。

comments.author: gradus_ad
comments.content: It seems that as the tools available to developers have become more abstracted allowing them to do more with less, their ability to command higher salaries and prestige has only grown and grown. LLM's are just a continuation of this trend.The naive view considers only the small scale ease of completing a task in isolation and expects compensation to be proportional to it. But that's not how things work. Yes abstraction makes individual tasks easier to complete, but with the extra time available more can be done, and as more is done and can be done, new complexities emerge. And as an individual can do more, the importance of trust grows as well. This is why CEO's make disproportionately more than their employees, because while the complexity of their work may scale only linearly with their position, or not at all even beyond a certain point, the impact of their decisions grows exponentially.LLM's are just going to enhance the power and influence of software developers.
comments.content_cn: 随着开发者可用的工具日益抽象化，使他们能够以更少的付出完成更多工作，他们获取更高薪酬和声望的能力也在持续增强。大型语言模型不过是这一趋势的延续。天真的观点只孤立地考虑小规模任务完成的便利性，并期望报酬与之成正比。但现实并非如此。确实，抽象化让单个任务更容易完成，但节省下来的时间可用于完成更多工作；随着完成和可完成的工作增多，新的复杂性也随之浮现。当个人能力提升时，信任的重要性也同步增长。这就是为什么首席执行官的薪酬远高于普通员工——尽管他们工作的复杂性可能仅随职位线性增长，甚至超过某个节点后不再增加，但其决策的影响力却呈指数级扩大。大型语言模型将进一步增强软件开发者的权力和影响力。

comments.author: zeroonetwothree
comments.content: You’re right of course. For me there’s no flow state possible with LLM “coding”. That makes it feel miserable instead of joyous. Sitting around waiting while it spits out tokens that I then have to carefully look over and tweak feels like very hard work. Compared to entering flow and churning out those tokens myself, which feels effortless once I get going.Probably other people feel differently.
comments.content_cn: 你说得对。对我来说，使用大语言模型“编程”时根本无法进入心流状态。这让人感到痛苦而非愉悦。坐着等待它逐字输出结果，然后还得仔细检查调整，感觉像在干苦力活。相比之下，自己进入心流状态一气呵成地编写代码，一旦开始就毫不费力。可能其他人的感受会不同吧。

comments.author: NitpickLawyer
comments.content: > Whatever you believe about what the Right Thing should be, you can't control it by refusing what is happening right now. Skipping AI is not going to help you or your career. Think about it. Test these new tools, with care, with weeks of work, not in a five minutes test where you can just reinforce your own beliefs.This is the advice I've been giving my friends and coworkers as well for a while now. Forget the hype, just take time to test them from time to time. See where it's at. And "prepare" for what's to come, as best you can.Another thing to consider. If you casually look into it by just reading about it, be aware that almost everything you read in "mainstream" places has been wrong in 2025. The people covering this, writing about this, producing content on this have different goals in this era. They need hits, likes, shares and reach. They don't get that with accurate reporting. And, sadly, negativity sells. It is what it is.THe only way to get an accurate picture is to try them yourself. The earlier you do that, the better you'll be. And a note on signals: right now, a "positive" signal is more valuable for you than many "negative" ones. Read those and try to understand the what, if not the how. "I did this with cc" is much more valuable today than "x still doesn't do y reliably".
comments.content_cn:
无论你认为正确的事情应该是什么，都无法通过拒绝当下正在发生的一切来控制它。回避人工智能对你或你的职业生涯都没有帮助。仔细想想。花几周时间认真测试这些新工具，而不是用五分钟的测试来强化自己的固有观念。这也是我一段时间以来一直给朋友和同事的建议。忘掉炒作，只需时不时花时间测试它们。看看它们发展到了什么程度。并尽你所能为即将到来的变化“做好准备”。

还有一点需要考虑。如果你只是通过阅读来随意了解，请注意，你在“主流”平台上看到的几乎所有内容在2025年都是错误的。在这个时代，报道、撰写和制作相关内容的人有着不同的目标。他们需要点击量、点赞、分享和影响力。而准确的报道并不能带来这些。可悲的是，负面消息更易传播。现实就是如此。

获得准确认知的唯一方法就是亲自尝试。越早尝试，你就越能掌握先机。关于信号的一点提醒：目前，一个“积极”的信号比许多“消极”的信号对你更有价值。阅读那些积极信号并尝试理解其内容，即使不明白原理也没关系。如今，“我用cc做到了这件事”比“x仍然无法可靠地完成y”要有价值得多。

comments.content_cn: 对于我编写的所有被大型语言模型吸收的代码，我作何感想？我感到非常荣幸能参与其中，因为我认为这是我毕生致力于事业的延续：让代码、系统和知识普及化。大型语言模型将帮助我们更快地编写更好的软件，并让小型团队有机会与大型公司竞争。你可能感觉良好，这没问题，但我并不这么认为。而且软件质量正在下降，我不认为大型语言模型有助于编写更好的软件。

comments.content: These personal blogs are starting to feel like Linkdin Lunatic posts, kinda similar. to the optimised floor sweeping blog, “I am excited to provide shareholder value, at minimum wage”
comments.content_cn: 这些个人博客开始有点像领英上的疯狂帖子，和那篇关于优化扫地工作的博客挺相似的，“我很兴奋能在最低工资水平上为股东创造价值”。

comments.author: wooptoo
comments.content:
Programming is essentially automation. You tell the machine what to do character by character, and if you get it right, the machine will be able to correctly interpret your intention, transform it into a lower level code, and then execute it.AI is also automation but the instructions are given in a higher level language. 
You still have to know how to automate it. You need to instruct the machine in sufficient detail, and if done correctly the machine will once again be able to interpret your intention, transform it to a lower level code, and execute it for you.
comments.content_cn: 编程本质上是自动化。你逐字告诉机器该做什么，如果操作正确，机器就能准确理解你的意图，将其转化为更低层级的代码并执行。人工智能同样属于自动化，但指令是以更高层级的语言给出的。你仍需懂得如何实现自动化，需要用足够详细的指令指导机器，若操作得当，机器将再次解读你的意图，将其转化为低层级代码并为你执行。

comments.author: ironman1478
comments.content: I'm not sure what to make of these technologies. I read about people doing all these things with them and it sounds impressive. Then when I use it, it feels like the tool produces junior level code unless I babysit it, then it really can produce what I want.If I have to do all this babysitting, is it really saving me anything other than typing the code? It hasn't felt like it yet and if anything it's scary because I need to always read the code to make sure it's valid, and reading code is harder than writing it.
comments.content_cn: 我对这些技术持保留态度。读到人们用它们完成各种事情时，听起来很厉害。但当我亲自使用时，感觉除非全程监督，否则它只能生成初级水平的代码；只有在我紧盯的情况下，它才能真正产出我想要的东西。如果必须这样全程监督，那除了节省打字时间外，它真的帮我省了什么吗？至少目前我还没感受到，反而更让人不安——因为我必须反复检查代码确保其正确性，而读代码可比写代码难多了。

comments.author: golly_ned
comments.content: As long as I'm not reviewing PRs with thousands of lines net new that weren't even read by their PR submitter, I'm fine with anything. The software design I've seen from AI code agent using peers has been dreadful.I think for some who are excited about AI programming, they're happy they can build a lot more things. I think for others, they're excited they can build the same amount of things, but with a lot less thinking. The agent and their code reviewers can do the thinking for them.
comments.content_cn: 只要我不需要审阅那些提交者自己都没读过、净增数千行代码的PR，其他任何情况我都能接受。我见过的同行使用AI编程助手设计的软件实在糟糕。我认为对某些热衷AI编程的人来说，他们高兴的是能构建更多东西；而对另一些人而言，他们兴奋的是能用更少的思考完成同等量的工作——让AI助手和代码评审者替他们思考。

comments.author: bluGill
comments.content: I'm trying not to fall for it, but when I try ai to write code it fails more often than not - at least for me. some people claim it does everything but I keep finding major problems. Even when it writes something that works often I can't explain that in 2026 we should be using smart pointers (C++) or what ever the modern thing
comments.content_cn: 我尽量不轻信这些说法，但当我尝试用AI写代码时，它失败的次数远多于成功——至少对我来说是这样。有些人声称AI无所不能，但我总是发现重大问题。即使它写出了能运行的代码，我也常常无法解释为什么到了2026年我们还要用智能指针（C++）或类似的现代技术。

comments.content: How would we measure the effects of AI coding tool taking over manual coding ? Would we see an increase in the number of GitHub projects ? In the number of stars (given the ai is so good) ? In the number of start up ipos (surely if all your engineers are 1000x engineers thanks to Claude code, we'll have plenty of googles and Amazons to invest in) ? In the price of software (if I can just vibe code everything, than a 10$ fully compatible replacement for MS Windows is just a few months away, right ?) In the the numbers of app published in the stores ?
comments.content_cn: 我们该如何衡量AI编程工具取代人工编码的影响？是否会看到GitHub项目数量的增长？或是星标数量的增加（毕竟AI如此出色）？初创公司IPO数量会上升吗（如果所有工程师借助Claude代码都成为千倍效率工程师，我们就会有大量谷歌和亚马逊级别的公司可供投资）？软件价格会如何变化（如果我能轻松编写一切，那么几个月内就会出现10美元完全兼容的Windows替代品，对吗？）应用商店上架应用数量又会怎样？

comments.author: keyle
comments.content: > The fun is still there, untouched.Well that's a way to put it. But not everyone enjoy the art only for the results.I personally love learning, and by letting AI drive forward and me following, I don't learn. To learn is to be human.So saying the fun is untouched is one-sided. Not everyone is in it for the same reasons.
comments.content_cn: 乐趣依然存在，未曾改变。这么说倒也没错。但并非所有人都只为结果而欣赏艺术。我个人热爱学习，如果让AI主导而我跟随，我就无法真正学习。学习正是人之为人的体现。所以说乐趣未受影响是片面的，并非所有人参与其中的初衷都相同。

comments.author: adityaathalye
comments.content: Don't fall into the "Look ma, no hands" hype.Antirez + LLM + CFO = Billion Dollar Redis company, quite plausibly./However/ ...As for the delta provided by an LLM to Antirez, outside of Redis (and outside of any problem space he is already intimately familiar with), an Apples to Apples comparison would be he trying this on an equally complex codebase he has no idea about. I'll bet... what Antirez can do with Redis and LLMs (certainly useful, huge Quality of Life improvement to Antirez), he cannot even begin to do with (say) Postgres.The only way to get there with (say) Postgres, would be to /know/ Postgres. And pretty much everyone, no matter how good, cannot get there with code-reading alone. With software at least, we need to develop a mental model of the thing by futzing about with the thing in deeply meaningful ways.And most of us day-job grunts are in the latter spot... working in some grimy legacy multi-hundred-thousand line code-mine, full of NPM vulns, schelpping code over the wall to QA (assuming there is even a QA), and basically developing against live customers --- "learn by shipping", as they say.I do think LLMs are wildly interesting technology, however they are poor utility for non-domain-experts. If organisations want to profit from the fully-loaded cost of LLM technology, they better also invest heavily in staff training and development.
comments.content_cn: 别被“看啊，不用手”的炒作迷惑。Antirez + 大语言模型 + 首席财务官 = 价值十亿美元的Redis公司，这相当可信。/但是/……至于大语言模型为Antirez在Redis之外（以及在他已经非常熟悉的任何问题领域之外）提供的助力，一个公平的比较应该是让他在一个同样复杂、他一无所知的代码库上尝试。我敢打赌……Antirez用Redis和大语言模型能做到的事（当然有用，极大提升了Antirez的工作体验），他根本无法在（比如）Postgres上开始做。要在（比如）Postgres上达到那种程度，唯一的途径是/懂/Postgres。而且几乎所有人，无论多厉害，都无法仅靠阅读代码就做到。至少在软件领域，我们需要通过以深刻有意义的方式摆弄那个东西，来建立对它的心智模型。而我们大多数日常工作的普通人都处于后一种境地……在某个肮脏的、遗留的、数十万行代码的“矿坑”里工作，满是NPM漏洞，把代码扔过墙给QA（假设还有QA），基本上是对着真实客户开发——正如他们所说，“通过发布来学习”。我确实认为大语言模型是非常有趣的技术，但对于非领域专家来说，它们的实用性很差。如果组织想从大语言模型技术的全部成本中获利，他们最好也在员工培训和发展上大力投入。

comments.author: kiriakosv
comments.content: AI tools in their current form or another will definitely change software engineering, I personally think for the bestHowever I can’t help but notice some things that look weird/amusing:- The exact time that many programmers were enlightened about the AI capabilities and the frequency of their posts.- The uniform language they use in these posts. Grandiose adjectives, standard phrases like ‘it seems to me’- And more importantly the sense of urgency and FOMO they emit. This is particularly weird for two reasons. First is that if the past has shown something regarding technology is that open source always catches up. But this is not the case yet. Second, if the premise is that we re just the in beginning all these ceremonial flows will be obsolete.Do not get me wrong, as of today these are all valid ways to work with AI and in many domains they increase the productivity. But I really don’t get the sense of urgency.
comments.content_cn:
人工智能工具以其现有或未来形态必将改变软件工程领域，我个人认为这种改变是积极的。然而，我忍不住注意到一些看似古怪或有趣的现象：
- 许多程序员突然意识到人工智能能力的时间点如此集中，以及他们发布相关内容的频率之高。
- 他们在这些帖子中使用高度统一的表达方式：夸张的形容词、“在我看来”这类标准句式。
- 更重要的是他们流露出的紧迫感和错失恐惧。这一点尤其令人费解，原因有二：首先，历史经验表明开源技术总能迎头赶上，但目前尚未发生；其次，如果前提是我们尚处起步阶段，那么这些仪式化的流程终将过时。
请不要误会，就目前而言，这些确实是运用人工智能的有效工作方式，并在诸多领域提升了生产效率。但我实在无法理解这种紧迫感从何而来。

comments.author: bitwize
comments.content: OK, so what do I hear about LLMs? Oh, it's just like having an intern. A fresh graduate. Now you're not building the thing yourself, you're giving directives and delegating the actual building of the thing. What does this sound like?The managerial class believes that all the value in a business comes from managerial work. LLMs are being hyped by the managerial class because they are turning software development into managerial work and eliminating "programmer" as a professional category. The key insight Milt Bryce had with PRIDE is that software is a product that can be manufactured just like any other product. The ideal software production workflow is that of a factory, and the ideal factory is staffed by no more than a man and a dog—in other words, fully automated.So the rules of business in your father's or grandfather's time prevail once again. It's up or out. Learn people skills, learn the business, and take on more responsibilities putting those skills to use and fewer responsibilities involving code. Or find yourself increasingly irrelevant.
comments.content_cn: 好吧，关于大语言模型我听到了什么？哦，它就像请了个实习生。一个刚毕业的新人。现在你不用自己动手构建东西了，你只需下达指令，把实际构建工作委派出去。这听起来像什么？管理层认为企业的所有价值都来自管理工作。大语言模型之所以被管理层热捧，是因为它们正将软件开发转变为管理工作，并逐渐淘汰“程序员”这一职业类别。米尔特·布莱斯在PRIDE项目中的关键洞见是：软件是一种可以像其他产品一样被制造的产品。理想的软件生产流程就像工厂流水线，而理想的工厂只需一人一狗即可运作——换句话说，完全自动化。于是你父辈或祖辈时代的商业规则再次占据上风：要么晋升，要么出局。去学习人际交往技巧，了解业务运作，承担更多运用这些技能的职责，减少与代码相关的责任。否则你会发现自己越来越无足轻重。

comments.author: systemf_omega
comments.content: What I don't understand about this whole "get on board the AI train or get left behind" narrative, what advantage does an early adopter have for AI tools?The way I see it, I can just start using AI once they get good enough for my type of work. Until then I'm continuing to learn instead of letting my brain atrophy.
comments.content_cn: 对于这种“要么搭上人工智能列车，要么被时代抛弃”的说法，我不理解的是早期采用者使用人工智能工具到底有什么优势？在我看来，我完全可以等到这些工具发展到足够胜任我的工作时再开始使用。在此之前，我会继续学习，而不是让大脑退化。

comments.author: edg5000
comments.content: >  state of the art LLMs are able to complete large subtasks or medium size projects alone, almost unassisted, given a good set of hints about what the end result should beNo. I agree with the author, but it's hyperbolic of him to phrase it like this. If you have solid domain knowledge, you'll steer the model with detailed specs. It will carry those out competently and multiply your productivity. However, the quality of the output still reflects your state of knowledge. It just provides leverage. Given the best tractors, a good farmer will have much better yields than a shit one. Without good direction, even Opus 4.5 tends to create massive code repetion. Easy to avoid if you know what you are doing, albeit in a refactor pass.
comments.content_cn: 顶尖的大语言模型能够独立完成大型子任务或中等规模项目，几乎无需协助，只要提供关于最终结果应为何样的良好提示即可。我同意作者的观点，但他这样表述有些夸张。如果你具备扎实的领域知识，就能通过详细规格来引导模型。模型会高效执行这些规格，并显著提升你的生产力。然而，输出的质量仍反映出你的知识水平。它只是提供了杠杆作用。有了最好的拖拉机，优秀的农民会比糟糕的农民获得好得多的收成。如果没有良好的指导，即使是Opus 4.5也容易产生大量代码重复。如果你清楚自己在做什么，这很容易避免，尽管可能需要一次重构过程。

comments.author: lrvick
comments.content: As a security engineer that regularly architects and helps implement new defense tactics that no LLM has trained on, I choose not to use LLMs at all, like a cave man.Being differently trained and using different tools than almost everyone else I know in engineering my entire career has allowed me to find solutions and vulnerabilities others have missed time and time again. I exclusively use open source software I can always take apart, fully understand, and modify as I like. This inclination has served me well and is why I have the skillsets I do today.If everyone is doing things one way, I instinctively want to explore all the other ways to train my own brain to continue to be adversarial and with a stamina to do hard experiments by hand when no tools exist to automate them yet.Watching all my peers think more and more alike actually scares me, as they are all talking to the same LLMs. None for me, thanks."But this magic proprietary tool makes my job so much easier!!" has never been a compelling argument for me.
comments.content_cn:
作为一名经常设计并协助实施全新防御策略的安全工程师（这些策略尚未被任何大语言模型训练过），我选择完全不用大语言模型，就像个原始人。在我整个工程师生涯中，与几乎所有同行接受不同训练并使用不同工具的经历，让我一次次找到了他人遗漏的解决方案和漏洞。我只使用开源软件，这样我总能拆解、完全理解并按喜好修改它们。这种倾向让我受益匪浅，也造就了我今天的技能。

如果所有人都用一种方式做事，我会本能地探索所有其他途径，以此训练自己的大脑保持对抗性思维，并在尚无自动化工具时，保持亲手进行复杂实验的耐力。看着同行们的思维越来越趋同，这着实令我担忧——因为他们都在和相同的大语言模型对话。我就不必了，谢谢。

“但这个神奇的专有工具让我的工作轻松多了！”这种说法对我从来就没有说服力。

comments.author: cmiles8
comments.content: The “anti-AU hype” phrase oversimplifies what’s playing out at the moment. It’s a nice set of useful features but without products with sufficient revenue flowing in to pay for it all.That paints a picture of the tech sticking around but a general implosion of the startups and business models betting on making all this work.The later isn’t really “anti-AI hype” but more folks just calling out the reality that there’s not a lot of evidence and data to support the amount of money invested and committed. And if you’ve been around the tech and business scene a while you’ve seen that movie before and know what comes next.In 5 years time I expect to be using AI more than I do now. I also expect most of the AI companies and startups won’t exist anymore.
comments.content_cn:
“反AI热”这个说法过度简化了当前的实际情况。从技术层面看，虽然仍存在一些不完善之处，但这项技术非常实用且具有持久生命力。坦白说，在这方面我并未看到太多分歧。主要的担忧来自商业层面……尽管技术本身很有用，但目前还没有清晰的可行路径能为所有相关投入提供资金支持。这是一系列实用的功能组合，但缺乏能产生足够收入来支撑其持续发展的产品体系。

这描绘出这样的图景：技术本身会留存下来，但那些试图实现这一切的初创企业和商业模式将面临大规模崩塌。后者其实并非“反AI热”，而是更多人在指出现实——目前缺乏足够的证据和数据来支撑已投入和承诺的资金规模。如果你在科技和商业领域有一定阅历，这种剧情早已屡见不鲜，也清楚接下来的发展轨迹。

五年后，我预计自己会比现在更频繁地使用AI技术。同时我也预料到，大多数AI公司和初创企业将不复存在。

comments.author: epolanski
comments.content: Because using AI takes some practice:- you should document your best practices in a file and point it to the LLM (the standards are @claude or @agent markdown files- you should manage context (the larger it gets the weaker the output)- you should use good and clear prompts- you should generally make it generate a plan with the requirements (business logic changes focused) and then follow and review the implementation plan (I generally produce both in two different markdown files).- only then you let it codeThe last phase, isn't even the most important to be honest, you can do it manually. But I have found that forcing myself through the first two and having AI find information in the codebase, edge cases in the business logic, propose different solutions, evaluate the impact of the changes is a huge productivity multiplier.Very often I'm not worn out by the coding part, again, I can do it on my own, it's the finding information and connecting the dots the hard one. In that, it excels and I would struggle (mentally) to go back to jumping from file to file while keeping track of my findings in notes to figure out the wheres, whats and whys.
comments.content_cn:
因为使用AI需要一定练习：你应该将最佳实践记录在文件中并指引大语言模型参考（标准格式是@claude或@agent的markdown文件）；需要管理上下文（范围越大输出质量越弱）；应当使用优质清晰的提示词；通常应让它先根据需求生成实施计划（聚焦业务逻辑变更），随后跟进并评审该计划（我通常会分别生成两个独立markdown文件）。完成这些步骤后才让其编写代码。

说实话最后编码阶段甚至不是最重要的环节，完全可以手动完成。但我发现强制自己执行前两个步骤，让AI在代码库中检索信息、发现业务逻辑中的边界情况、提出不同解决方案、评估变更影响，能极大提升工作效率。很多时候让我疲惫的并非编码部分——这我自己也能完成，真正困难的是信息检索与逻辑串联。在这方面AI表现卓越，而若要我重新在文件间反复跳转，同时用笔记追踪发现来定位问题所在、内容与成因，会感到相当吃力。

comments.content_cn: 与大型语言模型协作的妙处在于，你无需人际交往技巧——尽管管理它们的过程大致模仿了这种技巧。你不必考虑代码助手的情感、个人偏好，或是哪些挑战最能促进其技能或职业发展。你只需下达指令，若执行有误便指出修正之处，并能持续反复调整直至获得正确结果。倘若它们偏离轨道过远，你可以重置状态，让它们以全新视角从不同方向重新执行任务。

comments.author: roncesvalles
comments.content: Exactly. AI is minimally useful for coding something that you couldn't have been able to code yourself, given enough time, without explicitly investing time in generic learning not specific to that codebase or particular task.Although calling AI "just autocomplete" is almost a slur now, it really is just that in the sense that you need to A) have a decent mental picture of what you want, and, B) recognize a correct output when you see it.On a tangent, the inability to identify correct output is also why I don't recommend using LLMs to teach you anything serious. comments.content_cn: 确实如此。人工智能在编程方面的作用有限，它主要适用于那些你本可以自己完成、只是需要更多时间、且无需投入额外精力进行与特定代码库或任务无关的通用学习的场景。尽管现在将AI称为“仅仅是自动补全”几乎带有贬义，但从本质上讲，它确实如此：你需要A）对自己想要的东西有清晰的概念，B）在看到正确输出时能够识别出来。顺便一提，无法识别正确输出也是我不建议使用大型语言模型来学习任何严肃知识的原因。当我们使用搜索引擎学习时，我们能通过信息密度、逻辑一致性、思维的结构性/清晰度、共识、评论、作者资历等多种信号来判断是否遇到了优质的教学内容。但使用大型语言模型时，我们失去了这些关键的分析信号。

comments.author: loubbrad
comments.content: > I think there is a section of programmer who actually do like the actual typing of letters, numbers and special characters into a computer...Reminds me of this excerpt from Richard Hamming's book:> Finally, a more complete, and more useful, Symbolic Assembly Program (SAP) was devised—after more years than you are apt to believe during which most programmers continued their heroic absolute binary programming. 最终，经过多年努力——这年数可能超乎你的想象，期间大多数程序员仍在进行英勇的绝对二进制编程——我们设计出了更完整、更实用的符号汇编程序（SAP）。SAP刚问世时，我估计只有约1%的老牌程序员对它感兴趣：使用SAP是“娘娘腔的把戏”，真正的程序员可不愿屈尊浪费机器性能去做汇编。没错！程序员们根本不想碰它，尽管被逼问时他们不得不承认，自己用老方法定位和修复错误所耗费的机器时间，远比SAP程序运行所需的时间更多。主要的抱怨之一是使用符号系统时，你无法知道任何内容在存储中的具体位置——尽管早期我们提供了符号与实际存储的映射表，信不信由你，他们后来竟深情地钻研这些表格，而不愿意识到只要坚持在系统内操作就根本不需要了解那些信息——不！修改错误时，他们宁愿使用绝对二进制地址。

comments.author: simonw
comments.content: This is a pretty common position: "I don't worry about getting left behind - it will only take a few weeks to catch up again".I don't think that's true.I'm really good at getting great results out of coding agents and LLMs. I've also been using LLMs for code on an almost daily basis since ChatGPT's release on November 30th 2022. That's more than three years ago now.Meanwhile I see a constant flow of complaints from other developers who can't get anything useful out of these machines, or find that the gains they get are minimal at best.Using this stuff well is a deep topic. These things can be applied in so many different ways, and to so many different projects. The best asset you can develop is an intuition for what works and what doesn't, and getting that intuition requires months if not years of personal experimentation.I don't think you can just catch up in a few weeks, and I do think that the risk of falling behind isn't being taken seriously enough by much of the developer population.I'm glad to see people like antirez ringing the alarm bell about this - it's not going to be a popular position but it needs to be said!

这是一种相当普遍的观点："我不担心落后——只需要几周就能重新赶上"。我认为这并不正确。我非常擅长利用编码助手和大型语言模型取得优异成果。自2022年11月30日ChatGPT发布以来，我几乎每天都在使用LLM处理代码工作，至今已超过三年。

与此同时，我持续看到其他开发者抱怨无法从这些工具中获得任何实质性帮助，或发现收益微乎其微。

有效运用这些技术是个深奥的课题。它们能以多种不同方式应用于各类项目。你能培养的最佳能力是形成对"什么方法有效、什么无效"的直觉，而这种直觉需要数月甚至数年的亲身实践才能获得。

我认为不可能仅用几周就迎头赶上，也确信开发者群体普遍未能足够重视落后于技术发展的风险。

comments.author: keeda
comments.content: What "domain expert" means is also changing however.As I've mentioned often, I'm solving problems in a domain I had minimal background in before. However, that domain is computer vision. So I can literally "see" if the code works or not!To expand, I've set up tests, benchmarks and tools that generate results as images. I chat with the LLM about a specific problem at hand, it presents various solutions, I pick a promising approach, it writes the code, I run the tests which almost always pass, but if they don't, I can hone in on the problem quickly with a visual check of the relevant images.This has allowed me to make progress despite my lack of background. Interestingly, I've now built up some domain knowledge through learning by doing and experimenting (and soon, shipping)!These days I think an agent could execute this whole loop by itself by "looking" at the test and result images itself. I've uploaded test images to the LLM and we had technical conversations about them as if it "saw" them like a human. However, there are ton of images and I don't want to burn the tokens at this point.The upshot is, if you can set up a way of reliably testing and validating the LLM's output, you could still achieve things in an unfamiliar domain without prior expertise.Taking your Postgres example, it's a heavily tested and benchmarked project. I would bet someone like Antirez would be able to jump in and do original, valid work using AI very quickly, because even if hasn't futzed with Postgres code, he HAS futzed with a LOT of other code and hence has a deep intuition about software architecture in general.So this is what I meant by the meaning of "domain expert" changing. The required skills have become a lot more fundamental. Maybe the only required skills are intuition about software engineering, critical thinking, and basic knowledge of statistics and the scientific method.
comments.content_cn: 然而，“领域专家”的含义也在发生变化。正如我常提到的，我正在解决一个我之前背景知识极少的领域问题。不过，这个领域是计算机视觉。所以我实际上可以“看到”代码是否有效！进一步来说，我建立了测试、基准和工具，这些工具能生成图像形式的结果。我与LLM就手头的具体问题进行交流，它提出各种解决方案，我选择一个有前景的方法，它编写代码，我运行测试，这些测试几乎总能通过，但如果不通过，我可以通过视觉检查相关图像迅速定位问题。尽管缺乏背景知识，这使我能够取得进展。有趣的是，我现在通过实践和实验（很快还会通过交付产品）积累了一些领域知识。如今我认为，一个智能体可以通过自己“查看”测试和结果图像来独立执行整个循环。我曾将测试图像上传给LLM，我们围绕它们进行了技术对话，就好像它像人类一样“看到”了这些图像。然而，图像数量庞大，目前我不想消耗太多令牌。关键在于，如果你能建立一种可靠测试和验证LLM输出的方法，即使没有先前的专业知识，你也能在不熟悉的领域取得成果。以你的Postgres为例，这是一个经过充分测试和基准评估的项目。我敢打赌，像Antirez这样的人能够迅速介入，并利用AI做出原创且有效的工作，因为即使他没有深入研究过Postg...

posts.title: I dumped Windows 11 for Linux, and you should too
posts.author: smurda
posts.title_cn: 我放弃了Windows 11转投Linux，你也该试试
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕用户是否应从Windows 11转向Linux展开。核心争议在于Linux的实用性与理想化主张之间的平衡。有人认为Linux在隐私控制、系统轻量和避免商业捆绑方面优势明显，且社区生态已足够成熟；也有用户指出其存在硬件兼容性不足、专业软件支持欠缺及系统更新可能引发稳定性问题等实际障碍。讨论中提到，对于依赖特定办公软件（如Microsoft Office）或游戏兼容性的用户，转换成本较高。尽管部分长期用户表达了对Linux自主性的高度认同，但普遍共识是：系统选择应基于实际需求而非单纯理念，Linux适合技术倾向用户，而Windows在易用性和生态整合上仍不可替代。

comments.author: voxleone
comments.content: It’s worth acknowledging the real challenges raised in this thread: desktop Linux still has rough edges for some use cases, hardware support isn’t always perfect, and niche professional software may lack native support or require workarounds. But these obstacles are not intrinsic technical limitations so much as ecosystem and investment gaps, areas where community projects, standards efforts, and wider adoption could drive improvement without sacrificing freedom.Viewed through the lens of digital autonomy and citizenship, the question isn’t simply “Is Linux perfect?” but rather: Do we want our fundamental computing environment to be ultimately under our control, or controlled by private interests with their own incentives?
comments.content_cn: 必须承认这个讨论中提出的现实挑战：对于某些使用场景，桌面Linux仍有不足之处，硬件支持并非总是完美，专业小众软件可能缺乏原生支持或需要变通方案。但这些障碍并非本质性的技术限制，更多是生态系统和投入的差距——在这些领域，社区项目、标准制定和更广泛的采用完全可以在不牺牲自由的前提下推动改进。从数字自主权和公民权利的角度来看，问题不在于“Linux是否完美”，而在于：我们是否希望自己的基础计算环境最终由自己掌控，而非受制于具有自身利益诉求的私营实体？

comments.author: bachmeier
comments.content: > Viewed through the lens of digital autonomy and citizenship, the question isn’t simply “Is Linux perfect?” but rather: Do we want our fundamental computing environment to be ultimately under our control, or controlled by private interests with their own incentives?As a user of Linux as my main desktop OS for more than 20 years, a user of Linux far longer than that, and a promoter of FOSS before that was a term, this has always been the question. Most of the world does not care. I suspect that is more true today than ever before. There are now adults that grew up in the age of social media that have no idea how local computing works.Not to be negative but the "obstacles" to adopting Linux were never actually obstacles most of the time. Fifteen years ago my mother started using Linux as her main OS with no training. I gave her the login information, but never had a chance to show her how to use it, and she just figured it out on her own. Everything just worked, including exchanging MS Office documents for work.
comments.content_cn: 从数字自主权和公民身份的角度来看，问题并非简单的“Linux是否完美？”，而是：我们是否希望自己的基础计算环境最终由自己掌控，还是由具有自身利益的私人实体控制？作为将Linux作为主要桌面操作系统使用超过20年的用户，使用Linux的时间更久，甚至在自由开源软件成为术语之前就倡导它，这一直是核心问题。世界上大多数人并不关心这一点。我怀疑如今这一现象比以往任何时候都更加明显。现在有在社交媒体时代长大的成年人，完全不了解本地计算的工作原理。并非消极，但采用Linux的“障碍”在大多数时候其实并非真正的障碍。十五年前，我母亲在没有接受任何培训的情况下开始将Linux作为主要操作系统使用。我给了她登录信息，但从未有机会教她如何使用，她完全靠自己摸索明白了一切。所有功能都运行正常，包括处理工作中的MS Office文档交换。

comments.author: keyshapegeo99

If I were a desktop computing person, I'd already have done so years ago.Alas, I exclusively use laptops - as I work a great deal while travelling.I do not wish to have to carry around a mouse with me wherever I go with my portable computer.If any Linux distro manages to replicate even 80% of the smoothness and functionality of a Mac trackpad experience, I'll switch. comments.content_cn: 出于理念和实际使用的双重考量，我非常愿意转换系统。倘若我是台式机用户，恐怕多年前就已付诸行动。遗憾的是，我完全依赖笔记本电脑——因为频繁差旅中需要处理大量工作。我不愿随身携带便携电脑的同时还必须搭配鼠标。如果有任何Linux发行版能复现Mac触控板哪怕80%的流畅度和功能性，我会立刻转投阵营。然而至今仍未寻得这样的系统（是的，我已尝试所有Asahi衍生版本——它们远未达到理想状态）。

comments.author: tmtvl

comments.author: Zak

comments.author: Aurornis
comments.content: I have a Mac laptop, a Linux workstation, and a Windows workstation for different purposes and I use them all. I agree. Every time someone says they switched OSes and they don’t miss anything, it’s revealed that 90-100% of their work was in generic outlets like the web browser, terminal, e-mail, and Slack.To be fair, that could cover a lot of people.In my experience watching people make the switch in the real world, the failure point is either the last 10% of software that they actually need, or the first time they encounter some Linux quirk that they didn’t expect. Then it reaches a point where there isn’t really any upside for people who aren’t ideologically motivated and who don’t get triggered by Windows 11 design choices or occasional pop-ups.I have some specific engineering software that must run on Windows, period. I’ve gotten flak from the software engineers at every company whenever it’s discovered that my second machine is Windows, but outside of software devs nobody else questions it. Using Windows for work is perfectly understood by most other disciplines
comments.content_cn:
我有一台Mac笔记本、一台Linux工作站和一台Windows工作站，分别用于不同用途，并且我都在使用。我赞同这个观点。每当有人说自己换了操作系统后没有任何不适应时，往往会发现他们90%到100%的工作都是在浏览器、终端、电子邮件和Slack这类通用软件中完成的。公平地说，这可能涵盖了很多人。

根据我观察现实中人们切换操作系统的经验，问题通常出现在两个环节：要么是他们真正需要的最后那10%的专业软件无法满足，要么是第一次遇到某些未曾预料的Linux系统特性。对于那些并非出于理念驱动、也不会被Windows 11的设计选择或偶尔弹出的提示所困扰的用户来说，最终往往会发现切换系统并没有带来实质性的优势。

comments.author: the__alchemist
comments.content: This is an clarifying perspective. In particular, I think this sheds light on understanding the various perspectives in the thread:> Viewed through the lens of digital autonomy and citizenship, the question isn’t simply “Is Linux perfect?” but rather: Do we want our fundamental computing environment to be ultimately under our control, or controlled by private interests with their own incentives?We make choices, become passionate about some, and wear values we feel strongly about on our shoulder. What we witness here, I believe, is a conflation of two things:A: Linux as a value: Representing open source software, rejecting bad corporate behavior, and as a philosophy for software ownershipB: Linux as a collection of related operating systems, as practical software.I think trying to understand each person's perspective, and if it can be categorized as one or the other makes sense of this article, similar ones, and discussion. Someone in Category B evaluating operating systems as tools should not be viewed by someone in Category A as an affront to their identity. It may just be different use cases; different hardware; different priorities; different variants and versions of operating systems used.

comments.content: There's a lot of servers running Linux that are regularly targeted by malware.There is a big difference in what software a desktop user runs versus what runs on a server, but the great thing about Linux is that you can keep just as much variation between your install and the average desktop user.Your best bet for security is probably running OpenBSD, but within Linux, if you avoid common optional applications and services like Gnome, KDE, pulseaudio, systemd, etc., you'll have a significantly different attack vector.  Avoiding Python and Node package managers and sticking to your distribution's package manager would be great, too.
comments.content_cn: 许多运行Linux的服务器经常成为恶意软件的攻击目标。桌面用户使用的软件与服务器上运行的软件存在很大差异，但Linux的优势在于，您可以在自己的安装配置和普通桌面用户之间保持同样大的差异性。最安全的选择可能是运行OpenBSD，但在Linux系统中，如果您避开常见的可选应用和服务，如Gnome、KDE、pulseaudio、systemd等，您的受攻击面将显著不同。同时，避免使用Python和Node的包管理器，坚持使用发行版自带的包管理器也会很有帮助。

comments.author: cosmic_cheese

Elsewhere, the most that’s needed is ticking a checkbox (if that). Worse, the mode of failure if you haven’t done the correct dance is unintelligible errors in e.g. GNOME Boxes that don’t even point the user in the right direction.There’s all sorts of somewhat low hanging fruit like this that I suspect hasn’t gotten attention because it’s not particularly sexy or interesting.

comments.content: I love Cachy, but please don't recommend it as a reasonable first step into Linux.It's a lot more polished than Arch, but it's not for someone who hasn't used Linux before and wants a reliably rock solid and predictable experience 365 days a year, with no fiddling.It's rolling release, and there are inevitably bugs when updating immediately to every minor version of every part of the OS stack. Arch/Cachy/Endeavour are for experts, and those who enjoy tinkering. comments.author: doodlesdev
comments.content: Do CachyOS optimizations actually make any difference whatsoever? I know they enable certain optimization flags whenever building software, but that doesn't directly equate to performance improvements unless you're actually benchmarking and testing it. I've seen some benchmarks in games and it seems there is literally zero performance difference (sometimes it loses to Fedora, even).I'd always recommend upstream distributions with corporate backing for novice users: Ubuntu or Fedora. If they're coming from Windows: Linux Mint. There's also a clear upgrade path for users who enjoy Mint or Ubuntu: Debian testing.Arch Linux is awesome, don't get me wrong. I just believe it's borderline unethical to recommend someone installing anything related to Arch on their workstation. It's just not what a beginner should choose at all. CachyOS included, it even makes you choose your bootloader at install (any user-friendly distro would simply never bother you with that and go with GRUB right away).A user's first distro can make or break their Linux experience. Think hard before recommending new users the flavor of the month or an Arch derivative.
comments.content_cn:
CachyOS的优化真的有任何实际效果吗？我知道他们在构建软件时会启用某些优化标志，但这并不直接等同于性能提升，除非你真正进行基准测试和验证。我见过一些游戏性能测试，结果似乎完全没有性能差异（有时甚至不如Fedora）。对于新手用户，我总是推荐有企业支持的上游发行版：Ubuntu或Fedora。如果他们来自Windows系统：Linux Mint是更好的选择。对于喜欢Mint或Ubuntu的用户，还有一个清晰的升级路径：Debian测试版。

请不要误会，Arch Linux本身很棒。我只是认为，推荐任何人在他们的工作机上安装与Arch相关的系统几乎是不道德的。这完全不是初学者应该选择的系统。CachyOS也不例外，它甚至在安装时让你选择引导程序（任何用户友好的发行版都不会用这种问题打扰用户，而是直接使用GRUB）。

用户选择的第一个发行版可能成就也可能毁掉他们的Linux体验。在向新用户推荐当下流行的版本或Arch衍生系统之前，请慎重考虑。

comments.author: pxoe
comments.content: Even if they pick a distro and decide to install it, more often than not the install process is still overly convoluted even in just making installation media.Going to a distro website and trying to find where to get it (ubuntu has a habit of leading with literally anything else other than regular desktop distro on their front page). Getting to a 'how to install' page and having it be intimidatingly long, perhaps even needlessly. Sites, pages and explainers being laid out in confounding ways, and install process sometimes laid out in a bit of an overcomplicated way. (debian has an installation guide that's presented perhaps in the most intimidating way possible to a new unwitting user, and also buried under click on a click on a click. somehow writing the iso is not even among the first dozen of pages there. ubuntu mate gives you links to iso downloads, and yet the installation process is buried under 'faq' (again, not very intuitive or straightforward), that faq only has a bunch of oddly laid out 'making installation media' pages, and the rest of actual installation process is just somewhere else.)That's before someone even gets to the actual install process. Somehow all of that stuff hasn't gotten more streamlined or user friendly. If you try to see how one would go about getting and installing any distro, you'd quickly see that it's very confusing and convoluted, way more than it has to be, or needs to be to appeal and be simple for new users.There's glimmers of hope, like fedora which has its media writer, which is gonna hold your hand through the whole thing. Even that links out to github for a download, despite clicking on a seemingly specific 'windows/mac or linux' button. It's a little buried too, below iso downloads, when it really should be brought up more forward, and explain a little bit better on how it's gonna guide you thru the whole thing.It really should be an app that's gonna guide you thru it, or a dead simple 1-2-3 step tutorial that's gonna guide you thru writing an image (download writer, download iso, write an image - laying it out more than that is just overcomplicating it really, at least in the initial quick install guide), with a clear, visible link to it - and yet somehow even this is too high of a bar for many distros to clear.What has done a number on the ease of installing linux is how compact discs have just went away, because having a compact disc, burning it, or having it be just sent to users was making that step of the process simpler. Sure, writing to a USB is easy, but the expectation that everyone's just gonna have a spare usb is naive (and you're never gonna hear that you actually need to buy a usb stick in any of those guides lol), and there's just a little more opportunity to fuck up there (overwriting other disks, unless the writer app is laid out nicely and fail-proof). Distros might as well start selling usb sticks with installers on them. If someone's gonna be brand new to the whole thing and they're gonna have to buy a usb stick anyway, they might as well buy it from the distro with the distro on it already.Some distros may want to get real about how a new user would even navigate their websites in order to get the thing. posts.title: I replaced Windows with Linux and everything's going great
posts.author: rorylawless
posts.title_cn: 我换用Linux替代Windows，一切进展顺利
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕用户从Windows转向Linux操作系统的个人体验展开。核心话题是Linux作为桌面系统的实用性和用户体验。多数用户对Linux的稳定性和自由度表示认可，有人认为长期使用后几乎不会遇到问题，甚至成功向家人推荐；也有用户指出，对于游戏等特定需求，Linux现已具备良好支持。然而，社区存在明显分歧：一方强调Linux对现代硬件的优化及日常使用的流畅性，另一方则批评其硬件兼容性不足，例如鼠标无法正常使用等基础问题，并质疑选择小众发行版（如CachyOS）可能影响体验代表性。讨论中提到，如果选择Ubuntu等主流发行版可能避免部分问题。共识在于，Linux适合有一定技术基础或愿意学习的用户，但对于追求“开箱即用”的普通用户，Windows或macOS仍是更稳妥的选择。

comments.author: IgorPartola
comments.content: Back in the days of Unity I decided to make a full switch to Linux and it just worked. The UX was unfamiliar but it had a cohesiveness that made sense. I use macOS for the past 10 years as my main system (work stuff needs Mac-specific things) but switching to a decent Linux distro would honestly feel like an upgrade. Windows continues being a shitshow and I want nothing to do with it.What I think could really push Linux desktop forward is if various PC gaming influencers started doing content on how to game on Linux. Given that it is not just viable now but actively sometimes better than on Windows it would make for good content AND show people an alternative. And soon as AAA games start being created for Linux first and run on Windows in some sort of compatibility or emulation mode that will really start turning the tides.
comments.content_cn: 在Unity时代，我曾决定全面转向Linux系统，结果一切顺利。虽然用户体验有些陌生，但其整体设计具有一种内在的连贯性。过去十年我一直以macOS为主力系统（工作需要某些Mac专属功能），但说实话，切换到优秀的Linux发行版反而像是一种升级。Windows始终像个烂摊子，我完全不想与之扯上关系。我认为真正能推动Linux桌面发展的，是让各类PC游戏领域有影响力的人开始制作关于如何在Linux上玩游戏的教程内容。考虑到现在Linux不仅可行，有时甚至比Windows表现更佳，这类内容既能吸引观众，又能向人们展示另一种选择。等到3A大作开始优先为Linux开发，再通过兼容或模拟模式在Windows上运行时，局面将真正开始扭转。

comments.author: compounding_it
comments.content: My personal experience with using macOS (m1 2020-) Windows 10 (2018-2020) and Linux (for the last 16-17 years on off) -If you want to do basic stuff like browsing streaming learning video calls etc, get a non Linux computer with decent specs with some headroom. These operating systems are for people who just want to use that ecosystem and not need to manage anything themselves. Battery life is exceptional. Most people I know need a one or two step process to do things (like backup photos contacts documents etc) and Apple google Microsoft offer you that. It’s not perfect but it’s easy to manage. People really have gotten used to someone managing it for them and these things do fine in that regard. It’s better than people having 5 hard drives with photos and misplacing them imo. I’ve had people in 2000s connect drives to my computers and find private pictures and contacts and files etc I need not be having access to. iCloud and Google Photos offer you that peace of mind. With 2FA you’d rather lose it all than fall into the wrong hands. People have all kinds of stuff on their phones and computers that should not leave their computers and accounts. Imagine having your kids classmates find your intimate pictures on some drive they used to copy something your kid gave them. All this has reduced with cloud managed services with activation locks and 2FA and password mangers built into them. Yes they can lock you out one day, but it’s better than people having access to it.If you are serious about your personal computer, switch to Linux before you start hating those companies. You are not the target audience anymore and you shouldn’t be disappointed about it.I use Linux for most things, macOS for streaming and surfing the web (private relay and 4k native works great on M1) and windows when I have to deal with others having windows only accounting software sometime.

comments.author: 20after4

And even those are use-cases where Linux has viable options. Actually, Video probably doesn't even belong here since one of the most popular video packages (DaVinci Resolve) has Linux support and there are multiple open source options like Kdenlive. comments.author: rickcarlino
comments.content: Linux is one of the last strong defenses for the idea that people should control the computers they own. On desktops and servers, root access is normal, and attempts to take it away do not work because software freedom is well established. On phones, that never happened. There is no real, mainstream “Linux for mobile,” and the result is a world of locked-down platforms where things like “sideloading” are treated as scary security risks instead of basic user rights. This makes it much easier for lawmakers to argue for removing root access on mobile devices, even though the same idea would be unrealistic on desktop systems.A great deal of gratitude is owed to all the people who volunteer their free time to create the stable desktop environment we have free access to on Linux in 2026.
comments.content_cn: Linux是捍卫“用户应掌控自有设备”理念的最后坚实堡垒之一。在桌面和服务器领域，root权限是常态，任何剥夺该权限的尝试都难以奏效，因为软件自由已深入人心。但在手机领域，这一理念从未实现。市场上缺乏真正主流的“移动版Linux”，导致我们被困在封闭的平台生态中——诸如“侧载应用”这类基础用户权利竟被视为可怕的安全威胁。这种现状使得立法者更容易主张移除移动设备的root权限，尽管同样的提议在桌面系统上根本不可行。我们应当深深感谢所有志愿者，他们奉献个人时间构建了稳定的桌面环境，让我们在2026年仍能自由使用Linux系统。

comments.author: tombert
comments.content: I've been running desktop Linux for about eighteen years, though I did take a break and run a Macbook for about four years.It's a little upsetting that Windows has gotten so terrible, because I think in a lot of ways the NT Kernel is a better piece of software than the Linux kernel.   Drivers are simply easier to install and they generally don't require a reboot and they don't require messing with kernel modules, IO is non-blocking by default, and a bunch of other things that are cool and arguably better than Linux.The problem is that, while the kernel is an important part of an operating system, it's not the only part.  Even if the NT kernel were the objectively best piece of software ever to be written by humans, that still doesn't change the fact that Windows has become a pretty awful mess. They have loaded the OS with so much crap (and ads now!), the Windows Update tool routinely breaks your computer, their recovery/repair tools simply do not work, their filesystem is geriatric and has been been left behind compared to stuff like ZFS, btrfs, and APFS, and they don't really seem determined to fix any of this stuff.Even if the Linux kernel were to be slightly worse, it's still good enough.  Even if you do have to muck with kernel modules it's not that hard now with DKMS. Even if the IO is blocking by default epoll has been around for decades and works fine.So at that point, if the kernel is good enough, and if we can get userland decent enough, then desktop Linux is better than Windows. Linux is good enough, without ads, with recovery tools that actually work, and performs comparably or better than Windows.
comments.content_cn:
我使用桌面版Linux大约有十八年了，虽然中间曾中断过四年，改用Macbook。Windows变得如此糟糕实在令人有些沮丧，因为我觉得从很多方面来看，NT内核其实是比Linux内核更优秀的软件。驱动安装简单得多，通常无需重启，也不必折腾内核模块；默认采用非阻塞IO，还有许多其他酷炫且可以说优于Linux的特性。

问题在于，内核虽是操作系统的重要组成部分，却并非全部。即便NT内核堪称人类编写过的最优秀软件，也无法改变Windows已变得一团糟的事实。他们在系统中塞入了太多无用之物（现在还有广告！），Windows更新工具经常搞坏电脑，恢复/修复工具基本失灵，文件系统老旧不堪，与ZFS、btrfs、APFS等相比已然落后，而且他们似乎也没有真正决心解决这些问题。

即使Linux内核稍逊一筹，它仍然足够好用。就算需要折腾内核模块，现在有了DKMS也不算太难。即便默认采用阻塞IO，epoll技术已存在数十年且运行良好。因此在这种情况下，如果内核足够优秀，用户空间也能达到理想状态，那么桌面版Linux显然是更好的选择……

There has been one time in 5 years that he had to reach out for technical assistance. It turned out that he had been misled by a prompt to buy Ubuntu pro and had gotten into a weird state. I blame that one solely on canonical, not on Linux in general. After that I switched him to Fedora, and he's been running that now for a few years and didn't even realize I had changed his underlying OS. He is able to install anything he wants from the graphical storefront, and same with updates. In the early days we did have some trouble getting his printer to work, though once we switched him to Fedora everything on that printer worked out of the box. When my sister came over to his house with her MacBook, she had to mess with the Mac to get the printer working for over an hour, and it was still pretty hit or miss. It would lose half the jobs she tried to send to it. It truly is remarkable how usable Linux is for the average person now. For people that have to run software that only runs on Windows or Linux, excluding games of course since steam and other game managers handle those wonderfully now, there is definitely still a bit of pain. But for people who can get by with cloud-based or Linux friendly software, it's really quite good.

坦率地说，苹果为其传统电脑开发的操作系统感觉像垃圾。我个人设备用Arch/Gnome，感觉过去五年左右我的观点彻底转变了——我曾认为Gnome大多在模仿苹果的设计思路，只是稍逊一筹。现在我觉得Gnome比苹果推出的系统更清晰、更好用。去年我给妻子的个人笔记本换了Arch/Gnome，最明显的迹象是她根本没遇到什么问题。

话虽如此……我还是留了一台装Windows 11的笔记本，因为有些旧工具（数控机床、太阳能逆变器）仍然需要它。天啊，现代Windows简直是彻头彻尾的垃圾。我从小用Windows，从3.1到10，现在它无疑是三者中最差的，而且差得很远。

当唯一感觉真正为用户设计的操作系统是免费产品时，你就知道商业科技公司出问题了。

posts.title_cn: 问HN：你正在做什么？（2026年1月）
posts.content_cn: 你在忙什么？有什么新想法在酝酿吗？
posts.abstract:
这是一个关于HackerNews社区成员在2026年1月分享个人项目的讨论帖。核心话题是开发者们正在进行的各种技术探索与创意项目，展现了广泛的兴趣领域。

讨论中提到，许多用户专注于解决实际工程问题或填补技术空白。有人认为当前软件工程师面试过于侧重算法题（LeetCode），未能有效评估真实工程能力，因此正在设计更注重技术判断的替代方案。也有用户指出Linux打印扫描栈存在大量基础缺陷，并投入多年进行改进。同时，社区中不乏充满个人趣味的项目，例如通过基因工程培育特殊风味的面包酵母、开发基于能力与消息传递的新型软件平台原型，以及制作帮助人们应对冬季日照缩短的网站。

普遍认同的看法是，这些项目大多源于个人需求或兴趣驱动，体现了技术社区的多样性和创造力。主要分歧在于项目目标的实用性导向不同：一部分人致力于改善基础设施和工具链，另一部分则更侧重于艺术表达、生活品质或纯粹的好奇心探索。其他被提及的项目还包括浏览器扩展、流媒体服务器、AI助手工具和Web图形渲染器等。

comments.author: sph
comments.content: After years of wondering what the post-UNIX paradigm of computing could look like, these past few months I've been prototyping a software platform built around capabilities and message passing, targeting Linux and bare-metal RISC-V. The big ideas I'm pursuing is a stackless design running on a flat address space with lightweight processes to minimize message-passing latency, and all the benefits of capabilities so every process is sandboxed and has only access to capabilities they have been explicitly passed via message passing.I've also built a RISC-V emulator to integrate with this platform, so eventually it'll be able to run native binaries written in any language, completely sandboxed, completely built around message-passing. Basically a native, low-level BEAM-like platform to build an entire operating system and user-space.While my day job is writing boring applications, this is the stuff that keeps me awake at night, and I would love so much to talk and write more about this, about the trial-and-errors I'm facing, but it's still so much in flux every week I'm exploring a new approach. Most of my work has been around the stackless scheduler, and I have a plan to achieve preemption for long-running or misbehaved tasks without having to compromise on memory usage (i.e. without giving each process its own stack and allocate memory for context switching).Eventually I'd like to layer on top either Cap'n Proto or another high-performance serialisation system to create a distributed, introspectable environment of object-capabilities that are sending typed messages between each other, achieving the ultimate goal of creating an unholy hybrid between Smalltalk and the Erlang VM.God, how I wish I was paid to work on this type of problems :-)If this sounds close to your area of interests, please send me an email and I’d love to chat.
comments.content_cn:
多年来我一直在思考后UNIX时代的计算范式会是什么样子，最近几个月我一直在开发一个围绕能力和消息传递构建的软件平台原型，目标平台是Linux和裸机RISC-V。我追求的核心构想是：在平坦地址空间上运行无栈设计，通过轻量级进程最小化消息传递延迟，并充分发挥能力机制的优势——每个进程都运行在沙箱中，仅能通过消息传递显式获取的能力权限进行访问。

我还构建了与该平台集成的RISC-V模拟器，最终它将能够原生运行任何语言编写的二进制文件，完全沙箱化，完全围绕消息传递构建。本质上这是一个类似BEAM的原生底层平台，可用于构建完整的操作系统和用户空间。

虽然日常工作只是编写常规应用程序，但这个项目让我彻夜难眠。我非常希望能多讨论和记录这个项目，分享遇到的试错过程，但每周都在探索新方案导致设计变动频繁。目前主要工作集中在无栈调度器上，我计划在不增加内存开销（即不为每个进程分配独立栈空间和上下文切换内存）的前提下，实现对长时间运行或异常任务的中断机制。

comments.content:
Script to auto-rename screenshots with Claude CodeI'm sure there are a ton of other projects out there that do this, but I couldn't find one that fit my needs exactly, so I threw this together in a few hours.claude-image-renamer uses Claude Code CLI to analyze screenshots and rename them to something actually usable. It combines OCR text extraction with Claude's vision capabilities, so instead of "Screenshot 2025-12-29 at 10.03.10 PM.png" you get something like "vscode_python_debug_settings.png".A few things it does:    Handles those annoying macOS screenshot filenames with weird Unicode characters
    Uses OCR to give Claude more context for better naming
    Keeps filenames clean (lowercase, underscores, max 64 chars)
    Handles naming conflicts automatically

If you're on macOS, you can also set this up as a Folder Action so screenshots get renamed automatically when they are saved to a folder, typically ~/Desktop. This is useful if you take a lot of screenshots and hate digging through "Screenshot 2025-12..." files later.GitHub: https://github.com/jftuga/claude-image-renamer

使用Claude Code自动重命名截图的脚本
我知道市面上有很多类似功能的项目，但没找到完全符合我需求的，所以花了几小时自己动手做了这个。
claude-image-renamer利用Claude Code CLI分析截图，将其重命名为真正实用的文件名。它结合了OCR文本提取和Claude的视觉识别能力，因此你得到的不会是"Screenshot 2025-12-29 at 10.03.10 PM.png"这类名称，而是像"vscode_python_debug_settings.png"这样有意义的文件名。
它的功能包括：
    处理macOS截图文件名中恼人的特殊Unicode字符
    通过OCR为Claude提供更多上下文信息，以生成更准确的文件名
    保持文件名整洁规范（小写字母、下划线分隔、最长64字符）
    自动处理命名冲突

如果你使用macOS，还可以将其设置为文件夹操作，这样当截图保存到指定文件夹（通常是~/Desktop）时就会自动重命名。如果你经常截图又不喜欢事后在一堆"Screenshot 2025-12..."文件中翻找，这个功能会非常实用。
GitHub地址：https://github.com/jftuga/claude-image-renamer

comments.author: liu3hao
comments.content: Hi HN, I am working on Circuitscript, a language based on python to describe electronic schematics: https://circuitscript.net/. A basic IDE (called the Bench) to try Circuitscript is available online: https://bench.circuitscript.net/During the December break, I have implemented some new features: automatic stable refdes annotations, parameter assignment rules for easy part number assignment and some ERC rules. These are also important parts of the design workflow to help turn a schematic into a usable BOM and layout.I have created a usb-uart converter board with the CH340 chip. The complete schematic was coded with Circuitscript and then imported as a netlist into kicad pcbnew to do the pcb layout. The design was produced with JLCPCB and after receiving the boards I tested them and they do work! The design files are here https://github.com/liu3hao/usb-uart-bridge. The circuitscript code file is here https://github.com/liu3hao/usb-uart-bridge/blob/main/usb_uar... and the generated pdf from the circuitscript code is here: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/liu3hao/usb-uart-bridge/re...The motivation for creating Circuitscript is to describe schematics in terms of code rather than graphical UIs after using different CAD packages extensively (Allegro, Altium, KiCAD) for work in the past. I wanted to spend more time thinking about the schematic design itself rather than fiddling around with GUIs.Please check it out and I look forward to your feedback, especially from electronics designers/hobbyists. Thanks!

comments.author: ValdikSS
comments.content: I work mostly with the old microcontroller-based cheap consumer ("GDI") USB models circa 2000-2010, these are hardly possible to brick with software, as some of them even don't have a firmware and expect the PC to upload it on each power on sequence.The hardware safety mechanisms are usually robust (USB communication is handled by "Formatter Board", all the mechanical stuff is in the "Engine Controller" power).Newer Linux-based models have filesystems, software, and vulnerabilities, printer hacking on Pwn2Own is an every year common occurrence. These could be permanently bricked by the software in a common sense, and would require a firmware reflash using the bootloader or external means.>Or is it possible to work on hardware support without having a physical device?Absolutely, but for me this is very inconvenient—like the debugging over the phone.Sometimes the bug is as low-level as in the USB stack: https://lore.kernel.org/linux-usb/3fe845b9-1328-4b40-8b02-61...>I assume it is impossible to test each and every one printer and scanner, so there is probably some clever tricks there, right?Not much, unfortunately. There's ongoing work on modern (driverless) printer behavior emulation, but it is under heavy development and not ready yet: https://github.com/OpenPrinting/go-mfpNothing for the older printers and scanners which require it's own driver, of what I'm aware.

我主要接触2000-2010年间基于旧式微控制器的廉价消费级（"GDI"）USB型号打印机，这些设备几乎不可能通过软件刷成砖机，因为其中部分型号甚至没有固件，需要电脑在每次开机时上传固件程序。它们的硬件安全机制通常很可靠（USB通信由"格式化主板"处理，所有机械操作则由"引擎控制器"负责供电）。

新型基于Linux系统的打印机则具备文件系统、软件和相应漏洞，Pwn2Own竞赛中每年都有打印机被攻破的案例。这类打印机确实可能因常规软件操作导致永久性损坏，需要通过引导程序或外部手段重新刷写固件。

>是否可以在没有实体设备的情况下进行硬件支持开发？
当然可以，但对我而言这种方式极不方便——就像通过电话进行调试。有时故障可能出现在USB协议栈这样的底层环节：https://lore.kernel.org/linux-usb/3fe845b9-1328-4b40-8b02-61...

>我猜不可能测试所有型号的打印机和扫描仪，应该存在某些巧妙的解决方案吧？
遗憾的是目前方法有限。现代（免驱动）打印机行为模拟的相关工作正在进行中，但尚处于深度开发阶段：https://github.com/OpenPrinting/go-mfp
据我所知，对于需要专用驱动的旧式打印机和扫描仪，目前还没有相应解决方案。

posts.title: The struggle of resizing windows on macOS Tahoe
posts.author: happosai
posts.title_cn: macOS Tahoe系统中调整窗口大小的困境
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕macOS Tahoe系统中窗口缩放功能的设计变更展开。核心争议在于新版系统的窗口边缘拖拽区域设计被许多用户认为反直觉且难以使用。有人认为，Tahoe的拖拽区域延伸至窗口角落外侧的做法令人困惑，与Windows 11类似的设计都被批评为倒退；也有用户指出，该系统还存在应用随机失去焦点等严重影响使用的缺陷。讨论中提到，部分用户怀念早期macOS系统明确标示可拖拽区域的视觉设计，认为当前变化破坏了历经35年验证的交互逻辑。普遍共识是此次更新引发了广泛不满，有用户将其类比为Windows Vista或Windows 8级别的失败改版。分歧点在于：部分用户认为拖拽区域扩展至角落外侧实际是改进，而更多用户则强烈谴责这种违背用户习惯的设计决策，并质疑苹果让视觉设计过度主导功能开发的问题。

comments.author: DonHopkins
comments.content: >"The products suck! There's no sex in them anymore!"Enter "Lickable Pixels" -- the phrase that stuck to describe the Aqua era.Introducing Mac OS X's Aqua interface, Jobs said at Macworld in January 2000: "We made the buttons on the screen look so good you'll want to lick them."https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aqua_(user_interface)Then there was the red hot irresistibly sexy and well designed IBM Thinkpad TrackPoint -AKA- Keyboard Clitoris -AKA- Joy Button, and IBM's explicitly lascivious "So Hot, We Had To Make It Red" ad.https://www.reddit.com/r/thinkpad/comments/hodidb/so_hot_we_...Ted Selker, the inventor of the TrackPoint, told me the story of how that ad got written and refined by focus groups: He slyly suggested the slogan, and IBM's ad designers begrudgingly put it on the page in small text in the corner, below the photo and ad copy. Then they A/B tested it with the text a little bigger, then a bit bolder, then even higher, and it finally worked its way up to the top of the page in BIG HUGE BOLD TEXT!More about Ted's work:https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34425576Ted Selker fondly reminds me of "Mr. Lossoff" the "Button Man" in "A Nero Wolfe Mystery” episode “The Mother Hunt”, where Archie drops in on "Mister Lossoff’s Distinguished Buttons” in the garment district of New York:https://youtu.be/h-QgWOSVKm4?t=724He's totally THAT enthusiastic, a distinguished expert fiendishly obsessed with buttons! He even carries around a big bag of replacement Joy Buttons that he hands out for free like candy to anyone who’s worn theirs out.I know this from personal experience: Ted and his wife Ellen once ran into me working on my Thinkpad at some coffee shop in Mountain View, and Ted noticed my worn out Joy Button. He excused himself to run out to his car to fetch his Button Bag, while Ellen smiled at me and rolled her eyes up into her head and shrugged, and we hung out and talked until he got back. I really appreciated a nice new crisp one with fresh bumpy texture, because mine was totally worn down, and it made his day to get rid of a few. (I imagine their house has hoards of boxes and piles of bags full of them!)The common thread: design that makes you come. Back for more, that is. Buttons to lick till they click. Nubs to rub till they're bald. Products you touched obsessively until they're worn smooth. Tahoe gives us clownish corners we can't even grab. Apple dropped the ball -- and frankly, it's a kick in the nuts.
comments.content_cn:
“这些产品太烂了！一点性感元素都没有了！”于是“可舔式像素”这个说法流行起来，成为描述Aqua时代的标志性短语。在2000年1月的Macworld大会上，乔布斯介绍Mac OS X的Aqua界面时说：“我们把屏幕上的按钮做得如此诱人，你会忍不住想舔一口。”

接着是那款炙手可热、设计性感迷人的IBM Thinkpad TrackPoint——也被称为键盘阴蒂或快乐按钮，以及IBM那则明目张胆挑逗的广告语“太火辣，我们不得不把它做成红色”。

TrackPoint的发明者泰德·塞尔克向我讲述了这则广告如何通过焦点小组打磨成型的故事：他狡猾地提议了这个标语，IBM的广告设计师勉强将其以小字号放在照片和广告文案下方的角落。随后他们通过A/B测试逐步调整——先是把文字调大一点，再加粗一些，接着提升位置，最终这条标语以硕大粗体的形式登上了广告页面的顶端！

关于泰德工作的更多细节：他让我不禁想起《尼禄·沃尔夫之谜》剧集《母亲狩猎》中那位“纽扣先生”——“洛索夫先生”。剧中阿奇造访纽约服装区的“洛索夫尊贵纽扣店”的场景，完美诠释了泰德那种对按钮的狂热痴迷：他正是那样充满热情，一位痴迷于按钮的杰出专家！他甚至随身带着一大袋备用快乐按钮，随时准备……

Everything from being able to clearly distinguish UI elements, to general accessibility, to discoverability, everything got worse.Operating Systems are one of the most complicated systems we created, not because they're a collection of processes and thread, but because everything is built on top of them and creating something that's well thought out and stable, and intuitive is really hard. Designers just randomly creating visual elements just because it looks cool and not paying attention how people are going to use it is simply half assing the whole thing.That's still one of the reasons I believe Alan Dye was let go, fired in a sense, he had power over the company, but with that power he screwed things so much that we need to rediscover all the things related to usability in very high detail as if we're rediscovering the wheel, just so that we can get back to square one.
comments.content_cn: MacOS一直有其独特之处，但它的直观设计经过深思熟虑，体验良好。每当我们提到Tahoe系统彻底搞砸了设计时，苹果的工程师和视觉设计师们总会迅速进入防御状态——因为这不仅仅是一次向玻璃化设计的转型，更是对设计原则的彻底背离，以至于整个系统正逐渐变得对用户充满敌意。对26系列系统的所有批评都可以像这篇文章一样，用早已刻在苹果设计准则中的深层设计原理来解释，但苹果自身却完全忽视了这些原则。从清晰区分UI元素，到通用无障碍功能，再到操作可发现性，所有方面都在倒退。操作系统是我们创造的最复杂系统之一，这并非因为它由进程和线程堆砌而成，而是因为一切功能都构建于其上，要打造一个深思熟虑、稳定且直观的系统极其困难。设计师仅因视觉炫酷就随意创建界面元素，毫不关注用户实际使用方式，这完全是对系统设计的敷衍。这仍然是我认为艾伦·戴伊被解雇的原因之一——他在公司拥有权力，却滥用这种权力将设计搞得一团糟，以至于我们现在需要像重新发明轮子般，事无巨细地重新探索所有可用性相关细节，只为了能让系统回归正轨。

comments.author: crazygringo

comments.author: keyringlight
comments.content: IIRC, win8 was the last windows to have thick graphical window borders, and that was after they got rid of the texture/aero look from vista/7, so at that point you at least had something graphical to grab onto which (mostly?) matched where the cursor was. comments.author: diskzero
comments.content: I worked on Finder/TimeMachine/Spotlight/iOS at Apple from 2000-2007. I worked closely with Bas Ording, Stephen Lemay, Marcel van Os, Imran Chaudry, Don Lindsey and Greg Christie. I have no experience with any of the designers who arrived in the post-Steve era. During my time, Jony Ive didn't figure prominently in the UI design, although echoes of his industrial design appeared in various ways in the graphic design of the widgets. Kevin Tiene and Scott Forstall had more influence for better or worse, extreme skeumorphism for example.The UX group would present work to Steve J. every Thursday and Steve quickly passed judgement often harshly and without a lot of feedback, leading to even longer meetings afterward to try and determine course corrections. Steve J. and Bas were on the same wavelength and a lot of what Bas would show had been worked on directly with Steve before hand. Other things would be presented for the first time, and Steve could be pretty harsh. Don, Greg, Scott, Kevin would push back and get abused, but they took the abuse and could make in-roads.Here is my snapshot of Stephen from the time. He presented the UI ideas for the intial tabbed window interface in Safari. He had multiple design ideas and Steve dismissed them quickly and harshly. Me recollection was that Steve said something like No, next, worse, next, even worse, next, no. Why don't you come back next week with something better. Stephen didn't push back, say much, just went ok and that was that. I think Greg was the team manager at the time and pushed Steve for more input and maybe got some. This was my general observation of how Stephen was over 20 years ago.I am skeptical and doubtful about Stephen's ability to make a change unless he is facilitated greatly by someone else or has somehow changed drastically. The fact that he has been on the team while the general opinion of Apple UX quality has degraded to the current point of the Tahoe disaster is telling. Several team members paid dearly in emotional abuse under Steve and decided to leave rather than deal with the environment post Steve's death. Stephen is a SJ-era original and should have been able to push hard against what many of us perceive as very poor decisons. He either agreed with those decisions, or did not, and choose to go with the flow and enjoy the benefits of working at Apple. This is fine I guess. Many people are just fine going with the flow and not rocking the boat. It may be even easier when you have Apple-level comp and benefits.My opinon; unless Stephen gets a very strong push from other forces, I don't see that he has the will or fortitude to make the changes that he himself has approved in one way or another. Who will push him? Tim Cook, Craig Federighi, Eddy Cue, Phil Schiller? The perceived mess of Tahoe happened on the watch of all of these Apple leaders.

用户体验团队每周四都会向史蒂夫·乔布斯展示工作成果，他往往迅速作出严厉评判且很少给出具体反馈，导致后续需要召开更长时间的会议来调整方向。史蒂夫与巴斯思维高度同步，巴斯展示的很多内容都曾与史蒂夫直接商讨过。其他首次呈现的方案则可能遭到史蒂夫相当尖锐的批评。唐、格雷格、斯科特和凯文会提出反驳并承受激烈指责，但他们接纳了这些批评并逐步推进了工作。

posts.title: AI is a business model stress test
posts.author: amarsahinovic
posts.title_cn: AI是对商业模式的压力测试
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“AI是对商业模式的压力测试”这一核心话题展开，探讨人工智能技术如何冲击现有商业模式。有人认为AI训练数据构成知识产权盗窃，削弱了内容创作的激励；也有用户指出问题更复杂，关键在于原有依赖流量或服务的间接变现模式受到挑战。讨论中提到，部分开源或工具类项目（如Tailwind Labs）因AI降低使用门槛而面临生存危机，体现了价值从产品本身向运维、安全等操作环节转移的趋势。对于解决方案，有观点主张向大型科技公司征税以资助开源及艺术领域，但这一提议被部分用户视为过度保护商业模式的“犯罪”。整体来看，社区普遍认同AI正在重塑传统盈利逻辑，但在知识产权界定、行业影响及政策应对等方面存在明显分歧。

comments.content_cn: 在我看来，大型语言模型是知识产权的盗窃行为。就像我开始分发书籍副本一样，这会大大降低创造新知识产权的动力。所有书面文本、艺术作品等都需要附带类似GPL的许可：如果你用这些内容训练模型，就必须公开你的权重和训练代码。

comments.author: theropost
comments.content: I think there is a real issue here, but I do not think it is as simple as calling it theft in the same way as copying books. The bigger problem is incentives. We built a system where writing docs, tutorials, and open technical content paid off indirectly through traffic, subscriptions, or services. LLMs get a lot of value from that work, but they also break the loop that used to send value back to the people and companies who created it.The Tailwind CSS situation is a good example. They built something genuinely useful, adoption exploded, and in the past that would have meant more traffic, more visibility, and more revenue. Now the usage still explodes, but the traffic disappears because people get answers directly from LLMs. The value is clearly there, but the money never reaches the source. That is less a moral problem and more an economic one.Ideas like GPL-style licensing point at the right tension, but they are hard to apply after the fact. These models were built during a massive spending phase, financed by huge amounts of capital and debt, and they are not even profitable yet. Figuring out royalties on top of that, while the infrastructure is already in place and rolling out at scale, is extremely hard.That is why this feels like a much bigger governance problem. We have a system that clearly creates value, but no longer distributes it in a sustainable way. I am not sure our policies or institutions are ready to catch up to that reality yet.
comments.content_cn:
我认为这里确实存在一个问题，但我不认为简单地将其等同于抄袭书籍那样的盗窃行为。更大的问题在于激励机制。我们建立了一个体系，其中编写文档、教程和开源技术内容通过流量、订阅或服务间接获得回报。大型语言模型从这些工作中获取了大量价值，但它们也打破了原本将价值回馈给创作者个人和公司的循环。

Tailwind CSS的情况就是一个很好的例子。他们构建了一个真正有用的工具，使用量激增，在过去这意味着更多流量、更高知名度和更多收入。如今使用量依然暴涨，但流量却消失了，因为人们直接从大型语言模型获取答案。价值显然存在，但资金从未流向源头。这与其说是道德问题，不如说是经济问题。

类似GPL风格许可的想法指出了关键矛盾，但事后实施难度很大。这些模型是在大规模投入阶段构建的，由巨额资本和债务资助，甚至尚未实现盈利。在基础设施已经就位且大规模推广的情况下，还要在此基础上厘清版权分成机制，这极其困难。

这就是为什么这更像一个治理难题。我们拥有一个明显创造价值的体系，却不再以可持续的方式分配价值。我不确定我们的政策或机构是否已准备好应对这一现实。

comments.author: Roark66
comments.content: >"Value is shifting to operations: deployment, testing, rollbacks, observability. You can't prompt 99.95% uptime on Black Friday. Neither can you prompt your way to keeping a site secure, updated, and running"I've been doing exactly that since AI came out :-DYou absolutely can prompt your way to 3.5 nines of uptime (even more), but you need to know what you're doing and correct it.Even very well aligned models like Opus will make traps for your infrastructure. For example you tell it to write a fluxCD implementation of some application, in your k8 cluster, following your conventions and best practices described in some md files. And it does this, very nicely. But unless you tell it in advance every detail it will do something extremely stupid mid way through.For example, let's say you have a database and it needs to create a new instance (with gitops) for the app. It adds the new DB and it gets created, but instead of using a tool that already exists (or proposing one if it doesn't) to sync the DB access credentials from the DB na espace to the app namespace it will read the credential, encrypt it and store in the app namespace.What's the problem with that? Well, none unless you rotate these credentials. In which case your app will stop working, possibly after you tested it and decided it's good enough to use seriously, despite having a HA DB.There are a dozen things like this in each "ai project", but even with this. With the time needed to review everything it saves a lot of time.
comments.content_cn:
价值正转向运维领域：部署、测试、回滚、可观测性。你无法通过简单指令确保黑色星期五期间99.95%的正常运行时间，也无法仅靠指令就让网站保持安全、更新和稳定运行。自从人工智能出现以来，我一直在做这件事 :-D 你完全可以通过指令实现3.5个九（甚至更高）的可用性，但需要清楚自己在做什么并及时修正。

即使是像Opus这样高度适配的模型，也可能给你的基础设施埋下陷阱。例如，你要求它按照某个Markdown文件描述的规范和最佳实践，在你的Kubernetes集群中为某个应用编写FluxCD实施方案。它确实能出色完成任务，但除非你提前告知每个细节，否则过程中它可能做出极其愚蠢的行为。

举例来说，假设你有一个数据库，需要为应用创建新实例（采用GitOps方式）。它会添加新数据库并成功创建，但不会使用现有工具（或在不存时建议创建）将数据库访问凭证从数据库命名空间同步到应用命名空间，而是直接读取凭证、加密后存储到应用命名空间。

这有什么问题？如果不轮换凭证就没事。但一旦轮换凭证，你的应用就会停止工作——可能发生在你测试完毕并决定正式使用之后，尽管数据库本身是高可用的。

每个"人工智能项目"中都存在大量类似问题，但即便如此，考虑到审查所有细节所需的时间，它仍然能节省大量……

comments.author: PeterStuer
comments.content: Many FOSS business models did, explicitly or implicitly, rely, not on direct obfuscation or overcomplication, but on not making things easy. So you sell not the product, services around the product.This is not exclusive to FOSS. It is also the basic model of most non SaaS B2B, often for good reason referred to by the derogatory term 'consulting-ware'.AI eats into these services, as it commoditizes them. 80%+ of what used to take a specialist for that product can now be handled by a good generalist + AI.Leaving aside the business model impact for a second, getting rid of obfuscation incentives is intrinsically good thing for a user community.Dries' solution, offering operations as a SaaS or managed service, is meeting a need AI can't as easily match, but not exactly for the the stated reason. What the client is actually buying  is making something someone else's problem. And CIOs will always love this more than anything if they can credibly justify it.Where AI does impact this is in that latter part. If AI does significantly commoditize operational expertise, then the cost of in-house operating is (sometimes dramatically) lowered, and thus the justification gap on the CIO side for spending outside widens. How much this will drive a decision will be highly variable between businesses and projects.
comments.content_cn:
许多自由开源软件商业模式，无论明示或暗示，其依赖的并非直接的代码混淆或过度复杂化，而是刻意不追求便捷性。因此企业销售的并非产品本身，而是围绕产品的服务。这种现象并非自由开源软件独有，它也是大多数非SaaS类企业级软件的基本模式——这类模式常被贬称为“咨询型软件”，且往往有其合理成因。

人工智能正在侵蚀这类服务，因其将服务转化为标准化商品。过去需要产品专家处理的工作，如今超过80%可由优秀的通才借助人工智能完成。

暂且不论商业模式的冲击，消除代码混淆的动机对用户社区而言本质上是件好事。Dries提出的解决方案——将运维以SaaS或托管服务形式提供——确实满足了人工智能难以替代的需求，但根本原因与表面说法略有差异。客户实际购买的是将难题转嫁给他人的服务。只要能够合理论证，企业信息官始终对此类服务青睐有加。

人工智能真正产生影响的是在后端环节。若人工智能确实大幅降低了运维专业知识的门槛，那么企业内部运维成本将（有时是显著）降低，这反而会扩大企业信息官选择外部服务的合理性论证空间。这种影响对决策的驱动程度，会因企业类型和项目性质存在显著差异。

comments.author: pradn
comments.content: > The value got extracted, but compensation isn't flowing back. That bothers me, and it deserves a broader policy conversation.It bothers me, too. But, look at the history of the internet. There's no reason to expect we'll be able to fix this problem.1. Search engines drove traffic to news/content sites, which monetized via ads. Humans barely tolerate these ad filled websites. And yet, local news went into steep decline, and the big national players got an ever-larger share of attention. The large, national sites were able to keep a subscriber-based paywall model. These were largely legacy media sites (ie: NYT).2. News sites lost the local classifieds market, as the cost of advertising online went to zero (ie: Craigslist). This dynamic was a form of creative destruction - a better solution ate the business of an older solution.3. Blog monetization was always tough, beyond ads. Unless you were a big blog, you couldn't make a living. What about getting a small amount of money per view from random visitors? The internet never developed a micro-payment or subscription model for the set of open sites - the blogosphere, etc. The best we got were closed platforms like Substack and Medium, which could control access via paywalls.All this led to the internet being largely funded through the "attention economy": ads mostly, paywalls & subscriptions some.The attention economy can't sustain itself when there are fewer eyeballs:1. So one HTTP request, more or less, to get the docs and docs are no longer required.2. Tailwind does change, so an AI will want to access the docs for the version its working with. 1. 搜索引擎为新闻/内容网站带来流量，这些网站通过广告变现。人们勉强忍受这些充满广告的网站。然而，地方新闻急剧衰落，大型全国性媒体吸引了越来越多的注意力。大型全国性网站能够维持基于订阅的付费墙模式，这些大多是传统媒体网站（例如《纽约时报》）。

2. 随着在线广告成本趋近于零（例如Craigslist），新闻网站失去了本地分类广告市场。这种动态是一种创造性破坏——更好的解决方案取代了旧有业务。

3. 博客变现始终困难，除了广告之外几乎没有其他途径。除非你是大型博客，否则难以谋生。从随机访客那里按浏览量获取小额收入如何？互联网从未为博客圈等开放网站群体发展出微支付或订阅模式。我们得到的最好结果是Substack和Medium这类封闭平台，它们能通过付费墙控制访问。

这一切导致互联网主要通过"注意力经济"获得资金：大部分靠广告，少部分靠付费墙和订阅。

我认为软件行业的本质就是变革（正如我几天前在另一条讨论中提到的）。如果把“商业”层级想象成：客户在最上层，之下是业务层，再往下是分析层，接着是软件层，最底层是机器/基础设施……

25年前，我曾认为领域特定语言这类高度形式化的高层级描述会推动产品定义（即业务分析）与软件/编码之间的界限向软件端移动，从而减少软件在整个层级中的占比。然而，这种情况并未发生，恰恰相反——如今开发者被期望通晓从基础设施、软件实现、分析逻辑到业务领域乃至更高层的所有环节。因此，现在的层级结构更像是：客户在上，业务居中……而软件开发几乎涵盖一切。需求分析等工作大多已消失/转由开发者承担。

现在，如果整个“软件开发”环节变得利润趋零，我预见到两种可能：要么企业迅速重振业务分析（即产品定义环节）并将其作为利润护城河，要么客户开始自行开发软件（因为如今试错成本已大幅降低）——从而将传统商业角色彻底排除在交易链条之外。

comments.author: yowlingcat
comments.content: It isn't that simple. One of the implicit tradeoffs you make buying SaaS is that the overall cost of evolution (development and ongoing maintenance) is subsidized across all of the investment resources and customer base of the vendor. With CRM in particular, ecosystem integration is one of the heaviest buildouts there is because each point solution integration can very significantly in complexity and is also where the combinatoric explosion of misbehavior sets in.When you decide to pull that in house, you are implicitly burdening yourself with the cost of the buildout as well as ongoing maintenance. True, you could probably knock together an okay v1 of CRM yourself inhouse. But are you really going to get it to and maintain production level quality over time at a lower total cost of ownership? I'm skeptical.The theoretical party you are describing would probably be better served by simply avoiding Salesforce in favor of a next gen CRM that is both more cost effective and easier to customize. In enterprise contexts, even HubSpot is effectively next gen, but there are also products like Attio et al that have a ton of adoption and strong integration ecosystems (albeit not at the Salesforce level).When you buy enterprise software from a vendor you are buying more than "just software" you are also hiring a company's services. And the inverse is correct as well, when you choose to build it in house, you are implicitly choosing to hire a team internally to resource all of the services you would've expected that vendor to provide.Certainly, this tradeoff can still make a lot of sense for some companies. The acid test for that, in my opinion, is whether said company could (and would) actually successfully sell the product they build internally on the open market. If the answer to that is "yes", the prospect of turning a cost center into a profit center can potentially bear significant long term ROI to the company.
comments.content_cn:

你描述的那种理想情况，或许更适合直接避开Salesforce，转而选择成本效益更高、更易定制的下一代CRM系统。在企业应用场景中，连HubSpot都算得上是新一代选择，此外还有Attio等产品——它们已获得大量用户采用并拥有强大的集成生态（尽管未达到Salesforce的规模）。

当你从供应商处购买企业软件时，购买的不仅是“软件本身”，更是购买了这家公司的服务体系。反之亦然：当你选择自建系统时，本质上就是选择在内部组建团队来承担所有服务职能……

posts.title: Meta announces nuclear energy projects
posts.author: ChrisArchitect
posts.title_cn: Meta宣布启动核能项目
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Meta宣布投资核能项目展开，核心话题是Meta对小型模块化反应堆等核能技术的实际投入与行业影响。社区观点多元，部分用户质疑投资的具体金额与实效性，认为部分合作公司如Oklo的设计尚未获批，可能缺乏实质进展；也有用户指出，核能降低成本的关键在于大规模标准化建设，并关注新设计如何解决福岛事故中的核心安全问题。讨论中提到，尽管有声音认为这是有益于人类的基础设施投资，但不少用户对项目可行性持怀疑态度，尤其质疑初创公司估值过高与现有成熟技术的优势。整体而言，社区普遍认同核能对数据中心能源独立的价值，但在项目实际成效与技术路径上存在明显分歧。

comments.author: mrtracy
comments.content: How big are the commitments here?  I’m having trouble finding actual dollar amounts.  Does this actually represent an infusion of money into these SMR efforts, or are these “commitments” tied to so many missable targets that it’s actually meaningless?Oklo in particular seems to be total vaporware, I can’t find a single technical picture anywhere of anything this company’s reactor is seeking to do. They seem to raise money based on a rendering of  a ski lodge.A huge, concrete investment in TerraPower would be more interesting, but as a molten salt SMR which has never been built, this also looks extremely non-committal.SMRs in general seem like a dead end, we’ve heard about them for decades and they don’t seem to be any closer to making nuclear power buildouts less expensive.Everything that makes proven nuclear power plant design expensive seems to revolve around the same drivers of expense for all long-term construction: large up front capital requirements, changing regulations, failure to predict setbacks, and pervasive lawsuits.  SMRs purport to tackle a couple of these (shorter-term builds, fewer setbacks), at the cost of considerable efficiency, but so far this seems like an inferior alternative to “just get better at building proven nuclear plant designs”.

总体而言，小型模块化反应堆似乎走进了死胡同。我们已听闻数十年，却未见其能降低核电站建设成本。成熟核电站设计的高成本主要源于长期建设工程的共同痛点：巨额前期资本投入、不断变化的监管要求、难以预见的工程延误以及无休止的法律诉讼。小型堆试图通过牺牲可观效率来解决部分问题（缩短建设周期、减少工程延误），但迄今为止，这似乎还不如“改进成熟核电站建造技术”的方案来得实际。

comments.author: Animats
comments.content:
Right. Meta wants big enough plants that an AP1000 or two would be the right size. They're known to work. There are four in operation, two in the US, and another dozen or so under construction.Most of the small nuclear reactor startups hand-wave the failure modes and argue that they don't need the hulking big expensive containment building. NuScale claimed that. 
They wanted multiple reactors sharing the same cooling pool. If they ever had a leak, the whole set of reactors would be contaminated, even without a meltdown.If we look at the big reactor accidents so far, there's Chernobyl, with no containment building. There's Fukushima, with too small a containment unable to contain the pressure. And there's Three Mile Island, where a large, strong containment building contained a meltdown. Three Mile Island was an expensive disaster, but not hazardous outside the plant. That's the failure mode you want.We might be better off at developing better techniques for welding thick sections to make hulking big, strong containment vessels. There's been progress with robotic welding of thick sections.[1][1] https://www.agrrobotics.com/trends-s-industry-analysis/roadm...
comments.content_cn:
确实，Meta公司需要足够大的核电站，一两台AP1000机组的规模正合适。这类机组技术成熟可靠，目前已有四台投入运行（其中两台在美国），另有约十二台在建。大多数小型核反应堆初创企业往往回避故障模式问题，声称无需建造庞大昂贵的安全壳。NuScale公司也曾这样主张。他们计划让多个反应堆共用同一个冷却池，一旦发生泄漏，即使没有堆芯熔毁，整套反应堆都将受到污染。

回顾迄今发生的重大核事故：切尔诺贝利事故因缺乏安全壳而失控；福岛事故的安全壳规模过小无法承受压力；而三哩岛事故中，坚固的大型安全壳成功控制了堆芯熔毁。三哩岛事故虽造成巨大经济损失，但未对厂区外造成危害——这正是理想的故障控制模式。

我们或许更应着力研发更先进的厚板焊接技术，以建造坚固的大型安全壳。目前厚板机器人焊接领域已取得显著进展。[1][1] https://www.agrrobotics.com/trends-s-industry-analysis/roadm...
