posts.title: My Home Fibre Network Disintegrated
posts.author: alienchow
posts.title_cn: 我的家庭光纤网络崩溃了
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕用户家中光纤网络线缆快速老化碎裂的问题展开。核心话题是探究导致铠装光纤在短期内严重劣化的可能原因。有人认为线缆本身质量可能存在问题，建议联系供应商检查是否有产品召回；也有用户指出环境因素可能是主因，如新加坡的高湿度、水泥埋设环境中的碱性物质或油漆溶剂导致PVC护套塑化剂流失。讨论中提到，线缆若标注“军用级”往往是营销噱头且价格虚高。部分用户分享了经验，认为普通薄型光纤通常很耐用，除非受到弯折，并建议埋设时使用管道以方便维护。大家普遍认同线缆过早碎裂属于异常情况，可能涉及材料缺陷或特殊环境侵蚀，但具体原因尚无定论。

comments.author: DannyBee
comments.content: I have fs.com armored cable installed for 10 years now.  Different times and spools. It is all in perfect shape.  They test all their cable.   Something is almost certainly disintegrating your cable.  If you have any spare old pvc pipe or something in the basement, hit it with a hammer and see if it is brittle (the hammer should  bounce). If it is brittle, I would not hang out in the basement until you figure out what is going on.One random guess other than gases of various sorts:  If you have the lights on a lot, it's possible you have lighting that is not properly uv filtered somehow.(It theoretically could be lots of heat/humidity vs certain types of cable jackets, but that would be obviously noticeable most of the time)The fiber and even the armor itself looks fine in your pictures and I bet the error rate is zero.  Outside of bending, i can't see how you could damage the fiber when the armor is in perfect shape.  That armor will unravel if you really damaged it.  The speed thing is not how fiber works.  It's hard to get marginal link enough to generate retries that degrade your speed by 10%.  Most of the time either you have full speed link, no link, or so many errors speed is zero.  The optics almost always have rx/TX signal strength DDM you can look atAlso did you say you direct buried it in cement?  If so it's not rated for that.  Direct burial and concrete tight/safe are not the same thing at all, not the least of reasons being concrete is highly alkaline (ph12-13) when poured
comments.content_cn:
我使用fs.com的铠装光缆已有十年之久，不同时期、不同批次的产品至今都保持完好状态。他们会对所有线缆进行测试。你的线缆问题几乎肯定是某种外部因素导致的退化。如果地下室还有剩余的旧PVC管或类似物品，可以用锤子敲击试试是否变脆（正常情况锤子会反弹）。如果确实变脆，在查明原因前建议不要长时间待在地下室。除了各类气体因素外，还有一个推测：如果长期开灯，可能是照明设备未配备有效的紫外线过滤装置。（理论上也可能是高温高湿环境与特定类型线缆护套的相互作用，但这种情况通常会有明显迹象）

从你提供的照片看，光纤甚至铠装层本身都完好无损，我敢断言误码率绝对是零。在铠装完好的情况下，除了过度弯折外很难想象会损伤光纤。如果铠装层真的受损，它会明显松散开来。关于速度问题——这并非光纤的工作原理。要实现10%的速度衰减需要极其临界的不稳定链路状态，这种情况极为罕见。通常光纤链路要么全速运行，要么完全中断，要么因错误过多导致速度归零。光模块几乎都配备可查看的收发信号强度数字诊断监测功能。

另外你提到直接埋入水泥中？这种使用方式并不符合产品规格。直埋敷设与混凝土密闭环境完全是两回事，重要原因之一在于混凝土呈强碱性（pH值12-13）……

comments.author: wolfi1
comments.content: if the PVC is brittle it almost certainly lost its plasticizer, could be that the alkaline eroded it
comments.content_cn: 如果聚氯乙烯变脆，几乎可以肯定是增塑剂流失了，可能是碱性物质腐蚀所致。

comments.author: ZeroConcerns
comments.content: There's no link to the data sheet of the actual cable, but, yeah, looks like this should not have happened in such a short timeframe unless there's something really funny going on in that room, like ambient temperatures above 50 degC.Another thing that should not have happened is installing the cable in loops in this way: any 'building' or 'underground' type cable needs to be of the exact length required at the demarcation point, fastened properly to prevent movement and terminated on a proper patch panel (can be a one-port box-type thingy for small setups), from where you use regular patch cords to connect your equipment.(Loops are definitely allowed though, but that use case is mostly for aerial fiber to enable repair splices, and there are some very specific bend-radius and strain relief requirements, which, again should be spelled out in the cable data sheet)
comments.content_cn: 没有实际线缆的数据手册链接，但确实，除非房间里有什么异常情况，比如环境温度超过50摄氏度，否则在这么短的时间内不应该发生这种情况。另一件本不该发生的事是以这种环形方式安装线缆：任何“建筑内”或“地下”类型的线缆都应在分界点精确裁剪至所需长度，妥善固定以防移动，并端接到合适的配线架上（对于小型设置，可以是单端口盒式设备），然后使用常规跳线连接设备。（虽然环形确实允许存在，但那种情况主要用于架空光缆以便维修接续，并且有非常具体的弯曲半径和应力消除要求，这些同样应在线缆数据手册中明确说明。）

comments.author: kev009
comments.content: There are very survivable fiber cables designed for stage and A/V setups for instance, and even "real" military grade ones.  But the common thin LZSH stuff is surprisingly resilient in my experience, so long as it didn't kink the OP would probably have been fine with a "standard" cable.  In any case I would always try to place fiber in a place where it can be re-pulled.. conduit, tray, or a plenum.I bought a big spool of 6 strand Corning stuff a long time ago for various projects, the cost and diameter don't increase much to add some protection lines even if you never imagine using them they can save you a re-pull if you bugger something up in construction.
comments.content_cn: 确实存在专为舞台和视听系统设计的、具有极高生存能力的光纤电缆，甚至还有“真正的”军用级别产品。但根据我的经验，常见的细型LZSH材料电缆表现出惊人的韧性，只要没有发生弯折，用户使用“标准”电缆通常也能满足需求。无论如何，我总是尽量将光纤安装在便于重新布线的位置——例如管道、线槽或压力通风系统中。很久以前我曾购买了一大卷康宁六芯光纤用于各种项目，即使你从未想过使用备用线路，增加一些保护线的成本和直径增加并不多，但如果在施工中不慎损坏主线，这些备用线能帮你省去重新布线的麻烦。

comments.author: alienchow
comments.content: Thanks HN folks for all the comments. To clarify a bit, the cables are pulled through PVC conduits under the flooring before being buried in cement. Currently the hypotheses for why the cable disintegrated so quickly is hydrolysis and paint solvents. Singapore is extremely humid but this doesn't explain why the exposed cabling on the other end is still healthy and not crumbly.The second possibility is that I keep the leftover wall paints (Nippon Paint Vinilex 5000) in the same room and have noticed that much of the solvents have evaporated. It is possible that the solvents in the air might have caused the cable to fail in 3 years. It would explain why the other ends that aren't exposed to the air inside the bomb shelter aren't falling apart.Some other learnings from this. Buried cabling should always be permanently fixed and attached to a patch panel instead of dangling in the open. That was the original plan but I figured it wouldn’t be an issue. I was wrong. Always measure exact length of buried fibre cabling as they aren’t meant to be stored in loops.

comments.content: From the photos, it does not look like the fibers themselves are damaged. You should check the error rate on both sides. You can also pay a professional to run an OTDR on your fiber. It would show where the fiber is degraded.

posts.title: Iran is likely jamming Starlink
posts.author: ukblewis
posts.title_cn: 伊朗可能正在干扰星链信号
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕伊朗可能干扰星链服务的报道展开。核心话题是星链在未经许可下于伊朗运营，并在抗议期间提供免费网络，引发与伊朗政府的紧张关系。有人认为干扰并不意外，因为星链以“太空海盗电台”方式运作，与伊朗政府存在明显对立。也有用户指出，卫星信号本质是易受干扰的射频信号，星链并无特殊防护。讨论中提到技术争议点，如星链依赖GPS可能成为其弱点，以及低轨道星座是否应使用自有卫星定位。部分用户对伊朗民众表示同情，希望他们以较低代价获得所需；另有用户质疑国际社会对伊朗自由议题的关注不足。共识在于，星链在冲突地区确实面临被干扰的风险，且卫星通信在技术上并非不可阻断。分歧则体现在对干扰行为的道德评价及技术解决方案的可行性上。

comments.author: ACCount37
comments.content: Not too surprising, given that Starlink operates in Iran without a permit, "space pirate radio" style, and has something of a habit of making the access free when major protests happen and the government imposes a network blackout. Iranian government and Starlink have no love for each other, clearly.It's a pattern by now: whenever a government wants to do something awful, it shuts down internet access - so that no one can hear it, see it or coordinate a response. posts.title: How to code Claude Code in 200 lines of code
posts.author: nutellalover
posts.title_cn: 如何在200行代码内编写Claude Code
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕一篇题为“如何用200行代码实现Claude Code”的技术文章展开，核心话题是探讨构建类似Claude Code的代码生成智能代理的核心原理与实际复杂性。社区观点呈现明显分歧：有人认为这类代理的核心机制其实很简单，本质上是一个结合工具调用的循环结构，文章揭示了其基础框架；但也有用户指出，实际企业级应用中需处理大量细节问题（如早期停止、循环控制等），复杂程度远超简单循环模型，当前文章的描述已不足以准确反映Claude Code的实际工作模式。讨论中提到，有效使用此类工具的关键在于规划能力，例如通过动态待办列表引导任务执行；同时有观点认为，现代智能代理已转向基于技能库的模型，将问题转化为编码问题来处理。尽管对实现难度看法不一，但多数用户认同智能代理开发中规划与迭代机制的重要性，而关于其底层架构是否真如文章所述那般简易，则成为争议焦点。

comments.author: lmeyerov
comments.content: Something I would add is planning. A big "aha" for effective use of these tools is realizing they run on dynamic TODO lists. Ex: Plan mode is basically bootstrapping how that TODO list gets seeded and how todos ground themselves when they get reached, and user interactions are how you realign the todo lists. The todolist is subtle but was a big shift in coding tools, and many seem to be surprised when we discuss it -- most seem to focus on whether to use plan mode or not, but todo lists will still be active. I ran a fun experiment last month on how well claude code solves CTFs, and disabling the TodoList tool and planning is 1-2 grade jumps: https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-breaking-bots-cheating-at-blue-t... .Fwiw, I found it funny how the article stuffs "smarter context management" into a breeze-y TODO bullet point at the end for going production-grade. I've been noticing a lot of NIH/DIY types believing they can do a good job of this and then, when forced to have results/evals that don't suck in production, losing the rest of the year on that step. (And even worse when they decide to fine-tune too.)
comments.content_cn: 我想补充的一点是规划。高效使用这些工具的关键在于认识到它们基于动态待办事项列表运行。例如：规划模式本质上是在引导待办列表如何初始化，以及任务到达时如何落地执行，而用户交互则是调整待办列表的方式。待办列表看似细微，却是编码工具的重大变革——讨论时很多人对此感到惊讶，多数人似乎只关注是否使用规划模式，但待办列表其实始终在后台运作。上个月我做了个有趣的实验，测试Claude代码解决CTF挑战的能力，禁用待办列表工具和规划功能会导致性能下降1-2个等级：https://media.ccc.de/v/39c3-breaking-bots-cheating-at-blue-t... 。顺带一提，我觉得那篇文章把“更智能的上下文管理”轻描淡写地塞进末尾关于生产级应用的待办事项要点里很有意思。我注意到很多闭门造车/自己动手型开发者总以为能轻松搞定这步，结果被迫要在生产中拿出像样的成果和评估时，反而全年都耗在这个环节上。（如果他们决定还要微调模型，情况会更糟。）

comments.author: btown
comments.content: I'm unsure of its accuracy/provenance/outdatedness, but this purportedly extracted system prompt for Claude Code provides a lot more detail about TODO iteration and how powerful it can be:https://gist.github.com/wong2/e0f34aac66caf890a332f7b6f9e2ba...https://gist.github.com/wong2/e0f34aac66caf890a332f7b6f9e2ba...I find it fascinating that while in theory one could just append these as reasoning tokens to the context, and trust the attention algorithm to find the most recent TODO list and attend actively to it... in practice, creating explicit tools that essentially do a single-key storage are far more effective and predictable. It makes me wonder how much other low-hanging fruit there is with tool creation for storing language that requires emphasis and structure.
comments.content_cn:
我不确定其准确性/来源/是否过时，但这个据称是从Claude Code提取的系统提示提供了关于TODO迭代及其强大功能的更多细节：https://gist.github.com/wong2/e0f34aac66caf890a332f7b6f9e2ba...https://gist.github.com/wong2/e0f34aac66caf890a332f7b6f9e2ba...

我觉得有趣的是，理论上我们可以将这些作为推理标记附加到上下文中，并依赖注意力算法找到最新的TODO列表并主动关注它……但实际上，创建本质上实现单键存储的显式工具要有效和可预测得多。这让我思考，在创建用于存储需要强调和结构化语言的工具方面，还有多少其他容易实现的目标。

comments.author: nyellin
comments.content: There's a bit more to it!For example, the agent in the post will demonstrate 'early stopping' where it finishes before the task is really done. You'd think you can solve this with reasoning models, but it doesn't actually work on SOTA models.To fix 'early stopping' you need extra features in the agent harness. Claude Code does this with TODOs that are injected back into every prompt to remind the LLM what tasks remain open. (If you're curious somewhere in the public repo for HolmesGPT we have benchamrks with all the experiments we ran to solve this - from hypothesis tracking to other exotic approaches - but TODOs always performed best.)Still, good article. Agents really are just tools in a loop. It's not rocket science.
comments.content_cn: 事情比这复杂一些！比如文中提到的智能体会出现"提前终止"现象——在任务真正完成前就结束了。你可能觉得用推理模型能解决这个问题，但实际上对当前最先进的模型并不奏效。要修正"提前终止"问题，需要在智能体框架中加入特殊功能。Claude Code的做法是通过TODO事项——在每个提示中反复注入待办事项，以此提醒大语言模型还有哪些任务尚未完成。（如果你感兴趣的话，在HolmesGPT的公开代码库里可以看到我们为解决这个问题所做的所有实验基准测试——从假设追踪到各种新奇方法——但TODO方案始终表现最佳。）不过这篇文章确实不错。说到底，智能体不过是循环使用的工具罢了，并非什么高深莫测的技术。

comments.author: joshmlewis
comments.content: This is cool but as someone that's built an enterprise grade agentic loop in-house that's processing a billion plus tokens a month, there are so many little things you have to account for that greatly magnify complexity in real world agentic use cases. For loops are an easy way to get your foot in the door and is indeed at the heart of it all, but there are a multitude of a little things that compound complexity rather quickly. What happens when a user sends a message after the first one and the agent has already started the tool loop? Seems simple, right? If you are receiving inputs via webhooks (like from a Slack bot), then what do you do? It's not rocket science but it's also not trivial to do right. What about hooks (guardrails) and approvals? Should you halt execution mid-loop and wait or implement it as an async Task feature like Claude Code and the MCP spec? If you do it async then how do you wake the agent back up? Where is the original tool call stored and how is the output stored for retrieval/insertion? This and many other little things add up and compound on each other.I should start a blog with my experience from all of this.
comments.content_cn: 这确实很酷，但作为曾自主构建企业级智能体循环系统、每月处理超10亿token的开发者，我必须指出实际应用中存在大量细节问题，它们会极大增加智能体用例的复杂度。循环结构虽是入门捷径且确为核心机制，但众多细微之处会迅速叠加复杂度。例如：当用户发送首条消息后智能体已启动工具循环，此时用户再发送消息该如何处理？看似简单对吧？若通过webhook接收输入（如Slack机器人），又该如何应对？这虽非尖端科技，但要妥善处理也绝非易事。那么防护机制与审批流程呢？是否应在循环中途暂停等待？还是像Claude Code和MCP规范那样实现异步任务？若采用异步方案，如何重新激活智能体？原始工具调用存储于何处？输出结果又如何存储以供检索或插入？这些看似琐碎的问题会不断累积并相互交织。我应当把这些实践经验整理成博客分享。

comments.author: armcat
comments.content: The new mental model actually is (1) skills based model, i.e. https://agentskills.io/home, and (2) where the LLM agents "see all problems as coding problems". Skills are a bunch of detailed Markdowns and corresponding code libraries and snippets. The mental model thereby loops as follows: read only the top level descriptions in each SKILL.md, use those in-context to decide which skill to pick, after picking the relevant skill read the skill in-depth to choose which code/lib to use, based on the <problem, code/lib> generate new code, execute the code, evaluate, repeat. The problem-as-a-code mental model is also a great way of evaluating, and creating rewards and guarantees.
comments.content_cn: 新的心智模型实际上是（1）基于技能的模式，即https://agentskills.io/home，以及（2）让LLM智能体“将所有问题视为编码问题”。技能是一系列详细的Markdown文档及对应的代码库和片段。因此，该心智模型循环如下：仅阅读每个SKILL.md中的顶层描述，利用这些上下文信息决定选择哪个技能，选定相关技能后深入阅读该技能以选择使用哪个代码/库，基于此生成新代码，执行代码，评估，重复。将问题视为代码的心智模型也是进行评估、创建奖励和保证的绝佳方式。

comments.content: What's interesting to me about the question of whether you could realistically compete with Claude Code (not Claude, but the CLI agent) is that the questions boil down to things any proficient developer could do. comments.author: libraryofbabel
comments.content: It's a great point and everyone should know it: the core of a coding agent is really simple, it's a loop with tool calling.Having said that, I think if you're going to write an article like this and call it "The Emperor Has No Clothes: How to Code Claude Code in 200 Lines of Code", you should at least include a reference to Thorsten Ball's excellent article from wayyy back in April 2025 entitled "How to Build an Agent, or: The Emperor Has No Clothes" (https://ampcode.com/how-to-build-an-agent)! That was (as far as I know) the first of these articles making the point that the core of a coding agent is actually quite simple (and all the deep complexity is in the LLM). Reading it was a light-bulb moment for me.FWIW, I agree with other commenters here that you do need quite a bit of additional scaffolding (like TODOs and much more) to make modern agents work well. And Claude Code itself is a fairly complex piece of software with a lot of settings, hooks, plugins, UI features, etc. Although I would add that once you have a minimal coding agent loop in place, you can get it to bootstrap its own code and add those things! That is a fun and slightly weird thing to try.(By the way, the "January 2025" date on this article is clearly a typo for 2026, as Claude Code didn't exist a year ago and it includes use of the claude-sonnet-4-20250514 model from May.)Edit: and if you're interested in diving deeper into what Claude Code itself is doing under the hood, a good tool to understand it is "claude-trace" (https://github.com/badlogic/lemmy/tree/main/apps/claude-trac...). You can use it to see the whole dance with tool calls and the LLM: every call out to the LLM and the LLM's responses, the LLM's tool call invocations and the responses from the agent to the LLM when tools run, etc. When Claude Skills came out I used this to confirm my guess about how they worked (they're a tool call with all the short skill descriptions stuffed into the tool description base prompt). Reading the base prompt is also interesting. (Among other things, they explicitly tell it not to use emoji, which tracks as when I wrote my own agent it was indeed very emoji-prone.)
comments.content_cn:
这个观点非常精辟且值得所有人了解：编码代理的核心其实非常简单，就是一个包含工具调用的循环。话虽如此，我认为如果你要写这样一篇文章并命名为《皇帝的新装：如何用200行代码实现Claude Code》，至少应该引用Thorsten Ball早在2025年4月发表的优秀文章《如何构建代理，或曰：皇帝的新装》（https://ampcode.com/how-to-build-an-agent）！据我所知，这是最早一批指出编码代理核心其实非常简单（所有深层复杂性都在大语言模型中）的文章之一，阅读时让我豁然开朗。

顺便说一句，我同意其他评论者的观点：要让现代代理良好运行，确实需要相当多的额外框架支持（比如待办事项列表等更多功能）。而Claude Code本身就是一个相当复杂的软件，包含大量设置、钩子、插件、用户界面特性等。不过我想补充的是，一旦你搭建好最简化的编码代理循环，就可以让它自行引导编写代码并添加这些功能！这是个有趣且略带奇妙的尝试。

（顺便提一下，文章标注的“2025年1月”明显是2026年的笔误，因为一年前Claude Code尚未问世，且文中使用了2025年5月的claude-sonnet-4-20250514模型。）

编辑补充：如果你有兴趣深入了解Claude Code的内部运行机制，一个很好的理解工具是……

comments.author: miki123211
comments.content: All you actually need is 50 lines and one tool.If your agent can execute Bash commands, it can do anything, including reading files (with cat), writing them (with sed / patch / awk /perl), grepping, finding, and everything else you may possibly need. The specialized tools are just an optimization to make things easier for the agent. They do increase performance (in the "how much can this do", not the "how fast is this" sense), but they're not strictly required.IMHO, this is one of the more significant LLM-related discoveries of 2025. You don't need a context-polluting Github MCP that takes 10+% of your precious context window, all you need is the gh cli, which the agent already knows how to use.
comments.content_cn: 实际上你只需要50行代码和一个工具。如果你的智能体能执行Bash命令，它就能完成所有任务，包括读取文件（用cat）、写入文件（用sed/patch/awk/perl）、搜索文本、查找文件以及其他任何你可能需要的操作。那些专用工具只是为了让智能体工作更便捷的优化手段。它们确实能提升性能（这里指“能处理多少任务”而非“处理速度多快”），但并非绝对必要。在我看来，这是2025年与大型语言模型相关的重要发现之一。你不需要那种会占用10%以上宝贵上下文窗口、污染上下文的Github MCP，你只需要gh命令行工具——而智能体早已掌握其使用方法。

comments.author: jacob019

Seems everyone is working on the same things these days. I built a persistent Python REPL subprocess as an MCP tool for CC, it worked so insanely well that I decided to go all the way. I already had an agentic framework built around tool calling (agentlib), so I adapted it for this new paradigm and code agent was born.The agent "boots up" inside the REPL. Here's the beginning of the system prompt:  >>> help(assistant)

  You are an interactive coding assistant operating within a Python REPL.
  Your responses ARE Python code—no markdown blocks, no prose preamble.
  The code you write is executed directly.

  >>> how_this_works()

  1. You write Python code as your response
  2. The code executes in a persistent REPL environment
  3. Output is shown back to you IN YOUR NEXT TURN
  4. Call `respond(text)` ...

You get the idea. No need for custom file editing tools--Python has all that built in and Claude knows it perfectly. No JSON marshaling or schema overhead. Tools are just Python functions injected into the REPL, zero context bloat.I also built a browser control plugin that puts Claude directly into the heart of a live browser session. It can inject element pickers so I can click around and show it what I'm talking about. It can render prototype code before committing to disk, killing the annoying build-fix loop. I can even SSH in from my phone and use TTS instead of typing, surprisingly great for frontend design work. Knocked out a website for my father-in-law's law firm (gresksingleton.com) in a few hours that would've taken 10X that a couple years ago, and it was super fun.The big win: complexity. CC has been a disaster on my bookkeeping system, there's a threshold past which Claude loses the forest for the trees and makes the same mistakes over and over. Code agent pushes that bar out significantly. Claude can build new tools on the fly when it needs them. Gemini works great too (larger context).Have fun out there! /end-rant

comments.author: stevenslade
comments.content: I’d been wondering how conversation history actually works in these agent loops — the LLM itself has no memory, so whatever “history” exists is just text you keep feeding back in.At a high level it seems to usually be one (or a mix) of:- full transcript appended every turn- sliding window of the last N turns / tokens- older turns summarized into a rolling memory- structured state (goals, decisions, progress) rendered into the prompt- external storage + retrieval (RAG-style) to pull in only relevant past infoUnder the hood I’m sure it gets more complex, but the core idea is pretty simple once you strip away the mystique: memory = prompt assembly.
comments.content_cn: 我一直好奇这些智能体循环中的对话历史究竟如何运作——大语言模型本身没有记忆，所以任何所谓的“历史”都只是你不断反馈输入的文本。从宏观上看，通常采用以下一种或多种方式：每轮对话都完整追加全部记录；使用最近N轮对话或词元的滑动窗口；将较早的对话轮次总结为滚动记忆；将结构化状态（目标、决策、进展）渲染到提示词中；通过外部存储加检索（类似RAG模式）仅提取相关的过往信息。在技术细节上肯定更为复杂，但一旦揭开神秘面纱，核心思想其实很简单：记忆即提示词的组装。

comments.author: rrvsh
comments.content: I've had a LOT of success keeping a "working memory" file for CLI agents. Currently testing out Codex now, and what I'll do is spend ~10mins hashing out the spec and splitting it into a list of changes, then telling the agent to save those changes to a file and keep that file updated as it works through them. The crucial part here is to tell it to review the plan and modify it if needed after every change. This keeps the LLM doing what it does best (short term goals with limited context) while removing the need to constantly prompt it. Essentially I feel like it's an alternative to having subagents for the same or a similar result

comments.author: jacob019
comments.content: Ohh, looks interesting, thanks for the tip!Git as db is clever, and the sqlite cache is nice. I'd been sketching sqlite based memory features myself. So much of the current ecosystem is suboptimal just because it's new. The models are trained around immutable conversation ledgers with user/tool/assistant blocks, but there are compelling reasons to manipulate both sides at runtime and add synthetic exchanges. Priming with a synthetic failure and recovery is often more effective than a larger, more explicit system message. Same with memory, we just haven't figured out what works best.For code agents specifically, I found myself wanting old style completion models without the structured turn training--doesn't exist for frontier models. Talking to Claude about its understanding of the input token stream was fascinating; it compared it to my visual cortex and said it'd be unreasonable to ask me to comment on raw optic nerve data."Tell it to reread it again"-exactly the problem. My bookkeeping/decision engine has so much documentation I'm running out of context, and every bit is necessary due to interconnected dependencies. Telling it to reread content already in the window feels wrong, that's when I refine the docs or adjust the framework. I've also found myself adding way more docstrings and inline docs than I'd ever write for myself. I prefer minimal, self-documenting code, so it's a learning process.There's definitely an art to prompts, and it varies wildly by model, completely different edge cases across the leading ones. Thanks again for the tip; I suspect we'll see a lot of interesting memory developments this year.

哦，看起来挺有意思的，感谢分享！用Git当数据库很巧妙，SQLite缓存的设计也不错。我自己之前也在构思基于SQLite的记忆功能。当前很多生态方案不够完善，主要还是因为技术太新。现有模型训练都围绕不可变的对话记录展开，采用用户/工具/助手模块的结构，但实际运行时确实有充分理由需要双向调整对话内容并添加合成交换记录。用模拟失败与恢复的案例进行预热，往往比冗长直白的系统提示更有效。记忆功能也是如此，我们还没找到最优方案。

comments.content_cn: 工具文档以文本形式存在，无论是直接形式如“工具 -h”还是间接形式如“man 工具”，加上网上有无数使用示例，因此显然工具与其用法之间的文本映射已经以文本形式存在。

comments.author: misternugget

Then I saw the "January 2025" in the title and got even more confused.So, thanks for your comment and answering all the questions I had just now about "wait, did I wake up in a parallel universe where I didn't write the post but someone else did?"

comments.author: embedding-shape
comments.content: Not all models are trained with long one-shot task following by themselves, seems many of them prefer closer interactions with the user. You could always add another layer/abstraction above/below to work around it.
comments.content_cn: 并非所有模型都通过长时间的单次任务自我训练，似乎许多模型更倾向于与用户进行更紧密的互动。你总可以在其之上或之下添加另一层抽象来应对这种情况。

comments.author: mickeyp
comments.content: Models just naturally arrive at a conclusion that they are done. TODO hints can help, but is not infallible: Claude will stop and happily report there's more work to be done and "you just say the word Mister and I'll continue" --- this is a RL problem where you have to balance the chance of an infinite loop (it keeps thinking there's a little bit more to do when there is not) versus the opposite where it stops short of actual completion.
comments.content_cn: 模型会自然而然地得出任务已完成的结论。待办事项提示虽能提供帮助，但并非万无一失：克劳德可能会中途停止，并愉快地报告还有更多工作待完成，表示“您只需吩咐一声，我就继续”——这是一个强化学习问题，需要在无限循环风险（实际已完成却总认为还有少量工作）与过早停止（实际未完成却提前终止）之间找到平衡点。

comments.author: terminalshort
comments.content: For one thing it seems to splitting up the work and making some determination of complexity, then allocating it out to a model based on that complexity to save resources.  When I run Claude with Opus 4.5 and run /cost I see tokens for Opus 4.5, but also a lot in Sonnet and Haiku, with the majority of tokens actually being used by Haiku.
comments.content_cn: 一方面，它似乎是在拆分任务并评估复杂度，然后根据复杂度将任务分配给相应模型以节省资源。当我使用Opus 4.5运行Claude并执行/cost命令时，我看到Opus 4.5消耗了部分token，但Sonnet和Haiku模型也使用了大量token，实际上大部分token是由Haiku模型消耗的。

comments.author: prodigycorp

comments.author: handfuloflight

comments.author: libraryofbabel
comments.content: Yeah, there is definitely some RLVR training going on for the Claude LLMs to get them good at some of the specific tool calls used in Claude Code, I expect. comments.content_cn: 是的，我预计Claude大语言模型肯定进行了一些RLVR训练，以使它们擅长Claude Code中使用的某些特定工具调用。话虽如此，用于文件编辑的字符串替换工具模式一点也不复杂（你可以在Claude Code发送给大语言模型的工具调用模式中看到它），所以如果你想确保发挥大语言模型的优势，可以轻松地在你自己的200-300行代理中使用它。

comments.content_cn: 这正是我期待开源模型大放异彩的地方。某个社区聚集起来，开始分享他们自主智能体成功或失败的运行经验，着手为特定语法和工具构建开放数据集，最终在此基础上为社区微调出新的模型变体。

comments.author: libraryofbabel

Thanks again for writing that first Emperor Has No Clothes blog post; like I said, it really inspired me and made everything click early on when I was first dipping my toes into the world of agents. Whenever I teach this stuff to other engineers, I often think back to that moment of realizing exactly how the exchange between LLM, tool call requests, tool functions, and agent code works and I try to get that across as the central takeaway. comments.content_cn: 你好！再次感谢你撰写那篇《皇帝的新装》博客首文；正如我之前所说，它确实给了我很大启发，让我在初次涉足智能体领域时迅速理清了一切。每当我向其他工程师讲解这些内容时，我总会回想起那个顿悟时刻——真正理解了大型语言模型、工具调用请求、工具函数与智能体代码之间如何交互运作，并始终尝试将这一点作为核心要义传达。如今我通常会添加示意图，以便更清晰地展示模型API两侧的具体运作过程。我确实好奇事情是否是这样的发展路径：1）你在2025年4月写了那篇文章；2）新一代大型语言模型以你的文章作为训练数据；3）《TFA》的作者产生了类似想法，并大量使用大型语言模型协助编写代码和文章，包括让模型构思一个抓人眼球的标题。你猜模型最终提出了什么标题？当然也存在更不友善的解读。但我宁愿相信这是无心之失，尽管处理得有些草率。

comments.content_cn: 非常感谢您的文章，这真是我在2025年真正“顿悟”的时刻之一！遗憾的是，您的工作显然被他人挪用而未注明出处，用于销售在线课程……

posts.title: CLI agents like Claude Code make self-hosting on a home server easier and fun
posts.author: websku
posts.title_cn: 像Claude Code这样的CLI代理让家庭服务器自托管变得更简单有趣
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕使用Claude Code等CLI代理工具简化家庭服务器自托管展开。核心话题是这类AI工具如何降低自托管的技术门槛并提升体验，同时引发了对自托管可行性与依赖关系的争议。

多数用户肯定AI工具在自托管中的实用性：有人认为它们能高效生成脚本、调试问题，替代传统搜索；也有用户指出Tailscale等安全工具比AI管理功能更重要，解决了家庭服务器的安全顾虑。讨论中提到，自托管爱好者普遍认同家庭实验室是值得投资的长期项目，但需配备UPS不同断电源等基础设施保障稳定性。

主要分歧体现在两方面：一方认为自托管配合AI工具能减少对大科技公司的依赖，是值得推广的技术方案；另一方则质疑使用闭源AI服务（如Claude Code）来实现“去依赖”存在逻辑矛盾，且强调专业托管服务的可靠性。此外，对于技术门槛问题，有用户建议新手优先选择带图形界面的NAS设备，而非依赖LLM管理服务器。

comments.author: thrownawaysz
comments.content: I went down the self host route some years ago but once critical problems hit I realized that beyond a simple NAS it can be a very demanding hobby.I was in another country when there was a power outage at home. My internet went down, the server restart but couldn't reconnect anymore because the optical network router also had some problems after the power outage. I could ask my folks to restart, and turn on off things but nothing more than that. So I couldn't reach my Nextcloud instance and other stuff. Maybe an uninterruptible power supply could have helped but the more I was thinking about it after just didn't really worth the hassle anymore. Add a UPS okay. But why not add a dual WAN failover router for extra security if the internet goes down again? etc. It's a bottomless pit (like most hobbies tbh)Also (and that's a me problem maybe) I was using Tailscale but I'm more "paranoid" about it nowadays. Single point of failure service, US-only SSO login (MS, Github, Apple, Google), what if my Apple account gets locked if I redeem a gift card and I can't use Tailscale anymore? I still believe in self hosting but probably I want something even more "self" to the extremes.
comments.content_cn:
几年前我也尝试过自托管路线，但当关键问题出现时，我意识到除了简单的NAS之外，这可能是项非常耗费精力的爱好。有一次我在国外时家里停电了，网络中断，服务器重启后却无法重新连接，因为光纤网络路由器在停电后也出了问题。我只能让家人帮忙重启、开关设备，但除此之外无能为力。于是我无法访问我的Nextcloud实例和其他服务。也许不间断电源能帮上忙，但事后越想越觉得不值得这么折腾。加个UPS没问题，但既然要加，何不再加个双WAN故障转移路由器以防网络再次中断？等等。这简直是个无底洞（说实话，大多数爱好都是如此）。

另外（这可能是我个人的问题），我虽然用过Tailscale，但现在对它越来越“疑神疑鬼”。它是单点故障服务，只支持美国单点登录（微软、GitHub、苹果、谷歌），万一我兑换礼品卡导致苹果账户被锁，岂不是连Tailscale都不能用了？我依然相信自托管，但或许我想要的是更极致、更“自主”的方案。

comments.author: dwd
comments.content: Been self-hosting for last 20 years and I would have to say LLMs were good for generating suggestions when debugging an issue I hadn't seen before, or for one I had seen before but was looking for a quicker fix. I've used it to generate bash scripts, firewall regex.On self-hosting: be aware that it is a warzone out there. Your IP address will be probed constantly for vulnerabilities, and even those will need to dealt with as most automated probes don't throttle and can impact your server. That's probably my biggest issue along with email deliverability.
comments.content_cn: 过去20年我一直自己托管服务器，不得不说大语言模型在调试从未遇到过的问题时很有帮助，或者对以前遇到过但想快速解决的问题也能提供建议。我用它生成过bash脚本和防火墙正则表达式。关于自托管：要意识到这就像战场。你的IP地址会不断被扫描漏洞，即使没有漏洞也需要处理，因为大多数自动扫描不会限速，可能影响服务器性能。这可能是我遇到的最大问题，还有邮件送达率也是难题。

comments.author: HarHarVeryFunny
comments.content: Interesting use case for Claude Code, or any similar local executor talking to a remote AI (Gemini suggests that "Hybrid-Local AI Agent" is a generic name for these, although I've never heard it called that before).I wonder if a local model might be enough for sysadmin skills, especially if were trained specifically for this ?I wonder if iOS has enough hooks available that one could make a very small/simple agentic Siri replacement like this that was able to manage the iPhone at least better than Siri (start and stop apps, control them, install them, configure iPhone, etc) ?
comments.content_cn: Claude Code（或任何类似的与远程AI对话的本地执行器）的有趣应用场景（Gemini建议将这类工具统称为"混合本地AI代理"，虽然我以前从未听过这个说法）。我在想，本地模型是否足以胜任系统管理任务，特别是如果专门为此训练的话？我也好奇iOS是否提供了足够的接口，让人能够开发一个非常小巧/简单的类似代理式Siri替代品，至少能比Siri更好地管理iPhone（启动和关闭应用、控制应用、安装应用、配置iPhone等）？

comments.author: tkgally
comments.content: I used Claude Code just yesterday in a similar way: to solve a computer problem that I previously would have tried googling.I had a 30-year-old file on my Mac that I wanted to read the content of. I had created it in some kind of word processing software, but I couldn’t remember which (Nexus? Word? MacWrite? ClarisWorks? EGWORD?) and the file didn’t have an extension. I couldn’t read its content in any of the applications I have on my Mac now.So I pointed CC at it and asked what it could tell me about the file. It looked inside the file data, identified the file type and the multiple character encodings in it, and went through a couple of conversion steps before outputting as clean plain text what I had written in 1996.Maybe I could have found a utility on the web to do the same thing, but CC felt much quicker and easier.
comments.content_cn: 我昨天刚以类似方式使用了Claude Code：解决了一个以往我可能会尝试通过谷歌搜索解决的电脑问题。我Mac上有个30年前的文件想查看内容，它是我用某种文字处理软件创建的，但记不清具体是哪个（Nexus？Word？MacWrite？ClarisWorks？EGWORD？），而且文件没有扩展名。现在Mac上的所有应用程序都无法读取其内容。于是我将CC指向该文件，询问它能提供什么信息。它深入解析了文件数据，识别出文件类型及其中包含的多重字符编码，经过几个转换步骤后，最终将我1996年写的内容以整洁的纯文本形式输出。或许我能在网上找到具有相同功能的工具，但CC显然更加快捷简便。

comments.author: wswin
comments.content: Home NAS servers are already shipped with user friendly GUI. Personally I haven't used them, but I certainly would prefer it, or recommend it to tech-illitarate people instead of allowing LLM to manage the server.
comments.content_cn: 家用NAS服务器已经配备了用户友好的图形界面。我个人虽然没用过，但肯定会优先选择它，或者推荐给不熟悉技术的人，而不是让LLM来管理服务器。

comments.author: fhennig
comments.content: I think it's great that people are getting into self-hosting, but I don't think it's _the_ solution to get us off of big tech.Having others run a service for you is a good thing! I'd love to pay a subscription for a service, but ran as a cooperative, where I'm not actually just paying a subscription fee, instead I'm a member and I get to decide what gets done as well.This model works so well for housing, where the renters are also the owners of the building. Incentives are aligned perfectly, rents are kept low, the building is kept intact, no unnecessary expensive stuff added. And most importantly, no worries of the building ever getting sold and things going south. That's what I would like for my cloud storage, e-mail etc.
comments.content_cn: 我认为人们开始自托管服务是件好事，但这并非让我们摆脱科技巨头的唯一解决方案。让他人为你运营服务其实是件好事！我很愿意为服务支付订阅费，但希望以合作社形式运营——这样我不仅是付费用户，更是拥有决策权的成员。这种模式在住房领域非常成功，租户同时是楼宇的所有者。各方利益完全一致，租金得以保持低位，建筑得到良好维护，不会添加不必要的昂贵设施。最重要的是，完全不必担心楼宇被出售导致情况恶化。这正是我对云存储、电子邮件等服务所期待的模式。

comments.author: simonw
comments.content: This posts lists inexpensive home servers, Tailscale and Claude Code as the big unlocks.I actually think Tailscale may be an even bigger deal here than sysadmin help from Claude Code at al.The biggest reason I had not to run a home server was security: I'm worried that I might fall behind on updates and end up compromised.Tailscale dramatically reduces this risk, because I can so easily configure it so my own devices can talk to my home server from anywhere in the world without the risk of exposing any ports on it directly to the internet.Being able to hit my home server directly from my iPhone via a tailnet no matter where in the world my iPhone might be is really cool.
comments.content_cn: 这篇文章列举了低成本家用服务器、Tailscale和Claude Code作为关键解锁工具。实际上我认为Tailscale在这里可能比Claude Code等工具提供的系统管理帮助更重要。我过去不搭建家用服务器的最大原因是安全顾虑：我担心自己可能疏于更新补丁，最终导致系统被入侵。Tailscale极大降低了这种风险，因为它能让我轻松配置，使我的个人设备可以从世界任何地方安全访问家用服务器，而无需将任何端口直接暴露在互联网上。无论我的iPhone身处世界何处，都能通过tailnet直接访问家用服务器，这实在太棒了。

comments.author: danpalmer
comments.content: There's something ironic about using Claud Code – a closed source service, that you can't self-host the hardware for, and that you can't get access to the data for – to self-host so that you can reduce your dependencies on things.
comments.content_cn: 使用Claud Code这件事本身就颇具讽刺意味——这是一个闭源服务，你既无法自行托管其硬件，也无法获取相关数据，却要用它来实现自托管以减少对外部事物的依赖。

comments.author: cmiles8
comments.content: Anyone seriously about tech should have a homelab. It’s a small capital investment that lasts for years and with proxmox or similar having your own personal “private cloud” on demand is simple.
comments.content_cn: 任何认真对待技术的人都应该拥有一个家庭实验室。这是一项小额资本投资，可持续使用多年，借助Proxmox或类似工具，按需拥有个人“私有云”变得轻而易举。

comments.author: zrail
comments.content: My spouse and I work at home and after the first couple multi-day power outages we invested in good UPSs and a whole house standby generator. Now when the power goes out it's down for at most 30 seconds.This also makes self-hosting more viable, since our availability is constrained by internet provider rather than power.
comments.content_cn: 我和伴侣都在家工作，经历过几次持续数日的停电后，我们购置了优质的不间断电源和全屋备用发电机。现在即便停电，最多也只会中断30秒。这也让自托管服务变得更可行，因为我们的可用性现在只受网络供应商限制，不再受电力影响。

comments.author: tezza
comments.content: Wait… tailscale connection to your own network, and unsupervised sysadmin from an oracle that hallucinates and bases its decisions on blog post aggregates?p0wnland. this will have script kiddies rubbing their hands
comments.content_cn: 等等……用Tailscale连接你自己的网络，再让一个基于博客文章汇总产生幻觉并做出决策的Oracle进行无人监管的系统管理？这简直是黑客乐园。脚本小子们要摩拳擦掌了。

comments.author: chasd00
comments.content: What I do at home is ubuntu on a cheap small computer I found on ebay. ufw blocks everything except 80, 443, and 22. Setup ssh to not use passwords and ensure nginx+letsencrypt doesn’t run as root. Then, forward 80 and 443 from my home router to the server so it’s reachable from the internet. That’s about it,  now I have an internet accessible reverse proxy to surface anything running on that server. The computers on the same LAN (just my laptop basically) have host file entries for the server. My registrar handles DNS for the external side (routers public ip). Ssh’ing to the server requires a lan IP but that’s no big deal I’m at home whenever I’m working on it anyway.
comments.content_cn: 我在家使用一台从易趣淘来的廉价小电脑运行Ubuntu系统。通过ufw防火墙仅开放80、443和22端口，并设置SSH免密码登录，同时确保nginx和Let's Encrypt不以root权限运行。接着将家庭路由器的80和443端口转发至该服务器，使其能够从公网访问。这样一来，我就拥有了一个可通过互联网访问的反向代理服务器，能够对外暴露运行在该服务器上的任何服务。同一局域网内的设备（基本上只有我的笔记本电脑）通过hosts文件配置了服务器域名解析。外部DNS解析由域名注册商处理（指向路由器的公网IP）。虽然SSH连接服务器需要使用局域网IP，但这并不成问题，毕竟我每次操作时都在家里。

comments.author: jackschultz
comments.content: I literally did this yesterday and had the same thought. Older computer (8 gigs ram) with crappy windows I never used and I thought huh, I wonder how good these models can take me through installing linux with goal of docker deploys of relatively basic things like cron tasks, personal postgres, and minio that I can used for self shared data.Took a couple hours with some things I ran across, but the model had me go through the setup for debian, how to go through the setup gui, what to check to make it server only, then it took me through commands to run so it wouldn't stop when I closed the laptop, helped with tailscale, getting the ssh keys all setup. Heck it even suggested doing daily dumps of the database and saving to minio and then removing after that. Also knows about the limitations of 8 gigs of ram and how to make sure docker settings for the difference self services I want to build don't cause issues.Give me a month and true strong intention and ability to google and read posts and find the answer on my own and I still don't think I would have gotten to this point with the amount of trust I have in the setup.I very much agree with this topic about self hosting coming alive because these models can walk you through everything. Self building and self hosting can really come alive. And in the future when open models are that much better and hardware costs come down (maybe, just guessing of course) we'll be able to also host our own agents on these machines we have setup already. comments.content_cn:

posts.title: Overdose deaths are falling in America because of a 'supply shock': study
posts.author: marojejian
posts.title_cn: 研究：美国因“供应冲击”导致用药过量死亡人数下降
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕美国阿片类药物过量死亡人数下降是否源于“供应冲击”展开。研究认为芬太尼纯度下降导致死亡减少，但社区对此存在争议。有用户指出死亡率的下降早于纯度变化，质疑因果关系；也有人认为可能是“需求冲击”，即成瘾者快速死亡导致需求减少。讨论中提到政府通过合法渠道提供廉价清洁毒品以打击非法市场的可能性，但未形成共识。部分用户提出其他解释，包括执法加强、使用者学会安全剂量控制等。普遍认同的是美国阿片类药物处方泛滥的历史问题，但对当前死亡率下降的主因仍存分歧。

comments.author: 20after4
comments.content: I think that many methadone clinics are operating very unethically, to the point I would call it fraudulent. Certainly it's cruel to the patients. They essentially set up the patient to be a lifetime methadone addict. This may be an improvement over getting your fix on the street but it's still addiction dependence and it's expensive (profitable!).  I'm unsure if it's just a few or a large fraction of them that operate this way. Maybe my data point is a unique outlier but here's what I saw:I had a friend who was going through the program in Springfield Missouri, approximately 10 years ago, and the clinic literally increased his dose every week or two. They also had strict controls to make sure the patients actually take the full dose (because otherwise they might sell some of it on the street). So they were left with just 2 options, either drop out of the program and find their fix elsewhere, or accept a gradually increasing dose of methadone, forever.  It's a sick program that is set up to make sure patients gradually descend deeper into addiction while they rake in huge profits.  It's not really any different from what the drug dealers on the street are doing except that it's even more exploitative and dishonest.  The doctors had zero plan for weaning people off of the methadone and some people had been on the program for years, with correspondingly huge doses doled out to them every time they came in. This was 10 years ago, at the time it cost something like $50 per visit, paid by the patient or possibly medicaid.Edited slightly for clarity.

comments.content_cn:
我听过一个看似合理的解释，但直白地说，那完全是胡说八道。药物的剂量范围极其广泛。芬太尼属于极低剂量的一端，成年人可能服用25或50毫克的苯海拉明，对乙酰氨基酚可能服用500毫克，而像阿莫西林这样的药物，成年人治疗严重感染时可能服用高达3000毫克。无论纯化学品的效力如何，都有标准且极其可靠的方法来制备含有正确剂量的药片。

显然，芬太尼（或其前体）是以高纯度形式进口（即走私）的，以尽量减少运输体积。显然，它不能以这种形式被直接服用。其高效力和走私成本低廉的特点，使其非常适合用于掺入其他（更昂贵的）产品中。这是虚假宣传，但通常不会仅因此就致人死亡。

当外行人不懂操作、没有适当设施、当然也无法建立适当的质量控制流程来处理如此强效的物质时，出错并导致死亡就不足为奇了。如果（例如）同样的受害者是从药房购买芬太尼（而不是他们以为自己正在服用的东西），他们几乎肯定不会遇到任何问题。几乎没有人是故意过量服用的。

关键在于，不是“芬太尼有毒所以你会过量”，而是“配制药片的人搞错了剂量，你服用的比你认为的要多，所以才会过量”。这种情况同样可能发生在任何其他……

posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子讨论了HTML中某些标签（如

、

  • 、、
    ）是否必须闭合的问题。核心话题围绕HTML标准对标签闭合的宽松处理及其实际应用影响展开。 有人认为不闭合标签符合SGML推断规则，能简化原型设计，使HTML文件编写更灵活。也有用户指出，这种宽松标准曾导致早期网页兼容性问题，例如某些浏览器渲染异常。讨论中提到，尽管技术上允许不闭合标签，但许多开发者出于代码清晰度和可维护性考虑，仍倾向于显式闭合标签。有用户强调“可以不闭合不代表应该这样做”，认为明确闭合标签有助于表达意图，方便其他开发者理解。 普遍共识是，不闭合标签在语法上可行且能减少文件体积，但在实际开发中，多数人更重视代码的可读性和一致性。分歧点在于是否应在实践中利用这一特性：一方认为它提升了编写效率，另一方则担忧可能引发维护困难或历史兼容性问题。

comments.author: tannhaeuser
comments.content: Guess what, you're not required to open <html>, <head>, or <body> either. It all follows from SGML tag inference rules, and the rules aren't that difficult to understand. What makes them appear magical is WHATWG's verbose ad-hoc parsing algorithm presentation explicitly listing eg. elements that close their parents originally captured from SGML but having become unmaintained as new elements were added. This already started to happen in the very first revision after Ian Hickson's initial procedural HTML parsing description ([1]).I'd also wish people would stop calling every element-specific behavior HTML parsers do "liberal and tag-soup"-like. Yes WHATWG HTML does define error recovery rules, and HTML had introduced historic blunders to accomodate inline CSS and inline JS, but almost always what's being complained about are just SGML empty elements (aka HTML void elements) or tag omission (as described above) by folks not doing their homework.[1]: https://sgmljs.sgml.net/docs/html5.html#tag-omission (see also XML Prague 2017 proceedings pp. 101ff)
comments.content_cn:
猜怎么着，你其实也不需要打开<html>、<head>或<body>标签。这一切都遵循SGML标签推断规则，而这些规则理解起来并不困难。它们之所以显得神秘，是因为WHATWG冗长的临时解析算法描述明确列出了某些元素——例如那些原本从SGML继承而来、会关闭其父元素的规则——但随着新元素的添加，这些规则已不再维护。这种情况在伊恩·希克森最初提出的程序化HTML解析描述（[1]）之后的第一次修订中就已经开始出现了。

我还希望人们不要再把HTML解析器对每个元素的特定行为都称为“宽松且像标签汤”。是的，WHATWG HTML确实定义了错误恢复规则，而且HTML为了兼容内联CSS和内联JS也引入了一些历史性错误，但人们抱怨的几乎总是那些没有做好功课的人所误解的SGML空元素（即HTML空元素）或标签省略（如上所述）。

[1]: https://sgmljs.sgml.net/docs/html5.html#tag-omission（另见XML Prague 2017会议记录第101页及之后）

comments.author: delaminator
comments.content:
Go back a bit further for why.Netscape Navigator did, in fact, reject invalid HTML. Then along came Internet Explorer and chose “render invalid HTML dwim” as a strategy. People, my young naive self included, moaned about NN being too strict.
NN eventually switched to the tag soup approach.
XHTML 1.0 arrived in 2000, attempting to reform HTML by recasting it as an XML application. The idea was to impose XML’s strict parsing rules: well-formed documents only, close all your tags, lowercase element names, quote all attributes, and if the document is malformed, the parser must stop and display an error rather than guess. XHTML was abandoned in 2009.
When HTML5 was being drafted in 2004-onwards, the WHATWG actually had to formally specify how browsers should handle malformed markup, essentially codifying IE’s error-recovery heuristics as the standard.
comments.content_cn:
追溯更早的原因。网景导航者浏览器确实曾拒绝无效的HTML。随后出现的Internet Explorer则选择了“以所见即所得方式渲染无效HTML”作为策略。人们——包括当时年轻天真的我——曾抱怨网景过于严格。
网景最终转向了标签汤解析方式。
XHTML 1.0于2000年问世，试图通过将HTML重构为XML应用来进行改革。其核心思想是强制实施XML的严格解析规则：仅接受格式良好的文档、必须闭合所有标签、元素名称小写、所有属性加引号，若文档格式错误，解析器必须停止并显示错误而非猜测。XHTML于2009年被弃用。
当HTML5从2004年起开始起草时，网页超文本技术工作小组实际上不得不正式规定浏览器应如何处理错误标记，本质上将IE的错误恢复启发式方法编入了标准。

comments.author: HiPhish
comments.content: Serious question: why would you ever want to not close tags? It saves a couple of key strokes, but we have snippets in our editors, so the amount of typing is the same. Closed tags allow editors like Vim or automated tools to handle the source code easier; e.g. I can type `dit` in Vim to delete the contents of a tag, something that's only possible because the tag's content is clearly delimited. It makes parsing HTML easier because there are fewer syntax rules.I learned HTML quite late, when HTML 5 was already all the rage, and I never understood why the more strict rules of XML for HTML never took off. They seem so much saner than whatever soup of special rules and exceptions we currently have. HTML 5 was an opportunity to make a clear cut between legacy HTML and the future of HTML. Even though I don't have to, I strive to adhere to the stricter rules of closing all tags, closing self-closing tags and only using lower-case tag names.
comments.content_cn: 严肃提问：为什么有人会不想闭合标签呢？虽然少敲几个键能节省一点时间，但编辑器里都有代码片段功能，实际输入量并没有差别。闭合标签能让Vim这类编辑器或自动化工具更轻松地处理源代码——比如在Vim里输入`dit`就能删除标签内容，这完全得益于标签边界明确。它还能简化HTML解析，因为需要处理的语法规则更少。我接触HTML很晚，当时HTML5已蔚然成风，始终不理解为何更严格的XML式规则没有在HTML领域普及。相比现在各种特例和例外规则混杂的现状，XML的规则显然更合理。HTML5本应是划清传统HTML与未来HTML界限的契机。即使没有强制要求，我仍坚持遵循更严格的规范：闭合所有标签、闭合自闭合标签、只使用小写标签名。

comments.author: jerf
comments.content: Perhaps the most distinguishing characteristic of HTML5 is that it specifies exactly what to do with tag soup. The rules are worth a glance at some time, just to see how rather absurdly complicated they are to do the job of picking up the pieces of who knows how many terabytes and petabytes of garbage HTML were generated before they were codified in an attempt to remain backwards compatible with the various browsers prior to that. And then you'll understand why I'm not going to even begin to attempt to answer your question about how browsers handle various tag combinations. Instead my point is only that, with HTML5, there is in fact a very concrete answer that is no longer up to the browsers trying to each individually spackle over the various and sundry gaps in the standards.But honestly no answer to "what does the browser do with this sort of thing" fits into an HN comment anymore. I'm glad there's a standard, but there's a better branch of the multiverse where the specification of what to do with bad HTML was written from the beginning and is much, much simpler.

comments.author: bazoom42
comments.content:
But not closing

etc has always been valid HTML. Back from SGML it was possible for closing tags to be optional (depending on the DTD), and Netscape supported this from the beginning.Leaving out closing tags is possible when the parsing is unambigous. E.g

foo

bar is unambiguous becuse p elements does not nest, so they close automatically by the next p.The question about invalid HTML is a sepearate issue. E.g you can’t nest a p inside an i according to the spec, so how does a browser render that? Or lexical error like illegal characters in a non-quoted attribute value.This is where it gets tricky. Render anyway, skip the invalid html, or stop rendering with an error message? HTML did not specify what to do with invalid input, so either is legal. Browsers choose to go with the “render anyway” approach, but this lead to different outputs in different browsers, since it wasn’t agreed upon how to render invald html.The difference between Netscape and IE was that Netscape in more cases would skip rendering invalid HTML, where IE would always render the content.
comments.content_cn: 但不闭合标签等做法一直是有效的HTML。自SGML时代起，闭合标签就可选（取决于DTD），网景浏览器从一开始就支持这种做法。当解析没有歧义时，省略闭合标签是可行的。例如，foobar没有歧义，因为p元素不能嵌套，所以它们会在下一个p出现时自动闭合。关于无效HTML的问题是另一个独立议题。例如，根据规范，不能在i标签内嵌套p标签，那么浏览器会如何渲染这种情况？或者像非引号属性值中出现非法字符这类词法错误。这里就变得棘手了：是继续渲染、跳过无效HTML，还是停止渲染并显示错误信息？HTML并未规定如何处理无效输入，因此这些做法都是合法的。浏览器选择了“无论如何都渲染”的方式，但由于对如何渲染无效HTML没有统一标准，这导致不同浏览器产生不同的输出结果。网景和IE的区别在于，网景在更多情况下会跳过渲染无效HTML，而IE总是会渲染内容。

posts.title: C++ std::move doesn't move anything: A deep dive into Value Categories
posts.author: signa11
posts.title_cn: "C++ std::move 并不移动任何东西：深入探讨值类别"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕C++中std::move的实际作用与价值类别展开。核心话题在于澄清std::move并非直接移动对象，而是将对象转换为右值引用，从而允许编译器选择移动构造函数而非复制构造函数。

社区中普遍认同std::move本身不执行移动操作，移动行为需依赖用户实现的移动构造函数或赋值运算符。有共识认为，若移动构造函数未标记为noexcept，标准库容器可能出于安全考虑仍使用复制操作，这可能导致性能隐患。

讨论中观点存在分歧：有人认为std::move的命名易产生误解，应更贴近“资源转移”的语义；也有用户指出，过度追求通用解决方案可能不如针对常见情况优化有效。部分用户表示，理解移动语义存在认知门槛，而学习Rust等语言有助于建立更清晰的概念模型。此外，有开发者质疑是否需显式使用std::move，期望编译器能自动优化，但实际中隐式移动可能无法覆盖所有场景，需谨慎处理。

comments.content: In C++17 and later, return std::move(local_variable) as opposed to return local_variable is only breaking NRVO (which avoids even having to move, by essentially replacing local_variable with a reference to the variable the caller is assigning the function result to).In C++17 if you do return std::move(local_variable) it will do exactly what you asked for and move the local variable to the return value, which with copy elision means directly to the caller's variable.So, return std::move(local_variable) is only preventing NRVO, it's not preventing a move (even though you shouldn't be asking for a move, because move is not the most efficient way).
comments.content_cn: 在C++17及后续版本中，使用`return std::move(local_variable)`而非`return local_variable`只会破坏NRVO（命名返回值优化，该优化通过将局部变量替换为指向调用者接收函数结果的变量的引用，从而避免移动操作）。在C++17中，如果使用`return std::move(local_variable)`，编译器将严格按照要求执行，将局部变量移动到返回值，结合复制消除机制，这意味着直接移动到调用者的变量中。因此，`return std::move(local_variable)`仅会阻止NRVO，而不会阻止移动操作（尽管不应要求移动，因为移动并非最高效的方式）。

comments.author: usefulcat
comments.content: Agreed that c++03 was much simpler, but that doesn't change the fact that there are useful things that are possible in modern c++ that simply were not possible before.Like if I have a vector<std::string>, in c++03 when it resizes it must copy every string from the old storage to the new storage. For a vector of size N, that's up to N+1 allocations (allowing for the possibility that std::string uses the small string optimization).Granted, std::string doesn't have to allocate when copied if it's a "copy on write" implementation. IIRC, there were some implementations that used that technique when c++03 was the latest, but I don't think there are any that still do, due to other problems with COW.In modern c++, that same vector resizing operation requires exactly one allocation (for the new vector storage), because all the strings can be moved from the old storage to the new.Yes, you could have a vector of pointers to std::string, but now you've got yet another allocation (and indirection on access) for every string. In practice that tradeoff almost never makes sense, unless perhaps the strings have shared ownership (e.g. vector<shared_ptr<string>>).Ultimately, I think there's really no question that the vector resizing optimization described above is useful in certain scenarios. Having said that, I do agree that the associated complexity is annoying. Therefore, the real question is whether it's possible to have these benefits with less complexity, and I personally don't know the answer to that.
comments.content_cn:
确实，C++03要简单得多，但这无法改变一个事实：现代C++中有些实用功能是早期版本根本无法实现的。例如，假设我有一个向量，在C++03中，当它调整大小时，必须将每个字符串从旧存储区复制到新存储区。对于大小为N的向量，这最多需要N+1次内存分配（考虑到std::string可能采用短字符串优化）。当然，如果采用“写时复制”实现，std::string在复制时无需分配内存。我记得在C++03作为最新标准时，确实有些实现采用了这种技术，但由于写时复制存在的其他问题，我认为现在已没有实现继续使用这种方式。

在现代C++中，同样的向量调整大小操作仅需一次内存分配（用于新向量存储区），因为所有字符串都可以从旧存储区移动至新存储区。是的，你也可以使用指向std::string的指针向量，但这意味着每个字符串都需要额外的一次内存分配（以及访问时的间接寻址）。实际上，这种权衡几乎毫无意义，除非字符串需要共享所有权（例如使用vector<shared_ptr<string>>）。

归根结底，我认为上述向量调整大小优化在某些场景下显然是有用的。话虽如此，我也同意相关的复杂性确实令人烦恼。因此，真正的问题在于：能否以更低的复杂度获得这些优势？我个人尚不知道这个问题的答案。

The documentations seems to say that option only causes the compiler to issue a warning when move constructors are not marked noexcept - it doesn't override anything.https://clang.llvm.org/extra/clang-tidy/checks/performance/n...
constructor.htmlNote that the way std::vector (and other STL containers) require noexcept move constructors for reallocation is by using template matching, and of course any other code might be doing this too, so having a compiler option that forced a constructor (or anything) to have a type signature different than the way it was declared would be a pretty dangerous thing to do since it'd be hard to know what the consequences would be.
comments.content_cn: 文档似乎表明该选项仅会在移动构造函数未标记为noexcept时导致编译器发出警告——它不会覆盖任何内容。请注意，std::vector（及其他STL容器）通过模板匹配要求重新分配时使用noexcept移动构造函数，当然其他代码也可能采用这种做法。因此，若设置编译器选项强制构造函数（或任何其他元素）拥有与声明时不同的类型签名，将是非常危险的操作，因为很难预知其后果。

posts.title: Show HN: Ferrite – Markdown editor in Rust with native Mermaid diagram rendering
posts.content: Ferrite: Fast Markdown/Text/Code editor in Rust with native Mermaid diagramsBuilt a Markdown editor using Rust + egui. v0.2.1 just dropped with major Mermaid improvements:→ Native Mermaid diagrams - Flowcharts, sequence, state, ER, git graphs - pure Rust, no JS→ Split view - Raw + rendered side-by-side with sync scrolling→ Syntax highlighting - 40+ languages with large file optimization→ JSON/YAML/TOML tree viewer - Structured editing with expand/collapse→ Git integration - File tree shows modified/staged/untracked statusAlso: minimap, zen mode, auto-save, session restore, code folding indicators.~15MB binary, instant startup. Windows/Linux/macOS.GitHub: https://github.com/OlaProeis/Ferritev0.2.2 coming soon with performance improvements for large files. Looking for feedback!
posts.author: OlaProis
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: Ferrite – 基于 Rust 的 Markdown 编辑器，支持原生 Mermaid 图表渲染"
posts.content_cn:
Ferrite：基于 Rust 开发的快速 Markdown/文本/代码编辑器，支持原生 Mermaid 图表
使用 Rust + egui 构建的 Markdown 编辑器。v0.2.1 版本刚刚发布，对 Mermaid 功能进行了重大改进：
→ 原生 Mermaid 图表 - 流程图、时序图、状态图、ER 图、Git 图 - 纯 Rust 实现，无需 JS
→ 分屏视图 - 原始文本与渲染视图并排显示，支持同步滚动
→ 语法高亮 - 支持 40 多种语言，并优化了大文件处理
→ JSON/YAML/TOML 树形查看器 - 支持展开/折叠的结构化编辑
→ Git 集成 - 文件树显示已修改/已暂存/未跟踪状态
此外还包含：缩略图导航、禅模式、自动保存、会话恢复、代码折叠指示器。
约 15MB 的二进制文件，启动迅速。支持 Windows/Linux/macOS。
GitHub：https://github.com/OlaProeis/Ferrite
v0.2.2 版本即将推出，将优化大文件处理性能。期待您的反馈！
posts.abstract:
该帖子展示了用Rust开发的Markdown编辑器Ferrite，其核心特色是原生支持Mermaid图表渲染。社区讨论主要围绕编辑器功能、技术实现和市场需求展开。

有人认为该项目展现了Rust生态在编辑器领域的潜力，特别是其纯Rust实现的Mermaid渲染和Git集成受到关注。也有用户指出当前截图显示文字过小，建议优化展示方式。讨论中提到用户期待更多专注于基础功能的Markdown编辑器替代品，部分用户希望获得更简洁的单二进制文件方案。

存在明显分歧的是关于AI生成内容的争议，有用户质疑代码和帖子是否由AI生成，开发者未直接回应。但普遍认同的是，社区对注重隐私、易于扩展的编辑器有强烈需求，许多用户期待出现能替代Obsidian且不存储明文文件的工具。

开发者积极回应反馈，在后续版本中快速修复了CJK字体支持、CLI功能等问题，体现了对社区意见的重视。整体而言，虽然市场已存在大量Markdown编辑器，但社区仍对基于Rust构建的高性能、可定制工具抱有期待。

Ferrite is privacy-focused in that it's fully offline — no telemetry, no cloud sync, no accounts, no network calls (even Mermaid diagrams render locally in pure Rust).However, files are stored as plain text, same as Obsidian/VS Code/any text editor. Encryption at rest isn't currently on the roadmap.For encrypted storage, you might consider:
 - Using Ferrite with an encrypted volume (VeraCrypt, LUKS, FileVault)
 - git-crypt for encrypted git reposThat said, if there's strong interest in built-in encryption (vault-style or file-level), I'd love to hear more about the use case. Would you want password-protected vaults? Per-file encryption? Something else?
comments.content_cn:
Ferrite注重隐私保护，主要体现在完全离线运行——无遥测、无云同步、无账户体系、无网络请求（甚至Mermaid图表也通过纯Rust在本地渲染）。但文件以纯文本形式存储，与Obsidian/VS Code/任何文本编辑器相同。目前尚未规划静态加密功能。如需加密存储，可考虑：
 - 在加密卷中使用Ferrite（如VeraCrypt、LUKS、FileVault）
 - 通过git-crypt加密git仓库
若对内置加密功能（保险库模式或文件级加密）有强烈需求，欢迎进一步说明使用场景。您需要密码保护的保险库？单文件加密？或其他方案？

comments.author: OlaProis
comments.content:
Fair point about fragmentation! Ferrite uses Comrak which implements CommonMark + GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM) — arguably the closest thing to a "standard" we have.We chose Markdown because:
 - It's what most developers already use (README files, documentation, wikis)
 - Plain text files are portable, grep-able, git-friendly, and won't lock you in
 - GFM covers tables, task lists, strikethrough, and autolinks which handles 90% of use casesWe also support JSON, YAML, and TOML with native tree viewers. Wikilinks ([[links]]) and backlinks are planned for v0.3.0 for folks wanting Obsidian-style knowledge bases.That said, I'd love to hear what format you'd prefer — always interested in expanding support!
comments.content_cn:
关于碎片化的观点很中肯！Ferrite 使用 Comrak 库，它实现了 CommonMark + GitHub 风味 Markdown（GFM）——这可以说是目前最接近“标准”的方案。我们选择 Markdown 是因为：
- 这是大多数开发者已经使用的格式（README 文件、文档、维基）
- 纯文本文件便于移植、支持 grep 搜索、与 git 兼容，且不会造成技术锁定
- GFM 支持表格、任务列表、删除线和自动链接，能满足 90% 的使用场景

我们还通过原生树状查看器支持 JSON、YAML 和 TOML 格式。针对需要 Obsidian 风格知识库的用户，计划在 v0.3.0 版本中实现维基链接（[[链接]]）和反向链接功能。

话说回来，我很想听听您更倾向于什么格式——我们始终对扩展支持持开放态度！

comments.author: OlaProis
comments.content: Ha! I appreciate the compliment (I think?). To be transparent: yes, AI tools were used during development — they're fantastic for boilerplate, documentation, and exploring unfamiliar APIs.But this wasn't "2 sessions" — Ferrite has been in development for months with ~30,000 lines of Rust across 50+ modules. posts.title: Eulogy for Dark Sky, a data visualization masterpiece (2023)
posts.author: skadamat
posts.title_cn: 《暗空》悼文：一部数据可视化杰作（2023）
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕已停服的天气应用Dark Sky展开，用户们普遍怀念其卓越的数据可视化界面和简洁高效的设计。许多人认为Dark Sky在用户体验上至今未被超越，尤其对比苹果收购后的官方天气应用，后者虽逐步加入类似功能，但被批评为界面杂乱、信息过载。有用户指出，苹果应用甚至缺失Dark Sky的历史天气查询等关键特性。

社区中提到了多个替代方案：例如MerrySky、Weathergraph、Breezy Weather等应用，以及Yr.no网站，部分用户认为这些应用在界面或功能上各有接近之处，但整体仍无法完全替代Dark Sky。讨论中也存在分歧：有人认为Dark Sky的温度显示方式存在模糊性（如日间高低温时段不明确），但更多用户强调其直观的视觉呈现和精准的降雨通知功能，成为大家共同认可的核心优势。

comments.author: Leftium
comments.content: > It removes a sense of artificial precision that doesn’t really exist because weather forecasts fundamentally have very high uncertainty and error bands.So true.Open Meteo supports 28 different WMO weather condition codes[1]. Most weather apps only support half as many. (Just "rain" instead of light/moderate/heavy rain.)Showing all 28 is less helpful because of the noise. More useful just to show it might rain for a period of several hours vs oscillating between light rain and heavy rain. The light vs heavy precision wasn't worth it when there was high uncertainty whether it would even rain at all.So https://weather-sense.leftium.com consolidates hours with similar weather conditions into a single segment by default. You can click on the weather icons at the left of the plots to toggle the original unconsolidated view.[1]: https://weather-sense.leftium.com/wmo-codes
comments.content_cn: 它消除了那种本不存在的虚假精确感，因为天气预报本质上具有很高的不确定性和误差范围。确实如此。Open Meteo支持28种不同的世界气象组织天气状况代码[1]。大多数天气应用只支持一半左右。（比如只显示“下雨”，而不区分小雨、中雨、大雨。）显示全部28种反而会因为信息噪音而降低实用性。更有用的是显示未来几小时可能下雨，而不是在小雨和大雨之间反复变化。当连是否下雨都存在高度不确定性时，区分小雨或大雨的精确度并不值得追求。因此，https://weather-sense.leftium.com 默认将天气状况相似的时段合并为单个区间。你可以点击图表左侧的天气图标来切换显示原始的未合并视图。[1]: https://weather-sense.leftium.com/wmo-codes

posts.title: iCloud Photos Downloader
posts.author: reconnecting
posts.title_cn: iCloud 照片下载器
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕iCloud照片下载的困难展开。用户普遍认为苹果的照片管理系统过于复杂，特别是iCloud照片的批量下载和备份存在诸多不便。有人指出，仅靠复制文件无法完整保留相册、实况照片、编辑记录等元数据状态，这给数据迁移带来挑战。也有用户提到，苹果的“优化存储”功能难以关闭，且文件命名规则在超过9999张后会导致重复，增加了管理难度。

在解决方案上，讨论中出现了不同观点。部分用户推荐使用第三方工具如Photos Backup Anywhere、Parachute或PhotoSync来简化下载流程；但也有用户对非官方工具的安全性表示担忧，建议谨慎处理iCloud凭证。此外，对于专业格式（如实况照片）的导出是否无损存在分歧，一些用户认为现有导出方式可能导致画质损失。

共识在于，用户希望拥有更自主、透明的照片管理方式，避免被单一生态系统锁定。尽管不少人欣赏iCloud的回忆等功能，但高昂的长期存储费用和封闭的系统设计促使他们寻求外部备份方案。

comments.author: gerdemb
comments.content:
HN disclosure: I’m the author of Photos Backup Anywhere, but this thread mirrors the exact issues that pushed me to write it.One thing that surprised me when digging into Apple Photos is how much state isn’t represented by just files-on-disk. Albums, Live Photos (paired assets), bursts, slo-mo, edits, and even “simple” things like adjusted capture dates are all tracked separately, and most export/backup tools end up flattening or partially reconstructing that on restore.The approach I took was to treat Photos as the source of truth and verify restored items against it, rather than assuming filesystem metadata is enough. As far as I know, this is the only tool that restores albums and correctly round-trips all Photos item types while preserving location data, creation dates, and modification dates when restoring back into Photos.Project page is here if it’s useful:
https://photosbackup.app/Happy to explain details if anyone’s curious — there are a lot of sharp edges in Photos once you go beyond “export originals”.
comments.content_cn:
HN声明：我是Photos Backup Anywhere的作者，但这个帖子恰好反映了促使我开发此工具的那些问题。深入研究苹果照片应用时，让我惊讶的一点是，仅凭磁盘文件无法体现大量状态信息。相册、实况照片（配对资源）、连拍、慢动作视频、编辑内容，甚至像调整过的拍摄日期这类“简单”信息，都是单独记录的，大多数导出/备份工具在恢复时最终会将这些信息扁平化处理或部分重建。

我采用的方法是将照片应用视为数据源，并据此验证恢复的项目，而不是假设文件系统元数据就足够了。据我所知，这是唯一能在恢复回照片应用时，正确还原相册、完整循环处理所有照片项目类型，同时保留地理位置、创建日期和修改日期的工具。

项目页面在此，供参考：
https://photosbackup.app/

如果有人好奇细节，我很乐意解释——一旦超越“导出原片”的范畴，照片应用里其实有很多棘手之处。

I run this periodically from a little shell script; I "should" automate it, but time is scarce.  ⟩ cat ~/bin/icloud_download
  #!/bin/bash
  mkdir "$(pwd)"/{photos,cookies} 2> /dev/null
  
  if [[ -z "${ICLOUD_USERNAME}" ]]; then
      echo "need env ICLOUD_USERNAME"
      exit 1
  fi
  if [[ -z "${ICLOUD_PASSWORD}" ]]; then
      echo "need env ICLOUD_PASSWORD"
      exit 1
  fi
  
  podman container run -it --rm --name icloud \
      -v $(pwd)/photos:/data \
      -v $(pwd)/cookies:/cookies \
      -e TZ=America/Boise \
      icloudpd/icloudpd:latest \
      icloudpd --directory /data \
      --cookie-directory /cookies \
      --folder-structure {:%Y/%Y-%m-%d} \
      --username "${ICLOUD_USERNAME}" \
      --password "${ICLOUD_PASSWORD}" \
      --size original

My compromise is simple:- I use docker-icloudpd to download our iCloud Photos to local storage over time. It’s been the most practical way I’ve found to back up multiple accounts into one place, though it does require occasional re-auth every so often.
- I keep only the last ~2 years of media in iCloud and delete older ones after they’re archived locally.
- For browsing and searching the older archive, I use Immich, which has been a great self-hosted personal photo cloud experience with a modern app feel.For storage, I’ve found fast local disk matters a lot once you’re digging up photos from 5+ years ago. Something like an OWC 4M2 with M.2 drives keeps the experience snappy; a typical HDD-based NAS can feel sluggish when you just want to quickly pull up an old memory.https://github.com/boredazfcuk/docker-icloudpd

posts.title: Gentoo Linux 2025 Review
posts.author: akhuettel
posts.title_cn: Gentoo Linux 2025 评测
posts.abstract: 这篇帖子围绕Gentoo Linux 2025年度回顾展开讨论，核心话题是评估Gentoo的现状、技术进展及社区生态。有人认为Gentoo极具灵活性，其源码包管理方式使其能轻松支持RISC-V等新架构，且开发者入门系统广受好评；也有用户指出，随着Arch等发行版的兴起，Gentoo的影响力有所下降，部分用户因时间或资源限制转向了其他系统。讨论中提到，Google ChromeOS底层仍依赖Gentoo Portage，但社区对开发贡献减少表示担忧，猜测可能是项目趋于稳定或活跃度下降所致。分歧点主要集中在Gentoo的实用性上：一方赞赏其高度可定制性和技术前瞻性，另一方则认为其编译过程过于耗时，对老旧硬件不友好。普遍共识是Gentoo在支持新兴架构和社区协作方面表现突出，但面临用户流失和资源消耗大的挑战。

Probably one of the coolest things I’ve ever built, at this point I’m effectively building my own Linux distro from source and it’s all defined in Containerfiles! I have such affection for the Gentoo team for enabling this project, shocking to discover how little they operate on I’m definitely setting up a recurring donation.

comments.author: M95D
comments.content: TLDR: Installation is a pain, initial configuration is a pain and there's always something more to tweak, update is a lesser pain, but still a pain. But it's fun, BDSM-style...Installation is done by booting a liveCD, manually partitioning your storage, unpacking a Gentoo STAGE3 archive, chrooting in it, doing basic configuration such as network, timezone, portage (package manager) base profile and servers, etc., compiling and installing a kernel and then rebooting into the new system.Then you get to play with /etc/portage/make.conf which is the root configuration of the package manager. You get to set CPU instruction sets (CPU_FLAGS), gcc CFLAGS flags, MAKE flags, video card targets, acceptable package licenses, global USE flags (those are simplified ./configure arguments that usually apply to several packages), which Apache modules get built, which qemu targets get built, etc. These are all env vars that portage (the package manager) uses to build packages for your system.The more you use Gentoo, the more features of make.conf you discover. Never ending fun.Then, you start installing packages and updates (same procedure):1) You start the update by reviewing USE flags for each added/updated package - several screens of dense text.For example, PHP has these USE flags: https://packages.gentoo.org/packages/dev-lang/php - mouse hover to see what they do. You get to play with them in /etc/portage/package.use and there's no end to tweaking them.If you have any form of OCD, stay away from Gentoo or this will be your poison forever!2) Then the compilation begins and that takes hours or days depending on what you install and uses a lot of CPU and either storage I/O or memory (if you have lots of memory, you can compile in a tmpfs a lot faster).I'm not sure it is OK to compile the updates on a live server, especially during busy hours, but Gentoo has alternatives, including binary packages (recently added, but must match your USE flags with theirs), building packages remotely on another system (distcc), even on a different arch (crossdev). You could run an ARM server and build packages for it on a x86 workstation. I didn't use "steve", so I can't tell you what wonderful things that tool can do, yet.3) Depending on architecture, some less used packages may fail to compile. You get to manually debug that and submit bug reports. You can also add patches to /etc/portage/patches/<package> that will automatically be applied when the package is built, and that includes the kernel.I recommend you to run emerge with --keep-going to have the package manager continue after an error with the remaining packages.4) When each package is done compiling, it's installed automatically. There are no automatic reboots or anything. The files are replaced live, both executables and libraries. Running services continue to use old files from memory until you restart them or reboot manually - they will appear red/yellow in htop until you do.There were a few times, very very few, when I had crashes in new packages that were succesfuly built. It only happened on armv7, which is a practically abandoned platform everywhere. In those cases you can revert to the old ones and mask the bugged version to prevent it from being updated to next time.5) Last step is to review the config changes. dispatch-conf will present a diff of all proposed changes to .ini and .cfg files for all updated packages. You get to review, accept, reject the changes or manually edit the files.That's all. Simple. :)
comments.content_cn:
太长不看版：安装过程很痛苦，初始配置很痛苦，总有更多细节需要调整，更新相对好一些但依然痛苦。不过这种体验很有趣，带着点受虐倾向……

安装过程需要从LiveCD启动，手动分区存储设备，解压Gentoo STAGE3压缩包，切换根目录到新环境，进行网络、时区、Portage（包管理器）基础配置和服务设置等基础配置，编译并安装内核，最后重启进入新系统。

接着就可以开始配置/etc/portage/make.conf文件，这是包管理器的核心配置文件。你需要设置CPU指令集（CPU_FLAGS）、gcc编译标志（CFLAGS）、MAKE参数、显卡目标架构、可接受的软件许可证、全局USE标志（这些是简化的./configure参数，通常适用于多个软件包）、需要编译的Apache模块和qemu目标架构等。这些都是Portage（包管理器）用来为系统构建软件包的环境变量。

使用Gentoo越久，就越能发现make.conf的更多功能。这种乐趣永无止境。

然后开始安装软件包和更新（流程相同）：
1）每次更新前需要逐条审核新增/更新软件包的USE标志——往往要翻阅好几屏密集的文本信息。
例如PHP的USE标志详见：https://packages.gentoo.org/packages/dev-lang/php （鼠标悬停可查看功能说明）。你可以在/etc/portage/package.use文件中调整这些参数，而且这种调整永无止境。
如果你有任何形式的强迫症倾向，请务必远……

comments.author: Fiveplus
comments.content: That is a fantastic historical parallel. The early amd64 days were arguably Gentoo's killer app moment. While the binary distributions were wrestling with the logistical nightmare of splitting repositories and figuring out the /lib64 vs /lib standard, Gentoo users just changed their CHOST, bootstrapped and were running 64-bit native. You nailed the psychology of it, too. The speed marketing was always a bit of a red herring. The ability to say "I do not want LDAP support in my mail client" and have the package manager actually respect that is cool. It respects the user's intelligence rather than abstracting it away.Since you've been on the ride since '04, I'm curious to hear your thoughts. How do you feel the maintenance burden compares today versus the GCC 3.x era? With the modern binhost fallback and the improvements in portage, I feel like we now spend less time fighting rebuild loops than back then? But I wonder if long time users feel the same.
comments.content_cn: 这真是一个绝妙的历史类比。amd64早期阶段可以说是Gentoo的杀手级应用时刻。当二进制发行版还在为拆分软件仓库的繁琐问题以及/lib64与/lib标准争论不休时，Gentoo用户只需修改CHOST、完成引导就能直接运行原生64位系统。你也精准把握了用户心理——速度营销其实多少是个误导。能够声明“我不需要邮件客户端支持LDAP功能”并让包管理器真正遵循这一点，这种体验非常酷。它尊重用户的自主选择权而非将其抽象化。既然你从04年就开始使用，我很想听听你的看法：你觉得现在的维护负担与GCC 3.x时代相比如何？有了现代的二进制包备用方案和portage的改进，我感觉现在花在解决重建循环问题上的时间比过去少多了？但不知道长期用户是否也有同感。

comments.author: notme43
comments.content: Yes - still use emerge on the Thinkpad like I would on the host, like emerge -avuDN @world and such. This is the wiki article [1] I used to set up most the portage side of things, it covers NFS as well.I use NFS to mount the container's /etc/portage to /mnt/portage and symlink the files to the Thinkpad's /etc/portage so I can cherry pick what I want to keep in sync with the build container. Don't have to mess with repos.conf either because portage will look to /var/cache/binpkgs by default.make.conf is a directory on both machines and has files like 01-common-flags.conf and 02-binhost-flags.conf. The Thinkpad has 01-common-flags.conf and 03-target-flags.conf with EMERGE_DEFAULT_OPTS="--with-bdeps=n --usepkgonly" set, so running emerge -avuDN on the Thinkpad will only update with binaries from the mounted /var/cache/binpkgs. I keep the software in sync by using /etc/portage/sets instead of the world file. Then all the package.* dirs are symlinks as well.The Thinkpad binhost is a znver3, so the build container has CFLAGS="--march=x86-64-v3 --mtune=alderlake" set. There's some SIMD extensions that two don't have in common and it has to build code that runs on both machines, otherwise you could use the target architecture in --march. Using the --mtune option in my case apparently sets the L2 cache size of the produced code to that of the Intel chip.Systemd-nspawn containers are super easy to spin up, as you basically install Gentoo from stage3 and it works like a chroot but with a full init. I run updates irregularly, there's still some manual effort for maintenance, but it's mostly just kicking off emerge and letting it build in a tmux session.[1] https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Binary_package_guide
comments.content_cn:
是的——我仍然像在主机上一样在Thinkpad上使用emerge命令，比如emerge -avuDN @world之类的操作。这篇维基文章[1]是我用来设置大部分Portage相关配置的，其中也涵盖了NFS部分。我使用NFS将容器的/etc/portage挂载到/mnt/portage，并将文件符号链接到Thinkpad的/etc/portage，这样我可以选择性同步与构建容器保持一致的内容。也不需要处理repos.conf，因为Portage默认会查找/var/cache/binpkgs。

在两台机器上，make.conf都是一个目录，包含像01-common-flags.conf和02-binhost-flags.conf这样的文件。Thinkpad上有01-common-flags.conf和03-target-flags.conf，其中设置了EMERGE_DEFAULT_OPTS="--with-bdeps=n --usepkgonly"，因此在Thinkpad上运行emerge -avuDN时只会通过挂载的/var/cache/binpkgs中的二进制包进行更新。我通过使用/etc/portage/sets而不是world文件来保持软件同步。然后所有的package.*目录也都是符号链接。

Thinkpad的二进制主机是znver3架构，因此构建容器设置了CFLAGS="--march=x86-64-v3 --mtune=alderlake"。两者有一些不共有的SIMD扩展，并且需要构建能在两台机器上运行的代码，否则可以在--march中使用目标架构。在我的情况下，使用--mtune选项显然会将生成代码的L2缓存大小设置为英特尔芯片的规格。

Systemd-nspawn容器启动超级简单，基本上就是从stage3安装Gentoo，它工作起来就像chroot，但带有……

posts.title: A battle over Canada’s mystery brain disease
posts.author: lewww
posts.title_cn: 加拿大神秘脑部疾病之争
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕加拿大新不伦瑞克省出现的神秘脑部疾病展开。有人认为这可能与当地长期存在的工业污染有关，特别是欧文家族掌控的石油、造纸和林业企业，暗示环境因素可能是病因。也有用户指出，负责诊断的马雷罗医生在医疗界评价两极，部分同行认为他检查过度，且所有病例的唯一共同点就是这位医生，因此怀疑诊断准确性。讨论中提到，政府调查被突然终止且未对患者进行亲自检查，引发对官方处理方式不透明的批评。部分用户建议患者迁离该省以观察病情变化，并进行重金属检测。共识在于，无论疾病真实与否，卫生部门的应对都存在严重缺陷；分歧则集中在病因是环境暴露、医生误诊还是未知疾病，以及调查是否应更透明深入。

comments.author: pash
comments.content: I’m not qualified to comment intelligently on what might be going on here, but I’d like to add some background color that the article lacks.Creutzfeldt–Jakob Disease is a prion disease [0] for which there is no definitive diagnosis in vivo. A confident diagnosis can be made only after examining brain tissue under a microscope.Prions are an unusual type of mis-folded protein that induce other proteins to take on a similar mis-folded shape when they come into contact with them. The mis-folded shape of the prion itself is what causes the mis-folding in adjacent proteins. It’s a chemical-bonding thing at the molecular level. It’s the shape of the prion that causes other proteins to take on a similar shape and become prions, etc.Some prion diseases occur spontaneously (when a protein takes on a mis-folded configuration due to mis-transcription or random energetic impulses) and some are transmitted, typically by eating some part of an animal that contains prions, which then end up in your own body, inducing proteins in your body to take on prion configurations.Prion diseases are the only known transmissible diseases that do not involve the replication of a pathogen’s genetic material in a host cell. The only known prion diseases affect nervous tissues, and in humans the only known prion diseases affect brain tissues.I’m not an expert on prion diseases, but I’ve had a bit of a fascination with them since having to report on a bunch of USDA surveillance lectures on mad-cow disease (bovine spongiform encephalopathy, BSE) and to summarize a bunch of symposia on prion diseases in a previous life. The symptoms reported in the article sound very much like a  prion disease, and the tests for CJD indicate that the doctors in the region suspect as much.But we simply don’t have good tests for prion diseases in vivo. And prion diseases are not well understood in general, so it wouldn’t be surprising that a new one would present as something of a mystery.It is also the case that I know very little about New Brunswick, but I will mention that prion diseases in humans are thought to be far more commonly acquired than spontaneous. The most common cause of acquisition is  eating animals with endemic prion diseases; this is most often nervous tissue of venison, but rarely nervous tissue of cattle infected with BSE, which is present in Canada more than anywhere else (by a small margin).It is also possible (but not likely) that a prion disease can arise de novo.0. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prion_disease

我虽不具备足够资质对此事进行专业评论，但想补充一些文章中缺失的背景信息。克雅氏病是一种朊病毒疾病[0]，目前尚无确切的生前诊断方法，唯有通过显微镜检查脑组织才能获得明确诊断。

朊病毒是一种异常的错误折叠蛋白质，当与其他蛋白质接触时，会诱导后者呈现类似的错误折叠形态。这种错误折叠形态本身正是导致相邻蛋白质发生错误折叠的原因，这是分子层面的化学键合现象。朊病毒的特定形态会促使其他蛋白质采取相似构象，从而转化为新的朊病毒。

部分朊病毒疾病属于自发产生（当蛋白质因转录错误或随机能量脉冲而形成错误折叠构型时），另一些则通过传播感染，通常因食用含有朊病毒的动物组织所致，这些朊病毒进入人体后会诱导体内蛋白质形成朊病毒构型。

朊病毒疾病是已知唯一不涉及病原体遗传物质在宿主细胞内复制的传染性疾病。目前已知的朊病毒疾病仅影响神经组织，而人类朊病毒疾病则专门侵袭脑组织。

我并非朊病毒疾病专家，但自当年需要报道美国农业部关于疯牛病的一系列监测讲座后，便对这种疾病产生了持续的研究兴趣……

posts.title: Code and Let Live
posts.author: usrme
posts.title_cn: 编码与生存
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Fly.io推出的云端开发沙盒服务Sprite展开。核心话题是开发者对这项服务能否提供安全、低成本且便捷的沙盒环境用于运行AI编程助手（如Claude Code）或进行独立开发分支测试的关注。

社区观点多元。有用户表示兴奋，认为Sprite以低成本解决了开发沙盒和AI代码工具安全运行两大需求；也有用户指出其本质类似具备快照功能的VPS，并希望提供本地化或自托管方案而非仅限云端。部分用户赞赏Fly.io的技术实力和快速启动体验，认为适合安全运行AI智能体；但同时存在担忧，包括对CLI工具的复杂性感到麻烦、遇到环境配置问题（如locale错误），以及希望增加沙盒克隆或模板功能以提高效率。

讨论中提到，用户普遍认可云端沙盒在避免遗忘关闭导致高费用方面的优势。主要分歧在于服务形态：一方满足于现成的云端解决方案，另一方则强烈期望获得本地部署或更灵活的分支管理能力。此外，用户对Anthropic（Claude开发公司）与Fly.io是否存在合作关系也表达了疑问。

comments.author: simonw

Fly now have a product that lets me make a simple JSON API call to run untrusted code in a new sandbox. There's even snapshotting support so I can roll back to a known state after running that code.I wrote more a bunch more about this here: https://simonwillison.net/2026/Jan/9/sprites-dev/

comments.content: fly.io is doing really good work. I've super enjoyed building our product on their platform. I love fly-replay combined with super fast start-up.I've been thinking a lot about how to run agents (and skills) securely while giving them a lot of powerful capabilities.I recently used their macaroons library to turn arbitrary API keys (e.g. for stripe's API) into macaroons. I route requests for an upstream host (like stripe) through Envoy as a mitm proxy which injects the real creds after verifying the macaroon.It is such a powerful pattern. I'm always worried about leaking sensitive keys through prompt injection attacks (or just sending them to anthropic), but in this model you can attenuate the keys (both capabilities & validity window) client side. The Envoy proxy lives inside my flycast network so it can't be accessed externally.It would be so cool if fly built something like this into sprites.dev (though I can see how it would be spooky to have fly install their own certs for stripe, etc...)

这种模式极具威力。我一直担心敏感密钥会通过提示注入攻击（或仅仅因为发送给 Anthropic）而泄露，但在这个模型中，客户端可以对密钥进行权限衰减（包括能力范围和有效期限制）。Envoy 代理部署在我的 flycast 网络内部，因此无法从外部访问。

如果 fly 能在 sprites.dev 中内置类似功能就太棒了（虽然我能理解让 fly 为 Stripe 等平台安装自有证书可能会令人感到不安……）

posts.title: Anthropic: Developing a Claude Code competitor using Claude Code is banned
posts.author: behnamoh
posts.title_cn: Anthropic：禁止使用Claude Code开发Claude Code竞品
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Anthropic公司禁止用户使用其Claude Code工具开发竞品的条款展开。核心争议在于用户协议中“使用”定义的模糊性及其执行可行性。有人认为这是律师起草的标准条款，虽对客户不友好但并非特例；也有用户指出该条款实质上禁止了所有开发用途，用户只能依赖公司“不作恶”。讨论中提到，大模型实验室已被明确禁止使用Claude，但对个人用户可能执法不严。部分用户质疑其可操作性：如何检测代码是否由Claude生成？若开源项目合并了相关代码，维护者是否会面临法律风险？同时有观点认为这实质是定价策略，200美元套餐限制使用范围，无限制访问需通过API实现。普遍共识是该条款存在过度限制倾向，但具体执行存在灰色地带。

What you cannot do is reverse engineer the way the Claude Code harness uses the API to build your own version that taps into stuff like the max plan. Which? makes sense?From the thread:> A good rule of thumb is, are you launching a Claude code oauth screen and capturing the token. That is against terms of service.

comments.author: ankit219
comments.content: Because your subscription depends on the very API business.Anthropic's cogs is rent of buying x amount of h100s. cost of a marginal query for them is almost zero until the batch fills up and they need a new cluster. So, API clusters are usually built for peak load with low utilization (filled batch) at any given time. Given AI's peak demand is extremely spiky they end up with low utilization numbers for API support.Your subscription is supposed to use that free capacity. Hence, the token costs are not that high, hence you could buy that. But it needs careful management that you dont overload the system. There is a claude code telemetry which identifies the request as lower priority than API (and probably decide on queueing + caching too). If your harness makes 10 parallel calls everytime you query, and not manage context as well as claude code, its overwhelming the system, degrading the performance for others too. And if everyone just wants to use subscription and you have no api takers, the price of subscription is not sustainable anyway. In a way you are relying on others' generosity for the cheap usage you get.Its reasonable for a company to unilaterally decide how they monetize their extra capacity, and its not unjustified to care. You are not purchasing the promise of X tokens with a subscription purchase for that you need api.
comments.content_cn: 由于您的订阅依赖于API业务本身。Anthropic的运营成本本质上是租赁或购买一定数量H100芯片的支出。在批次满载需要新集群之前，每个边际查询对他们而言成本几乎为零。因此，API集群通常按峰值负载建设，但任意时间点的实际利用率（满载批次）往往很低。鉴于AI需求峰值波动极大，最终API支持的利用率数据会处于低位。您的订阅正是为了利用这部分闲置容量。所以令牌成本并不高，您才负担得起。但这需要精细管理以避免系统过载。Claude代码遥测系统会将订阅请求识别为低于API的优先级（可能还涉及队列管理和缓存机制）。如果您的调用工具每次查询都发起10个并行请求，且上下文管理不如Claude代码高效，就会压垮系统并影响其他用户性能。倘若所有人都只想使用订阅服务而无人购买API，订阅价格终究难以持续。某种程度上，您正在依赖他人的慷慨获取低价服务。企业单方面决定如何将其闲置容量变现是合理的，他们对此表示关切也无可厚非。订阅购买并非承诺获得固定令牌额度——若需此类保障，您应当选择API服务。
