posts.title_cn: 比亚迪最便宜电动车将搭载激光雷达自动驾驶技术
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕比亚迪在低价电动车上搭载激光雷达自动驾驶技术展开。核心话题是激光雷达成本下降带来的普及可能性及其对汽车行业的影响。有人认为激光雷达价格已大幅降低，与依赖视觉方案的AI系统相比能免费获取深度信息，理想情况下应结合使用。也有用户指出特斯拉因早期激光雷达昂贵而回避该技术，如今成本下降可能使其策略显得短视。讨论中提到车顶安装激光雷达虽实用但可能影响外观，部分用户担忧激光辐射安全问题。对于比亚迪低价策略，有观点认为中国产品更注重规模化与功能而非过度设计，对比美国车企的高成本模式形成冲击。用户普遍认同激光雷达的性价比提升将改变行业格局，但在技术路线选择（纯视觉vs多传感器融合）和设计优先级上存在分歧。

激光雷达价格下降了约40倍。

posts.title: Show HN: I used Claude Code to discover connections between 100 books
posts.content:
I think LLMs are overused to summarise and underused to help us read deeper.I built a system for Claude Code to browse 100 non-fiction books and find interesting connections between them.I started out with a pipeline in stages, chaining together LLM calls to build up a context of the library. 
I was mainly getting back the insight that I was baking into the prompts, and the results weren't particularly surprising.On a whim, I gave CC access to my debug CLI tools and found that it wiped the floor with that approach. 
It gave actually interesting results and required very little orchestration in comparison.One of my favourite trail of excerpts goes from Jobs’ reality distortion field to Theranos’ fake demos, to Thiel on startup cults, to Hoffer on mass movement charlatans (https://trails.pieterma.es/trail/useful-lies/).
A fun tendency is that Claude kept getting distracted by topics of secrecy, conspiracy, and hidden systems - as if the task itself summoned a Foucault’s Pendulum mindset.Details:* The books are picked from HN’s favourites (which I collected before: https://hnbooks.pieterma.es/).* Chunks are indexed by topic using Gemini Flash Lite. The whole library cost about £10.* Topics are organised into a tree structure using recursive Leiden partitioning and LLM labels. This gives a high-level sense of the themes.* There are several ways to browse. The most useful are embedding similarity, topic tree siblings, and topics cooccurring within a chunk window.* Everything is stored in SQLite and manipulated using a set of CLI tools.I wrote more about the process here: https://pieterma.es/syntopic-reading-claude/I’m curious if this way of reading resonates for anyone else - LLM-mediated or not.

posts.title_cn: "Show HN：我用Claude Code发现了100本书之间的联系"
posts.content_cn:
我认为大型语言模型在总结方面被过度使用，而在帮助我们深度阅读方面却未得到充分利用。我构建了一个系统，让Claude Code能够浏览100本非虚构书籍，并找出它们之间有趣的联系。起初，我采用分阶段的流程，通过串联多个LLM调用来构建图书馆的上下文。  
但主要得到的见解只是我预先设计在提示中的内容，结果并不特别令人惊讶。一时兴起，我让Claude Code访问了我的调试命令行工具，结果发现它完全超越了之前的方法。  
相比之下，它给出了真正有趣的结果，且几乎不需要复杂的编排。我最喜欢的一条摘录线索从乔布斯的现实扭曲力场，到Theranos的虚假演示，再到蒂尔关于创业公司崇拜的论述，最后到霍弗关于群众运动中的江湖骗子的分析（https://trails.pieterma.es/trail/useful-lies/）。  
一个有趣的趋势是，Claude不断被秘密、阴谋和隐藏系统等话题分散注意力——仿佛任务本身召唤出了《傅科摆》式的心态……
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论用户利用Claude Code分析百本非虚构书籍并寻找关联性的项目。核心话题是探索大语言模型在深度阅读与跨文本关联分析中的应用潜力，而非仅用于浅层摘要。

社区观点呈现明显分歧。支持者认为该项目极具创意，体现了艺术洞察力与语言想象力，有用户称赞其突破传统工程思维。但也有用户指出关联性薄弱，认为模型常从海量文本中孤立提取段落并过度解读主题，甚至部分视觉化连接纯属风格化设计，缺乏实质关联。讨论中提到，部分用户通过类似技术（如文本嵌入与向量检索）处理个人藏书，但对其实际效果持保留态度。

共识在于肯定探索方向的价值，普遍认同大语言模型在人文计算领域具有潜力。但对其当前实现效果存在对立看法：一方认为关联分析具有启发性，能激发跨书灵感；另一方则质疑方法严谨性，认为结果牵强且未能捕捉真正深层的主题线索。

comments.author: johnwatson11218
comments.content: I did something similar whereby I used pdfplumber to extract text from my pdf book collection. I dumped it into postgresql, then chunked the text into 100 char chunks w/ a 10 char overlap. These chunks were directly embedded into a 384D space using python sentence_transformers. Then I simply averaged all chunks for a doc and wrote that single vector back to postgresql. Then I used UMAP + HDBScan to perform dimensionality reduction and clustering. I ended up with a 2D data set that I can plot with plotly to see my clusters. It is very cool to play with this. It takes hours to import 100 pdf files but I can take one folder that contains a mix of programming titles, self-help, math, science fiction etc. After the fully automated analysis you can clearly see the different topic clusters.I just spent time getting it all running on docker compose and moved my web ui from express js to flask. I want to get the code cleaned up and open source it at some point.
comments.content_cn: 我做过类似的事情，用pdfplumber从我的PDF书籍收藏中提取文本。将其导入PostgreSQL后，我把文本分割成100字符的片段，并设置10字符的重叠。这些片段通过python的sentence_transformers直接嵌入到384维空间中。接着我计算每个文档所有片段的向量平均值，将这个单一向量存回PostgreSQL。然后使用UMAP+HDBScan进行降维和聚类分析，最终得到可二维可视化的数据集，通过plotly绘制聚类图谱。这个过程非常有趣。虽然导入100个PDF文件需要数小时，但当我将包含编程教程、自助指南、数学著作、科幻小说等混合内容的文件夹进行分析后，全自动处理的结果能清晰展示不同主题的聚类。最近我花时间将整个系统部署在docker compose上，并把网页界面从Express.js迁移到Flask。希望将来能整理代码并开源这个项目。

comments.author: pxc
comments.content: I read a book maybe a decade ago on the "digital humanities". I wish now I could remember the title and author. :(Anyway, it introduced me to the idea of using computational methods in the humanities, including literature. I found it really interesting at the time!One of the the terms it introduced me to is "distant reading", whose name mirrors that of a technique you may have studied in your gen eds if you went to university ('close reading"). The idea is that rather than zooming in on some tiny piece of text to examine very subtle or nuanced meanings, you zoom out to hundreds or thousands of texts, using computers to search them for insights that only emerge from large bodies of work as wholes. The book argued that there are likely some questions that it is only feasible to ask this way.An old friend of mine used techniques like this for dissertation in rhetoric, learning enough Python along the way to write the code needed for the analyses she wanted to do. I thought it was pretty cool!I imagine LLMs are probably positioned now to push distant reading forward in an number of ways: enabling new techniques, allowing old techniques to be used without writing code, and helping novices get started with writing some code. (A lot of the maintainability issues that come with LLM code generation happily don't apply to research projects like this.)Anyway, if you're interested in other computational techniques you can use to enrich this kind of reading, you might enjoy looking into "distant reading": https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distant_reading
comments.content_cn:
大约十年前我读过一本关于"数字人文"的书。现在真希望还能记得书名和作者。无论如何，这本书让我初次接触到在人文学科（包括文学领域）运用计算方法的理念，当时觉得特别有意思！

书中让我认识的一个术语是"远读"，这个名称恰好对应大学通识课可能学过的"细读"方法。其核心理念在于：不是聚焦于文本片段来剖析精微含义，而是将视野拓展至成百上千的文本，借助计算机从海量作品整体中发掘仅通过宏观分析才能显现的规律。书中提出，有些研究问题或许只有通过这种方式才可能被探讨。

我的一位老友在修辞学论文中就运用了类似方法，为此还自学了Python来编写分析代码。我觉得这特别酷！

在我看来，大语言模型很可能从多个维度推动远读的发展：既能催生新技术，也能让旧方法免代码实现，还能帮助新手入门代码编写。（值得庆幸的是，大语言模型生成代码的许多可维护性问题在这类研究项目中并不构成障碍。）

总之，如果你对其他能丰富这种阅读方式的计算机技术感兴趣，或许可以了解一下"……

comments.author: johnwatson11218
comments.content:
Thanks for the supportive comments. I'm definitely thinking I should release sooner rather than later. I have been using LLM for specific tasks and here is some sample stored procedure I had an LLM write for me.--
-- Name: refresh_topic_tables(); Type: PROCEDURE; Schema: public; Owner: postgres
--CREATE PROCEDURE public.refresh_topic_tables()
    LANGUAGE plpgsql
    AS $$
BEGIN
    -- Drop tables in reverse dependency order
    DROP TABLE IF EXISTS topic_top_terms;
    DROP TABLE IF EXISTS topic_term_tfidf;
    DROP TABLE IF EXISTS term_df;
    DROP TABLE IF EXISTS term_tf;
    DROP TABLE IF EXISTS topic_terms;    -- Recreate tables in correct dependency order
    CREATE TABLE topic_terms AS
    SELECT
        dt.term_id,
        dot.topic_id,
        COUNT(DISTINCT dt.document_id) as document_count,
        SUM(frequency) as total_frequency
    FROM document_terms dt
    JOIN document_topics dot ON dt.document_id = dot.document_id
    GROUP BY dt.term_id, dot.topic_id;

    CREATE TABLE term_tf AS
    SELECT
        topic_id,
        term_id,
        SUM(total_frequency) as term_frequency
    FROM topic_terms
    GROUP BY topic_id, term_id;

    CREATE TABLE term_df AS
    SELECT
        term_id,
        COUNT(DISTINCT topic_id) as document_frequency
    FROM topic_terms
    GROUP BY term_id;

    CREATE TABLE topic_term_tfidf AS
    SELECT
        tt.topic_id,
        tt.term_id,
        tt.term_frequency as tf,
        tdf.document_frequency as df,
        tt.term_frequency * LN( (SELECT COUNT(id) FROM topics) / GREATEST(tdf.document_frequency, 1)) as tf_idf
    FROM term_tf tt
    JOIN term_df tdf ON tt.term_id = tdf.term_id;

    CREATE TABLE topic_top_terms AS
    WITH ranked_terms AS (
        SELECT
            ttf.topic_id,
            t.term_text,
            ttf.tf_idf,
            ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY ttf.topic_id ORDER BY ttf.tf_idf DESC) as rank
        FROM topic_term_tfidf ttf
        JOIN terms t ON ttf.term_id = t.id
    )
    SELECT
        topic_id,
        term_text,
        tf_idf,
        rank
    FROM ranked_terms
    WHERE rank <= 5
    ORDER BY topic_id, rank;

    RAISE NOTICE 'All topic tables refreshed successfully';
   
EXCEPTION
    WHEN OTHERS THEN
        RAISE EXCEPTION 'Error refreshing topic tables: %', SQLERRM;
END;
$$;

comments.author: urbandw311er
comments.content: This feels like a nice idea but the connection between the theme and the overarching arc of each book seems tenuous at best. In some cases it just seems to have found one paragraph from thousands and extrapolated a theme that doesn’t really thread through the greater piece.I do like the idea though — perhaps there is a way to refine the prompting to do a second pass or even multiple passes to iteratively extract themes before the linking step.
comments.content_cn: 这个想法听起来不错，但每本书的主题与整体主线之间的关联似乎有些牵强。在某些情况下，它似乎只是从成千上万的段落中找出一段，然后推导出一个并未真正贯穿全文的主题。不过，我确实喜欢这个思路——或许可以通过优化提示方式，在建立关联之前进行二次甚至多次迭代，逐步提炼出主题。

comments.author: bonkusbingus
comments.content:
"There are, you see, two ways of reading a book: you either see it as a box with something inside and start looking for what it signifies, and then if you're even more perverse or depraved you set off after signifiers. And you treat the next book like a box contained in the first or containing it. And you annotate and interpret and question, and write a book about the book, and so on and on. Or there's the other way: you see the book as a little non-signifying machine, and the only question is "Does it work, and how does it work?" How does it work for you? If it doesn't work, if nothing comes through, you try another book. This second way of reading's intensive: something comes through or it doesn't. There's nothing to explain, nothing to understand, nothing to interpret."
— Gilles Deleuze
comments.content_cn:
你看，读书有两种方式：要么把它看作一个装着东西的盒子，开始寻找它意味着什么，然后如果你更加反常或堕落，就会追逐能指。你把下一本书当作包含在第一本书里或被第一本书包含的盒子。你注释、解释、提问，写一本关于这本书的书，如此循环往复。或者还有另一种方式：你把书看作一台不意指的小机器，唯一的问题是“它运作吗？如何运作？”它对你如何起作用？如果它不运作，如果没有任何东西传达出来，你就换另一本书。这第二种阅读方式是强度性的：要么有东西传达出来，要么没有。没有什么需要解释，没有什么需要理解，没有什么需要诠释。
——吉尔·德勒兹

作为斯坦福文学实验室的创始人，莫雷蒂是该理念的主要倡导者：我们不应仅通过细读个别经典文本来分析文学，而应对数百甚至数千部作品进行大规模计算分析——观察体裁演变趋势、情节结构、标题长度等仅在大规模研究中显现的模式。

comments.author: samuelknight
comments.content:
I do this all the time in my Claude code workflow:
- Claude will stumble a few times before figuring out how to do part of a complex task
- I will ask it to explain what it was trying to do, how it eventually solved it, and what was missing from its environment.
- Trivial pointers go into the CLAUDE.md. Complex tasks go into a new project skill or a helper scriptThis is the best way to re-enforce a copilot because models are pretty smart most of the time and I can correct the cases where it stumbles with minimal cognitive effort. Over time I find more and more tasks are solved by agent intelligence or these happy path hints. As primitive as it is, CLAUDE.md is the best we have for long-term adaptive memory.

在我的Claude代码工作流中，我经常这样做：
- Claude在处理复杂任务的部分环节时，通常会尝试几次才能找到解决方法
- 我会要求它解释原本的意图、最终解决方案以及环境配置中缺失的部分
- 简单的提示会记录在CLAUDE.md文件中，复杂任务则创建新的项目技能或辅助脚本
这是强化智能助手的最佳方式，因为模型在大多数情况下相当聪明，我只需花费最小认知成本就能修正它的失误。随着时间的推移，我发现越来越多任务可以通过智能代理或这些优化提示来解决。尽管CLAUDE.md形式原始，但确实是我们目前实现长期自适应记忆的最佳工具。

posts.title: Finding and fixing Ghostty's largest memory leak
posts.author: thorel
posts.title_cn: 发现并修复Ghostty的最大内存泄漏问题
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Ghostty终端模拟器内存泄漏问题的发现与修复展开。核心话题是开发者通过博客详细分析了导致内存泄漏的代码缺陷及其解决方案，即未能正确释放非标准页面内存。社区普遍赞赏技术分析的深度与价值，认为这类故障复盘对开发者很有帮助。

多数用户对修复表示肯定，有用户分享自己曾遭遇进程占用40GB内存的崩溃经历，庆幸问题得到解决。同时，讨论中提到一些技术性质疑：有用户指出修复方案可能非必要地删除并重建非标准页面，存在优化空间；也有用户对修复被安排到数月后的功能版本而非紧急缺陷修复中表示意外。

关于问题根源，有人认为Claude Code的使用让更多用户触发了该缺陷，但本质是代码自身问题。讨论中虽出现“若选用Rust语言或可避免”的调侃，但未形成主流争议。整体上，社区肯定开发团队的响应与技术透明度，同时就具体实现细节提出了不同见解。

Maybe the assumption about what makes a page non-standard, isn't as black-and-white as presumed.  And I wonder if the leak would have been triggered more often for people who use scrollback-limit = 0, or something very small.Probably not a huge deal, but it does seem the fix will needlessly delete and recreate non-standard pages in the case where the new page needs to be non-standard, and the oldest one (that needs to be pruned) already is non-standard and could be reused.

虽然Claude Code可能是导致更多人触发这个bug的原因，但我们中有些人从未使用过Claude Code也遇到了这个问题。也许关于什么使页面成为非标准页面的假设，并不像我们以为的那样非黑即白。我在想，对于那些将滚动回退限制设置为0或很小数值的用户，这个内存泄漏是否会更频繁地触发。

可能问题不算严重，但看起来这个修复方案存在一个情况：当新页面需要是非标准页面，而最旧的待清理页面已经是非标准页面且本可重复利用时，系统会不必要地删除并重新创建非标准页面。

正如我在博客文章中提到，确实存在其他解决方案（例如您建议的方案），但我们缺乏足够的实证数据来支持改变现有观点，而当前观点（标准尺寸更常见）已得到已知基准测试的有力支持。我愿意重新考虑这个问题，但我不希望在一次改动中同时修正漏洞并颠覆现有认知体系。

comments.content: Edit: I'm getting a lot of down votes for this but nobody is saying why I'm wrong. If you think I'm wrong enough to down vote, please reply why.I don't understand why that is the preferred fix. I would have solved it other ways:1. When resizing the page, leave some flag of how it was allocated. This tagging is commonly done as the always 0 bits in size or address fields to save space.2. If you want to realloc, go for it, and have the memory manager handle that boundary for you.Both of those not only maintain functionality which seems to have been lost with the feature reduction but also are more future proof to any other changes in size.
comments.content_cn:
编辑：我因此收到了很多反对票，但没有人说明我错在哪里。如果你认为我错到值得反对，请回复解释原因。我不明白为什么这是首选的解决方案。我本会用其他方式处理：

1. 调整页面大小时，保留其分配方式的某种标记。这种标记通常通过大小或地址字段中始终为0的位来实现以节省空间。
2. 由于内存池是已知大小的连续内存区域，检查待释放内存是否在该范围内
3. 保持大小不可变。如需重新分配，直接操作即可，让内存管理器为你处理边界问题。

这些方法不仅能保留因功能缩减而似乎丢失的特性，还能更好地适应未来可能出现的其他大小变更。

comments.content: This feels like a case of guessing at something you could know. There are two types of allocations that each have a size and free method. The free method is polymorphic over the allocations type. Instead of using a tag to know absolutely which type an object it is you guess based on some other factor, in this case a size invariant which was violated. It also doesn't seem like this invariant was ever codified otherwise the first time a large alloc was modified to a standard size it would've blown up. It's worth asking yourself if your distinguishing factor is the best you can use or perhaps there is a better test. Maybe in this case a tag would've been too expensive.

comments.author: tialaramex
comments.content: The specific language feature you want if you insist that you don't want this kind of leak is Linear Types.Rust has Affine Types. This means Rust cares that for any value V of type T, Rust can see that we did not destroy V twice (or more often).With Linear Types the compiler checks that you destroyed V exactly once, not less and not more.However, one reason I don't end up caring about Leak Safety of this sort is that in fact users do not care that you didn't "leak" data in this nerd sense. In this nerd sense what matters is only leaks where we lost all reference to the heap data. But from a user's perspective it's just as bad if we did have the reference but we forgot - or even decided explicitly not - to throw it away and get back the RAM.The obvious way to make this mistake "by accident" in Rust is to have two things which keep each other alive via reference counting and yet have been disconnected and forgotten by the rest of the system. A typical garbage collected language would notice that these are garbage and destroy them both, but Rust isn't a GC language of course. Calling Box::leak isn't likely to happen by accident (though you might mistakenly believe you will call it only once but actually use it much more often)I think the main part of Ghostty's design mentioned here that - as a Rust programmer - I think is probably a mistake is the choice to use a linked list. To me this looks exactly like it needs VecDeque, a circular buffer backed by a growable array type. Their "clever" typical case where you emit more text and so your oldest page is scrapped and re-used to form your newest page, works very nicely in VecDeque, and it seems like they never want the esoteric fast things a linked list can do, nor do they need multi-writer concurrency like the guts of an OS kernel, they want O(1) pop & push from opposite ends. Zig's Deque is probably that same thing but in Zig.
comments.content_cn:
如果你坚持不希望出现这类内存泄漏，所需的具体语言特性是线性类型。Rust拥有仿射类型。这意味着Rust会确保对于类型T的任意值V，编译器能检测到我们没有重复销毁V（或多次销毁）。而线性类型要求编译器严格检查你是否恰好销毁V一次——既不能少也不能多。

不过，我最终不太在意这类内存泄漏安全性的一个原因是：实际上用户并不关心这种技术层面上的“泄漏”。在技术语境中，只有当我们彻底丢失堆数据的所有引用时才算真正的泄漏。但从用户视角看，即使我们持有引用却忘记释放——甚至主动决定不释放内存——其结果同样糟糕。

在Rust中“意外”犯这类错误的典型情况是：两个对象通过引用计数相互保持存活，却已被系统其他部分断开连接并遗忘。典型的垃圾回收语言会识别出这些垃圾并销毁它们，但Rust当然不是GC语言。虽然意外调用Box::leak的可能性不大（尽管可能误以为只调用一次实际却频繁使用），但确实存在风险。

我认为Ghostty设计中值得商榷的部分——以Rust程序员视角来看——是选择使用链表结构。这看起来完全适合使用VecDeque（基于可扩容数组类型的循环缓冲区）。他们……

comments.content: Thank you. I think each of my options are pretty trivial in C. I guess what I'm not understanding for #3 is if size is immutable, how the size changed which caused the issue? The post said they changed the size of the page without changing the underlying size of the allocated memory. To me this is the big issue. There was a desync in information where the underlying assumption is that size tells you where the data came from and that the size of the metadata and the size of the allocation move in tandem across that boundary.#1 and #2 are fixes for breaking that implicit trust. #1 still trusts the metadata, #2 is what I'd consider the most robust solution is that not only is it ideally trivial (just compare if a pointer is within a range, assuming zig can do that) but it doesn't rely on metadata being correct. #3 prevents the desync.I really don't understand the code base enough to say definitively that my ways work, which is I guess what I'm really looking for feedback on. Looking at the memorypool, I think you're right that my assumption of it being a simple contiguous array was incorrect.ETA: I think I'm actually very wrong for #2. Color me surprised that the zig memory pool allocated each item separately instead of as one big block. Feels like a waste, but I'm sure they have their reasons. That's addCapacity in memory_pool.zig
comments.content_cn:
谢谢。我认为在C语言中我的每个方案都相当简单。对于第3点我不太理解的是：如果尺寸不可变，那导致问题的尺寸变化是如何发生的？帖子提到他们改变了页面尺寸却没有调整底层分配内存的大小。在我看来这才是核心问题——信息出现了不同步，原本的隐含前提是尺寸能说明数据来源，且元数据大小与分配内存大小在边界处是同步变化的。

方案1和方案2正是为了解决这种隐含信任被破坏的问题。方案1仍然信任元数据，而方案2我认为是最稳健的解决方案：它不仅理论上很简单（只需判断指针是否在某个范围内，假设Zig能实现这个操作），而且不依赖元数据的正确性。方案3则是直接预防这种不同步现象。

我确实对代码库了解不够深入，无法断言我的方法一定有效，这也正是我希望获得反馈的地方。看了内存池的实现后，我觉得您说得对，我原先认为它是简单连续数组的假设是错误的。

补充：现在我觉得方案2可能完全错了。令我惊讶的是Zig内存池竟然为每个项目单独分配内存，而不是作为一个大块来分配。这似乎有点浪费，但他们肯定有自己的考量。这指的是memory_pool.zig中的addCapacity函数。

posts.title_cn: 毒化喷泉
posts.content_cn:
https://www.theregister.com/2026/01/11/industry_insiders_see...
https://www.anthropic.com/research/small-samples-poison
少量样本即可毒害任何规模的大型语言模型 - https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45529587 - 2025年10月（439条评论）
posts.abstract: 该HackerNews帖子围绕“毒药喷泉”这一概念展开讨论，核心话题是少量恶意样本能否污染大型语言模型的训练数据，以及“模型崩溃”是否构成现实威胁。讨论中提到，有用户认为模型崩溃被过度炒作，前沿实验室通过严格的数据筛选和后期强化学习已有效应对此问题，且当前大模型性能提升主要依赖训练后优化而非单纯扩大预训练数据。也有用户指出，公开“毒药”数据可能迫使研究者开发更先进的数据净化技术，反而推动AI发展。分歧点在于对数据污染风险的实际评估：一方认为主流实验室通过精细的数据策展和代理模型测试已能防范污染；另一方则担忧模型若持续使用合成数据或未经净化的网络数据，可能陷入错误放大的恶性循环。此外，有用户质疑相关报道的时效性，认为其未能反映当前业界的实际应对能力。讨论中普遍认同的是，数据质量管理和过滤技术对模型健康发展至关重要。

posts.title: NASA announces unprecedented return of sick ISS astronaut and crew
posts.author: bookofjoe
posts.title_cn: NASA宣布患病国际空间站宇航员及机组人员史无前例提前返回
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕NASA紧急从国际空间站接回患病宇航员的事件展开。核心话题涉及太空环境下的医疗风险与宇航员心理素质。多数用户认同太空医疗问题的严重性，有人指出在遥远太空遭遇肾结石或阑尾破裂等急症极为可怕，但也有用户强调宇航员经过严格选拔和训练，通常具备超常的冷静特质，例如部分人曾有特种部队背景。

讨论中提到，目前尚无人在太空中因疾病死亡，仅有的太空死亡案例源于事故。关于长期隔离对健康的影响，有用户好奇隔离环境是否会消除传染病，但随即有观点反驳称这可能导致免疫系统脆弱，一旦接触病毒后果更严重。此外，用户们提及太空中的传染病传播案例有限，如阿波罗任务中曾出现感冒在机组中传播，但本次事件因宇航员已隔离数月，传播风险较低。整体上，社区既关注太空医疗的挑战，也认可宇航员群体的专业性与抗压能力。

comments.author: heyflyguy
comments.content: It's great we can bring them down. What a terrifying experience to have a medical issue on the space station. Kidney stone? Ruptured appendix? intestinal blockage? How could you keep calm so far away!
comments.content_cn: 能把他们带回来真是太好了。在空间站上出现医疗问题是多么可怕的经历啊。肾结石？阑尾破裂？肠梗阻？在那么远的地方怎么能保持冷静！

comments.author: wmf
comments.content: How could you keep calm so far awayBy going through a ten-year process that selects for calm people.
comments.content_cn:
你如何能在如此遥远的地方保持平静
通过一个长达十年的过程，筛选出平静的人。

comments.author: lostmsu
comments.content: AFAIK no one have died in space from medical issues yet. Only accidents.
comments.content_cn: 据我所知，目前还没有人因医疗问题在太空中死亡，只有事故导致的伤亡。

comments.author: londons_explore
comments.content: The ISS is a good example of a fully isolated environment.    No new bacteria or viruses arrive there apart from spacecraft arrivals.I've been curious for a while what human health would look like if there was a small group of people isolated for many decades.   Would they effectively be disease free after the first few weeks?As well as removing flu and colds, might it also reduce things like heart disease and Alzheimer's which we have weak evidence are linked to transmissible diseases?
comments.content_cn: 国际空间站是一个完全隔离环境的绝佳范例。除了航天器抵达外，不会有新的细菌或病毒进入那里。我一直在好奇，如果一小群人被隔离几十年，人类的健康状况会是什么样子。在最初的几周后，他们是否会基本上不再患病？除了消除流感和感冒，这是否也可能减少心脏病和阿尔茨海默病等疾病？我们有微弱的证据表明这些疾病与传染病有关。

comments.author: Buttons840
comments.content: Related question. Have transmittable diseases spread in space? What examples do we know of?
comments.content_cn: 相关问题。传染性疾病是否曾在太空中传播？我们已知有哪些例子？

comments.author: ACS_Solver
comments.content: Technically there has only been one fatal accident in space, the Soyuz 11 failure which killed the crew of three. That occurred above the Karman line, all other spaceflight related fatalities were at much lower altitudes or on the ground.
comments.content_cn: 从技术上讲，太空中仅发生过一起致命事故，即导致三名宇航员遇难的联盟11号故障。该事故发生在卡门线以上，其他所有与航天相关的死亡事件都发生在更低的高度或地面。

comments.author: almost_usual
comments.content: I can’t imagine any other group who would be as calm as NASA astronauts. Maybe SEALs or other special forces.It looks like there are a few astronauts that were SEALs, one returned December 9th from the ISS.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonny_Kim
comments.content_cn: 我实在想不出还有哪个群体能像NASA宇航员那样镇定自若。或许海豹突击队或其他特种部队可以一比。看起来确实有一些宇航员曾服役于海豹突击队，其中一位已于12月9日从国际空间站返回。

comments.author: CableNinja
comments.content: The downside to doing that is that their immune system would be weak in the end. We survive cold and flu because we have had them before, but someone going many years without the yearly viruses would get hit 100x harder, even potentially dying.
comments.content_cn: 这样做的弊端在于，他们的免疫系统最终会变得脆弱。我们之所以能挺过感冒和流感，是因为我们以前经历过这些疾病，但如果有人多年不接触这些年度病毒，一旦感染就会遭受百倍严重的打击，甚至可能致命。

comments.author: geor9e
comments.content: Article about how the return capsule works: https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-52840482
comments.content_cn: 关于返回舱工作原理的文章：https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-52840482

comments.author: Klathmon
comments.content: There have been a few instances, IIRC there was an Apollo mission that had a head cold spread among the whole crew.But that's unlikely to be the case here because they've been up there isolated for over 6 months now
comments.content_cn: 我记得有过几次先例，比如有一次阿波罗任务中，感冒就在全体机组成员间传播开来。但这次情况不太可能如此，因为他们已经在上面隔离了超过六个月。

comments.author: nubg
comments.content: Why be so secretive? This is not a military mission. These missions cost a lot of taxpayer money (money well spend you may argue), but we deserve full transparency. You don't get to go to space on other people's money and expect privacy. We might want to learn from what went wrong here.
comments.content_cn: 为何如此神秘？这又不是军事任务。这些任务花费了大量纳税人的钱（你可能会说这钱花得值），但我们理应享有完全的透明度。你不能用别人的钱上太空还指望保有隐私。我们或许应该从这次的问题中吸取教训。

comments.author: AIorNot
comments.content: I used to work in ISS mission control, this is not an emergency return but an early returnAlso coming down on the Soyuz is pretty routine and only takes a few hours- I’d say it was overall a far less risky situation than being in Antarctic on a deep ocean vessel with appendicitis etcWe have dozens and (hundreds behind them) of men and women monitoring those folks from a global network of control centers 24 hrs a day- The station is mostly commanded from the ground and plans and procedures exist for everything- if anything its all over orchestrated and over-planned in my opinion, owing to national politics, corporate contracts and international bureaucracyIs it risky- yes obviously-but I’d argue its less risky then being out at the south pole in winterSee: https://nasawatch.com/iss-news/crew-medical-telecon-summary/
comments.content_cn: 我曾在国际空间站任务控制中心工作，这并非紧急返回而是提前返回。此外，乘坐联盟号返回是相当常规的操作，仅需数小时——我认为总体而言，这比在南极洲的深海船只上突发阑尾炎等情况的风险要低得多。我们有一个全球控制中心网络，每天24小时有数十名（背后还有数百名）工作人员监控着宇航员——空间站主要受地面指挥，且针对所有情况都有详尽的计划和流程。在我看来，由于国家政治、企业合同和国际官僚体系的影响，整个流程甚至有些过度编排和过度规划了。是否存在风险？显然是的——但我认为这比冬季身处南极的风险更低。详见：https://nasawatch.com/iss-news/crew-medical-telecon-summary/

comments.author: HardwareLust
comments.content: Did NASA say when they're coming back? The article didn't mention it.Should also mention NASA is trying to move up the launch of Crew 12 to cover some of the gap.
comments.content_cn: 美国宇航局有没有说他们什么时候回来？文章没提这点。还应该提到美国宇航局正试图提前发射第12号乘组以填补部分空缺。

comments.author: echoangle
comments.content: The other one that comes close is Columbia which broke up at around 60 km.
comments.content_cn: 另一个相近的例子是哥伦比亚号，它在约60公里高空解体。

comments.author: manuelmoreale
comments.content: Somewhat related to this topic: https://youtube.com/watch?v=Zo62S0ulqhA
comments.content_cn: 与此话题有一定关联：https://youtube.com/watch?v=Zo62S0ulqhA

comments.author: brycewray
comments.content: > IIRC there was an Apollo mission that had a head cold spread among the whole crew.Yep, Apollo 7.
comments.content_cn: 如果我没记错的话，有一次阿波罗任务中，感冒在全体机组成员间传播开了。是的，就是阿波罗7号。

comments.author: NooneAtAll3
comments.content: whatever is the cause, it is not immediate - or they would've been on the ground couple days agoso no, not appendix
comments.content_cn: 无论原因是什么，都不是急性的——否则他们几天前就该倒下了。所以不，不是阑尾炎。

comments.author: vpribish
comments.content: it's only 250 miles
comments.content_cn: 只有250英里

comments.author: daeken
comments.content: The astronaut in question may choose to disclose that they had the medical emergency and possibly its nature, but it seems wholly reasonable to not single them out (when it affects the whole mission) or disclose their medical status.
comments.content_cn: 相关宇航员可以选择公开自己曾出现医疗紧急状况及其性质，但在事件影响整个任务的情况下，不单独点名或披露其医疗状况的做法似乎完全合理。

comments.author: SJC_Hacker
comments.content: Astronauts are of a breed apart.  They're strapped onto a literally bomb which launches them into a vacuum, and windows where there is no chance of a mission abort.  They've pretty much accepted a risk of death that most would simply not tolerate. Ex-military is common for astronauts for a reason.
comments.content_cn: 宇航员是独特的一类人。他们被绑在名副其实的炸弹上发射进入真空，面对的是毫无任务中止可能的窗口期。他们坦然接受了大多数人根本无法容忍的死亡风险。宇航员中常见退役军人，这并非没有原因。

comments.author: trebligdivad
comments.content: or on the way to Mars.
comments.content_cn: 或者在前往火星的途中。

comments.author: perihelions
comments.content: This describes NASA's pre-flight quarantines since Apollo 14, and makes (very brief) references to in-flight diseases (and apparent transmission) prior to Apollo 14 ("upper respiratory infection"; "viral gastroenteritis"),https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/ochmo-tb-006... ("Health Stabilization Program (HSP)")
comments.content_cn: 这描述了自阿波罗14号以来美国宇航局的飞行前隔离措施，并简要提及了阿波罗14号之前飞行中出现的疾病（及明显传播情况）（"上呼吸道感染"；"病毒性胃肠炎"），https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/ochmo-tb-006...（"健康稳定计划（HSP）"）

comments.author: NetMageSCW
comments.content: Then why did you mention Soyuz when Dragon is coming down early?
comments.content_cn: 那为什么在龙飞船提前返回时你要提到联盟号？

comments.author: Zealotux
comments.content: Would it be possible for some food to have been contaminated with something? It seems unlikely.
comments.content_cn: 是否有可能某些食物被什么东西污染了？这似乎不太可能。

comments.author: perihelions
comments.content: Without taking a side, I'll share the interesting detail that NASA did not historically grant much medical privacy to astronauts. You can read medical reports of the Apollo-Soyuz crew here (documenting their poisoning by toxic rocket fuel, dinitrogen tetroxide),https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/19770023791 ("The Apollo-Soyuz Test Project: Medical report" (1977))
comments.content_cn: 不站任何立场，我只分享一个有趣的细节：美国宇航局历史上并未给予宇航员太多医疗隐私。你可以在这里阅读阿波罗-联盟号机组人员的医疗报告（记录了他们在有毒火箭燃料四氧化二氮中的中毒情况），https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/19770023791（《阿波罗-联盟号测试计划：医疗报告》（1977年））

comments.author: ssl-3
comments.content: These are free people (who happen to have a job that involves a space program).  They have the same rights to [try to] keep their medical concerns private as you and I do.It does cost a lot of money to keep their jobs going, but:  They're not slaves.  We do not own these people.
comments.content_cn: 这些是自由的人（恰巧从事与航天项目相关的工作）。他们和你我一样，有权[尝试]保护自己的医疗隐私。维持他们的工作确实耗费大量资金，但：他们不是奴隶。我们并不拥有这些人。

comments.author: bryant
comments.content: > Why be so secretive? This is not a military mission. These missions cost a lot of taxpayer money (money well spend you may argue), but we deserve full transparency.We deserve as much transparency as we can get on the science we as taxpayers paid for, not full de-anonymization of the bodily happenings of living crew. There's certainly valuable science here, but the crew member doesn't have to be outed for it.> You don't get to go to space on other people's money and expect privacy.I don't think this is a healthy mindset, and there's a heck of a slippery slope with this argument. Would we apply this to companies receiving federal grants too? Contractors? Universities? Schools? That's a lot of people who'll lose medical privacy for something probably unrelated to their job, and there'll be a much smaller applicant pool for the jobs themselves if applicants are aware that their own internal issues might be disclosed when the public clamors for it.> We might want to learn from what went wrong here.Agree, NASA certainly will, and new science and engineering will come of it that we benefit from. But that doesn't have to involve breaching medical privacy and ethics.
comments.content_cn:
为何要如此保密？这又不是军事任务。这些任务花费了大量纳税人的钱（你可能会说这钱花得值），但我们理应获得完全的透明度。我们作为纳税人资助的科学项目应当尽可能公开透明，但并非要完全公开宇航员的身体隐私。这里确实有宝贵的科学价值，但不必为此曝光宇航员的个人隐私。

你不能用别人的钱上太空还指望保有隐私。我认为这种心态并不健康，这种论调极易导致滑坡效应。难道我们也要这样对待获得联邦资助的公司吗？承包商呢？大学呢？中小学呢？这将导致许多人因可能与工作无关的事失去医疗隐私，而且如果申请者知道公众一旦要求就可能披露他们的个人健康问题，这些职位本身的申请者数量就会大幅减少。

我们或许应该从这次事故中吸取教训。同意，NASA肯定会这样做，并会由此产生新的科学和工程成果让我们受益。但这并不需要以侵犯医疗隐私和伦理为代价。

comments.author: Aurornis
comments.content: What difference would this make to you? It would unnecessarily violate someone’s medical privacy for no actual benefit to the public other than satisfying someone’s curiosity.> You don't get to go to space on other people's money and expect privacy.Yes, everyone gets privacy. You don’t get to see their private communications back home. You don’t get their medical records.They aren’t receiving money from taxpayers like a gift. They’re doing a job. It’s ridiculous to demand that they forfeit their privacy because tax money was involved.> We might want to learn from what went wrong here.NASA will learn what went wrong here because they’re in a position to act onYou are not in a position to do anything about it. Violating their privacy would make no difference.
comments.content_cn: 这对你有什么影响？这只会不必要地侵犯他人的医疗隐私，除了满足某些人的好奇心外，对公众没有任何实际好处。> 你不能用别人的钱去太空还指望有隐私。是的，每个人都有隐私权。你不能查看他们与家人的私人通讯，也不能获取他们的医疗记录。他们不是像接受礼物一样从纳税人那里拿钱，他们是在工作。仅仅因为涉及税款就要求他们放弃隐私是荒谬的。> 我们或许想从这次事故中吸取教训。NASA会从这次事故中吸取教训，因为他们有能力采取行动。你对此无能为力。侵犯他们的隐私不会有任何改变。

comments.author: dfcab
comments.content: All I know is that SpaceX said dragon and crew-11 would undock no earlier than Wednesday, Jan 14.
comments.content_cn: 我只知道SpaceX表示龙飞船和Crew-11号机组不早于1月14日星期三脱离对接。

comments.author: okdood64
comments.content: Disagree; this is completely taxpayer funded and we deserve to know every detail relevant to mission status. In this scenario knowing what illness and why it's grounds for a return is very relevant. That said, I can see NASA delaying information release to figure out a good strategy for it while still respecting any wishes of the sick astronaut with regards to disclosure.
comments.content_cn: 不同意；这完全由纳税人资助，我们有权了解与任务状态相关的所有细节。在这种情况下，了解具体疾病及其成为返航理由的原因至关重要。话虽如此，我能理解NASA可能会推迟信息发布，以便在尊重患病宇航员关于信息披露意愿的同时，制定合适的应对策略。

comments.author: xeonmc
comments.content: Maybe testicular torsion triggered by zero-G conditions?
comments.content_cn: 或许是零重力环境引发的睾丸扭转？

comments.author: mapmeld
comments.content: Especially since every movement up and down from space is expensive and risks the life of the crew, it'd be a bad idea for NASA to name the astronaut ahead of time.
comments.content_cn: 特别是考虑到每次从太空往返都代价高昂且危及宇航员生命，美国宇航局提前公布宇航员名单将是个糟糕的主意。

comments.author: CheeseFromLidl
comments.content: This is the reason I cringe every time I hear or read statements like “we went to the moon”, “we’ve split the atom”, “we developed antibiotics”, …No, we didn’t. A few who are not like us did.
comments.content_cn: 这就是为什么每次听到或读到“我们登上了月球”、“我们分裂了原子”、“我们发明了抗生素”这类说法时，我都会感到尴尬不已。不，我们并没有做到。是少数与我们不同的人做到了。

comments.author: eps
comments.content: There was one cosmonaut who died shortly after emergency return to the Earth. I think it was in the 90s, but maybe eariler.
comments.content_cn: 曾有一位宇航员在紧急返回地球后不久去世。我记得是在90年代，但也可能更早。

comments.author: daemonologist
comments.content: Current schedule is departure Wednesday, splashdown Thursday morning: https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/commercialcrew/2026/01/09/nasa-sp...Reentry should be visible from large parts of the west coast (if they stick to this schedule).
comments.content_cn: 当前计划是周三出发，周四上午溅落：https://www.nasa.gov/blogs/commercialcrew/2026/01/09/nasa-sp...再入过程从西海岸大部分地区应可见（如果他们遵循此计划）。

comments.author: 2OEH8eoCRo0
comments.content: Pregnancy?
comments.content_cn: 怀孕了？

comments.author: zitterbewegung
comments.content: Maximum operating depth of a Nuclear submarine is 3,350 ft.
comments.content_cn: 核潜艇的最大下潜深度为3350英尺。

comments.author: gpm
comments.content: Not that it really changes the point but modern spacecraft do have an option to abort (begin returning to earth) at just about any time. There's still contingencies where that won't save you of course.
comments.content_cn: 虽然这并不改变核心观点，但现代航天器确实具备在几乎任何时刻中止任务（开始返回地球）的能力。当然，仍存在某些意外情况，即使启动中止程序也无法确保安全。

comments.author: bryant
comments.content: Since this is a special publication and since it was published in 1977 (after the Privacy Act of 1974), I'm wondering if NASA's condition for astronauts on this mission was to release mission-related medical science to the public.Speculating:If this is a condition of employment as an astronaut, then it probably wouldn't include conditions confirmed not to be caused by being in space, which means this'll stay confidential until NASA has fully diagnosed the crew member and figured out what likely happened.And if it turns out the crew member's issue was entirely unrelated to the mission, it stays under wraps but new science or procedures are devised to better manage this and related conditions in space.
comments.content_cn: 鉴于这是一份特殊出版物，且发布于1977年（即1974年《隐私法案》颁布之后），我不禁猜想，美国国家航空航天局是否将公开与任务相关的医学研究作为此次宇航员执行任务的前提条件。推测如下：若这确实是担任宇航员的聘用条件之一，那么其中很可能不包括那些已确认与太空环境无关的健康状况——这意味着相关信息将一直保密，直到航天局完成对机组人员的全面诊断并明确可能的原因。而如果最终证实该机组人员的问题与任务完全无关，相关细节仍将不予公开，但航天局会据此制定新的科学方案或操作流程，以更好地应对太空环境中的此类及相关健康状况。

comments.author: ryanmcgarvey
comments.content: The full on dystopian take would be to require anyone receiving welfare or other public funds to fully disclose all of their private details.You want Medicaid? Tell everyone about your hemorrhoids first.
comments.content_cn: 彻底的反乌托邦做法是要求任何领取福利或其他公共资金的人完全公开所有私人细节。想要医疗补助？先告诉所有人你的痔疮情况。

comments.author: bookofjoe
comments.content: >NASA has said it will announce a target return date in the coming days.
comments.content_cn: 美国国家航空航天局表示将在未来几天公布目标返回日期。

comments.author: TitaRusell
comments.content: I remember watching a landing and the camera cut away when one of the returning astronauts got sick.These are human beings and employees not Big Brother contestants.
comments.content_cn: 我记得有一次观看着陆直播，镜头突然切换，因为一位返回的宇航员感到不适。他们是活生生的人，是雇员，而不是真人秀选手。

comments.author: yesitcan
comments.content: Going on a spaceship is probably safer than driving a car.
comments.content_cn: 坐宇宙飞船可能比开车更安全。

comments.author: HardwareLust
comments.content: Thanks!
comments.content_cn: 谢谢！

posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕美联储主席鲍威尔视频声明的帖子链接问题展开。核心争议在于帖子直接链接至YouTube视频，而用户认为应优先使用美联储官网页面，因其同时提供视频和文字稿。有人认为直接链接官网更全面，也有用户指出已有重复帖子并建议合并。讨论中提到社区对信息来源的完整性和避免内容重复较为关注，普遍认同应优先使用官方原始出处。最终版主采纳建议，将评论移至合并后的帖子。

posts.title: Dell admits it made a mistake when it abandoned XPS
posts.author: jnord
posts.title_cn: 戴尔承认放弃XPS系列是一个错误
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕戴尔承认放弃XPS系列是一个错误这一核心话题展开。社区观点呈现明显分歧。部分用户对戴尔产品质量和定价表示强烈不满：有人指出XPS系列存在电池膨胀、DRM限制等硬件缺陷，且售后支持困难；也有用户批评其近期大幅涨价，认为性价比低，甚至转向MacBook以获得更好性能与续航。另一方面，有用户对新产品表示认可，认为新款XPS 16已改进此前问题，并对自身持有的旧款XPS设备的长期稳定性给予肯定。讨论中普遍认同戴尔在产品命名、市场策略上存在混乱，且其高端Windows笔记本在市场竞争中面临挑战。

comments.author: harendra007
comments.content: Windows PC market is truly gone down the toilet. Its nearly impossible to find a windows laptop >15 inch, with decent battery life, with centered keyboard. Apparently I need to buy 14 inch laptop for centered keyboard, hey you know what I need 15 inch or more of real estate. Thinkpads used to be a solid bet but those too have weird lineup these days. Its just so simple to get a Macbook these days and not worry about performance or battery life for fairly decent price.
comments.content_cn: Windows PC市场真是彻底没落了。现在几乎找不到一款屏幕大于15英寸、电池续航不错且键盘居中的Windows笔记本。显然，为了键盘居中我得买14英寸的笔记本，但你知道吗？我真正需要的是15英寸或更大的屏幕。ThinkPad曾经是可靠的选择，但如今它们的产品线也变得很奇怪。现在买MacBook就简单多了，价格还算合理，完全不用担心性能或电池续航问题。

comments.author: iJohnDoe
comments.content: We dropped Dell after almost 30 years of exclusive use for our desktops, laptops, and server/storage infrastructure.They can never seems to get their shit together.Going public and then back to private. We stuck with them through that, even though it was a shitshow trying to get a hold of anyone. They blur together, but this might have also been the time when they offered everyone the opportunity to leave and it was a ghost town at Dell.We stuck with them when they outsourced their support, which we later realized was the best years of support. More on that in a sec.Outsourced support turned out to be better because we could triage everything ourselves, then tell them which piece of hardware was broken and they would send a tech or replacement part. Basically exactly what we expected for when we purchased premium support.We stuck with them when they brought their support back to the US. Each tech person wanted to make a career out of each ticket. We couldn't get broken hardware fixed without screaming and begging.Keep in mind, we always bought the best hardware with the most expensive support level. Precision laptops. Precision desktops. Best servers and storage.We tried to stick with them when their sales teams basically wanted to remind us every time they don't really want to talk to anyone anymore. Everything is done online and they prefer not to talk to anyone.We tried to place an order for a laptop refresh, which was going to be followed by desktop refresh, and then a complete server/storage refresh. The sales teams made it seem like they were doing us a favor by even quoting us anything. More reminders to use the customer portal and don't call or e-mail us. That was the final straw and we did the complete refresh with a different brand.
comments.content_cn: 在近三十年里，我们一直独家使用戴尔的台式机、笔记本电脑及服务器/存储设备，但最终还是放弃了他们。他们似乎永远都理不清自己的问题。公司先是上市，然后又退市私有化。尽管当时想联系上他们的人简直是一场灾难，我们还是坚持了下来。那段时期记忆有些模糊，但可能也是他们给所有员工提供离职机会的时候，戴尔内部几乎成了空城。当他们把技术支持外包出去时，我们依然选择留下，后来才意识到那竟是服务最好的几年。关于这点稍后再细说。外包的技术支持反而更出色，因为我们可以自行排查所有问题，然后告诉他们具体哪个硬件坏了，他们就会派技术人员或寄送替换部件。这基本上就是我们购买高级支持服务时期望得到的服务。当他们把技术支持迁回美国时，我们仍然没有离开。但每个技术人员都想把每个服务请求当成自己的职业跳板，不吼不哀求就修不好坏掉的硬件。请记住，我们购买的始终是最好的硬件和最昂贵的支持服务：Precision笔记本电脑、Precision台式机、顶级的服务器和存储设备。当他们的销售团队基本上每次都想提醒我们，他们其实不再愿意与任何人交谈时，我们仍试图坚持。所有流程都在线完成，他们宁愿不跟任何人沟通。我们曾尝试下单更新一批笔记本电脑，随后还计划更新台式机，接着是合……

comments.author: bearjaws
comments.content: Dell needs to admit they're in deep shit.I just bought our entire G&A team M4 Macbook Air 15" for the same price as our Dell Pro laptops.They are 20% faster, have 2x the battery life, and 8 more gb of RAM. Also standby actually works.We had done an initial batch of Dell Pro 16 laptops and with 16gb of ram + the 255h (now 258v) it's over $1100 a laptop. Only problem is... they need 32gb of RAM on Windows 11 because the performance was terrible. We were seeing average 88% memory usage for our G&A team at 16gb. The upgrade to 32gb of RAM moves the price to $1500+ each, they also recently swapped to soldered RAM for both Intel and AMD, so we are forced to the $1500+ option with a faster CPU.Initial reactions have been overwhelmingly positive, about 50% of them are new to Macs and have figured it out, additionally they all love the battery life and performance (most are switching from 11th and 12th gen Intel).Our more tech savvy members have mentioned the better screen, webcam and audio as positives.I am considering switching our call center (~200 members) to Mac mini's, the same price as our Lenovo mini PCs and will last a long time, the Core Ultra 210 is not great. My only fear is people stealing them really.Why would I pay $2000 for Dells mid line series of business laptops? How much is this XPS going to cost vs a Mac book Pro?
comments.content_cn:
戴尔需要承认他们现在麻烦大了。我刚刚为我们整个行政与财务团队配备了M4芯片的15英寸MacBook Air，价格和我们之前戴尔专业笔记本相同。这些Mac速度快20%，电池续航翻倍，还多了8GB内存。而且待机功能确实好用。

我们之前采购过一批戴尔XPS 16笔记本，16GB内存加255H（现258V）配置每台要1100多美元。唯一的问题是...在Windows 11系统下他们需要32GB内存，因为16GB时性能表现很糟糕。我们行政团队的平均内存使用率达到了88%。升级到32GB内存后每台价格就超过1500美元了，而且他们最近把英特尔和AMD版本都改成了焊接内存，逼着我们只能选择1500美元以上配更快CPU的型号。

初步反馈非常积极，约一半员工是第一次用Mac但都很快上手了，而且所有人都喜欢它的续航和性能（他们大多是从第11代、12代英特尔换过来的）。我们技术较强的同事还特别提到了更好的屏幕、摄像头和音质。

我正在考虑把呼叫中心（约200人）的设备换成Mac mini，价格和我们现在的联想迷你电脑相当，而且更耐用——酷睿Ultra 210处理器实在不怎么样。唯一担心的是可能会被人偷走。

我为什么要花2000美元买戴尔的中端商务笔记本？XPS系列和MacBook Pro比起来到底要贵多少？

comments.author: 650REDHAIR
comments.content: My top of the line XPS battery swole so much it broke the keyboard.Repaired under warranty.Less than a year later that battery was swollen.No warranty replacement. No OEM batteries available through Dell.I buy 4 replacements from Amazon and none work. The XPS line has battery DRM.I have an i7 with a discrete card, 64gb of ram, and a 4k screen that’s worthless.
comments.content_cn: 我顶配XPS的电池鼓胀到撑坏了键盘。保修期内修了一次。不到一年那块电池又鼓了。过保不换。戴尔官方渠道买不到原装电池。我从亚马逊买了四块替代电池全用不了。XPS系列有电池加密锁。我这台i7处理器配独立显卡、64GB内存和4K屏的机器现在成了废铁。

comments.author: bri3d
comments.content: While we're doing anecdotes, I don't actually hate my 2025 Dell 16 Premium at all, and it looks like they fixed most of my quibbles with the new XPS 16.Figuring out which laptop to get was horrible because of their completely inexplicable branding, which I'm glad to see them roll back, but the computer is fine. I'm not sure I can agree with all of the "Dell computers are bad/dying" arguments.I think they went through a huge quality slump from ~2020-2023, as did most things, but so far my experience has been that they're quite good now. I haven't had any standby issues (or issues of any kind, really) using Windows. Windows 11 is Windows 11 but Tahoe is also Tahoe so that's a net medium. A little bit of Group Policy tweaking to remove the junkware and a little wince when hit with new-Notepad aside, it's good enough. I also tried running Linux on it and everything was straightforward except for the webcam (most modern Intel laptops use a new Intel thing where the CPU has the ISP on it and the camera is attached over CSI, and the kernel support is quite bleeding-edge) and the usual Nvidia graphics switching and arcane Linux power management problems, but I really got it for Windows anyway.My only beefs are the terrible virtual function bar (this was stupid the first time vendors tried it, and trying it again in 2025 is a really incredible choice, I'm glad they backed down on this ludicrous idea) and that the OLED model only comes in touchscreen form and the digitizer is ever-so-slightly visible. Otherwise I like it as well as my M2 MacBook Pro; the screen is square and notchless, the performance-to-dollar ratio was far superior, and the physical build quality is quite good. The "infinity" touchpad that's not really infinite is a stupid gimmick on paper but overall I don't notice it at all - it works just as well as any non-Apple touchpad I've used, which is to say about 85% as well as an Apple one.
comments.content_cn:
说到个人体验，我其实完全不讨厌我的2025款戴尔16英寸高端版，而且看起来他们已在新款XPS 16上修正了我之前抱怨的大部分问题。当初选择笔记本的过程简直令人抓狂，因为他们那套令人费解的产品命名体系——很高兴看到他们现在做出了调整，但电脑本身其实不错。我不太认同那些“戴尔电脑质量差/正在没落”的论调。我认为他们确实在2020至2023年间经历了严重的质量滑坡，这期间大多数品牌都有类似问题，但就我目前的体验而言，现在他们的产品已经相当出色。使用Windows系统时我从未遇到待机问题（实际上任何问题都没出现过）。Windows 11还是那个Windows 11，就像太浩湖始终是太浩湖，整体算是中规中矩。除了需要稍微调整组策略来清除预装垃圾软件，以及偶尔被新版记事本的功能惊到之外，整体体验良好。我也尝试过安装Linux系统，除了摄像头驱动（多数现代英特尔笔记本采用新型架构，CPU集成图像信号处理器，摄像头通过CSI接口连接，相关内核支持尚处于前沿阶段）以及常见的Nvidia显卡切换和Linux电源管理难题外，其他配置都很顺利——不过反正我主要是为了Windows系统才购买这台设备的。

我唯一不满的是那个糟糕的虚拟功能栏（厂商首次尝试这种设计时就显得很蠢，2025年再次尝试更是令人难以置信的选择，很高兴他们最终放弃了这个荒谬的设计），还有OLED型号仅提供触屏版本且数字化仪始终……

comments.author: walterbell
comments.content:
Dell XPS 14 starts at $2,050, while the 16-inch model will demand $2,200 starting Jan. 6. If you think that’s high, that’s because Dell revised its price point from $1,650 and $1,850, respectively. 

25% / ~$400 laptop price increase due to market price increases for 16GB RAM?
comments.content_cn:
戴尔XPS 14起售价为2050美元，而16英寸型号将于1月6日起以2200美元起售。若您认为价格偏高，这是因为戴尔已分别将原定1650美元和1850美元的定价进行了上调。

笔记本电脑价格上涨25%/约400美元，是否源于16GB内存市场价格上涨？

comments.author: talideon
comments.content: I'm still using my decade-old Precision 5510 (the XPS 15 at the time was a variant of it), and I've rarely felt the need to replace it, beyond Nvidia no longer supporting the discrete graphics as of last year.There was a period around Project Sputnik where they were making really good machines. Years of abuse, and it's still in good condition, though the battery has been showing its age lately.It's rather sad that things have gone downhill since then, as there was a period there that Dell were really good.
comments.content_cn: 我还在用那台十年前的Precision 5510（当时的XPS 15是它的变种版），除了英伟达从去年起不再支持独立显卡外，我很少觉得有换机的必要。在Sputnik项目期间，他们确实制造过一批非常出色的机器。多年重度使用后，它依然状态良好，不过电池最近确实显露出老化迹象。令人遗憾的是，此后情况便急转直下——戴尔曾有过那么一段真正的高光时期。

comments.author: rationalist
comments.content: I have a 2020 XPS 13, and love it.  I was disappointed when the keyboards in the batch of 2020 XPS 13 laptops after mine, had rattly key caps.  My XPS 13 is still doing well after the last nearly 6 years, and I look forward to trying the new XPS laptops if I can get one with the specs I want.
comments.content_cn: 我有一台2020年的XPS 13，非常喜欢它。但让我失望的是，在我之后那批2020年XPS 13笔记本的键盘出现了键帽松动的问题。我的XPS 13在近六年的使用后依然表现良好，如果能找到符合我配置要求的新款XPS笔记本，我很期待尝试。

comments.author: NegativeK
comments.content: > We stuck with them when they brought their support back to the US. Each tech person wanted to make a career out of each ticket. We couldn't get broken hardware fixed without screaming and begging.The people I talk to doing laptop repairs and trying to get parts from Dell say that Dell is treating them like potential scammers. They've diagnosed the broken part, everything is under warranty, Dell was previously fine with trusting these people.. But now Dell is forcing them to prove, every time, that the part needs to be replaced.It's the weirdest combination of time wasting and incentivizing this team to be _lower_ skilled that I've ever seen. Because, I'm guessing, Dell was dealing with too much warranty waste and decided to crack down on everyone.
comments.content_cn: 当他们把技术支持迁回美国时，我们依然选择信任。每个技术人员都想把每张维修单做成事业，不吼不哀求就修不好损坏的硬件。我接触的那些从事笔记本维修、试图从戴尔获取零件的人都说，戴尔把他们当作潜在骗子对待。他们已经诊断出故障部件，所有设备都在保修期内，戴尔原本对这些技术人员是信任的……但现在戴尔每次都强迫他们证明零件确实需要更换。这是我见过最奇怪的组合：既浪费时间，又变相鼓励团队降低技能水平。我猜是因为戴尔之前保修浪费太严重，所以决定对所有人采取严厉措施。

comments.author: Aurornis
comments.content: > We were seeing average 88% memory usageMy 64GB MacBook Pro sits around that level after using it for a while, too. So do my Windows and Linux machines even with different amounts of RAM.There's a popular page explaining it for Linux, but it's applicable to every OS: https://www.linuxatemyram.com/Isolated RAM usage numbers aren't useful because spare memory is used for caching. Even if you are using 88% of the RAM, that's not indicative of a problem unless you're encountering a lot of swapping. Even swapping a little bit isn't bad if it's not stalling the machine out. You have to look at actual performance, not RAM usage percentages.
comments.content_cn: 我们观察到的平均内存使用率为88%。我的64GB MacBook Pro在使用一段时间后也大致维持在这个水平。我的Windows和Linux设备同样如此，即使它们的内存容量各不相同。有一个解释Linux系统内存使用的热门页面，但其原理适用于所有操作系统：https://www.linuxatemyram.com/孤立地看内存使用率数据没有意义，因为空闲内存会被用于缓存。即使内存使用率达到88%，只要没有出现大量交换现象，就不代表存在问题。即使发生少量交换，只要没有导致系统卡顿，也并非坏事。必须关注实际性能表现，而非单纯盯着内存使用百分比。

comments.author: xormapmap
comments.content: I used to manage a small fleet of about 6 XPS laptops at my old job. 3 of them needed motherboard replacements under warranty within a year. People would put them on standby and put them in their bag, then get home and find the laptop had decided to start up of its own volition and overheat to the point it would be searing hot to the touch. The charging would randomly fail or the laptop would go into a boot loop. Not to mention problems with Windows deciding to update 2 minutes before an important meeting (and then naturally the progress bar would get stuck).
comments.content_cn: 我以前的工作需要管理大约6台XPS笔记本电脑。其中3台在保修期内不到一年就需要更换主板。同事们常常让电脑进入待机状态后放进包里，结果回到家发现电脑竟自动开机，过热到烫手的地步。充电会随机失效，或者电脑陷入重启循环。更不用说Windows系统总在重要会议前两分钟突然开始更新（然后进度条自然就卡住了）。

comments.author: timpera
comments.content: I recently switched from a XPS 13 with tons of issues, replaced twice, to a Surface Laptop 7 on ARM64. Absolutely no regrets, it's so much better. They really need to focus on quality control.
comments.content_cn: 最近我从问题频发的XPS 13换成了ARM64架构的Surface Laptop 7，那台戴尔电脑曾两次送修。现在完全没有后悔，体验提升太多了。他们真该好好抓抓品控。

comments.author: martinmeba
comments.content:
I had an XPS laptop purchased around 2020. It was a very well spec-ed machine on paper and worked reasonably well. It just did not hold up.
1. Bulging battery - replaced
2. USB-C charging blew up the charge controller - laptop completely unable to charge - replaced motherboard
3. USB-C charging blew up the charge controller again (~6 months later)#3 was out of warranty and I had just changed companies so it went into the trash. It lasted 3 years tops.I also have a dell ultrasharp 4K monitor that had to be replaced under warrant within ~1 year of purchase and I am just waiting for it to go again now that it is out of warranty.Dell seems to have had reasonable service(in-warranty) but their stuff is always breaking down.I have had several macbooks. Each lasted ~10 years+.
comments.content_cn:
我大约在2020年购买了一台XPS笔记本电脑。从参数上看，这台机器配置很高，实际使用也还算顺畅。但它就是不经用。
1. 电池鼓包——更换了
2. USB-C充电烧毁了充电控制器——电脑完全无法充电——更换了主板
3. USB-C充电再次烧毁充电控制器（约6个月后）第三次故障已过保修期，而我刚换了公司，就直接把它扔了。这台电脑最多撑了三年。我还有一个戴尔 ultrasharp 4K显示器，购买后不到一年就因保修期内故障换新，现在保修已过，我正等着它再次出问题。戴尔的保修服务（在保内）似乎还算合理，但他们家的产品总是出故障。我用过好几台MacBook，每台都能用十年以上。

comments.author: macbem
comments.content: I had an XPS 9560 / 9570 or something like that. Top of the line spec, mind you.It had a Killer WLAN network card that would frequently disconnect from wifi on any OS - so much that I had to switch it out to a different one. posts.title: Show HN: Play poker with LLMs, or watch them play against each other
posts.content: I was curious to see how some of the latest models behaved and played no limit texas holdem.I built this website which allows you to:Spectate: Watch different models play against each other.Play: Create your own table and play hands against the agents directly.
posts.author: projectyang
posts.title_cn: "Show HN：与大型语言模型玩扑克，或观看它们互相对决"
posts.content_cn: 我很好奇一些最新模型在无限注德州扑克中的表现和行为，因此创建了这个网站，它允许你：观战：观看不同模型之间的对局。参与：创建自己的牌桌，直接与这些智能体进行手牌对决。
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子展示了一个让用户与大型语言模型玩德州扑克或观看模型间对战的网站。核心话题是探讨LLM在扑克游戏中的表现及其交互设计。

社区讨论中，用户普遍认可项目的趣味性，但也提出多项改进建议。有人认为界面布局有待优化，建议将模型的推理过程实时显示在玩家旁，而非分屏展示。也有用户指出模型实力不均衡的问题，希望看到更公平的对战组合。讨论中提到，有职业扑克玩家认为当前LLM的表现已优于低限注桌的大部分人类玩家，虽不完美但已超越许多业余玩家。

分歧点主要体现在功能设计上：部分用户希望加入虚拟表情和实时互动功能，让模型能通过表情或语言进行欺骗、施加心理影响；另有用户则关注技术成本，询问高令牌消耗下的项目运营成本问题。此外，有用户对LLM扑克智能体的实用性提出疑问，认为非LLM的扑克AI其实更强，但未引起同等关注。整体而言，社区肯定项目的创意，同时期待在交互体验和模型能力上进一步优化。

comments.content: >How much of a session is based on "reading players" vs "playing the odds"?I think the key is you need to watch for a person's play style.There's a two axis system: tight/agressive and passive/active.An active player sees more flops, and an aggressive player will call and raise more than a tight player.So a tight, aggressive player sees few flows but bets strongly when they have a good hand -- this is considered "good" strategy.Others might play a "tight-passive" strategy -- they'll play few hands but fold easily. They won't lose large amounts of money but they'll slowly bleed chips.A loose, aggeessive player is the type you want at the table -- they're making a lot of bets, and often bluffing, and you can sit and wait to catch them.Now, this is "reading" someone, but it's not the Rounders style "oh he just ate an oreo so he's bluffing" level reading of a player that moviesFor context, I'm an OK player. I can make a few hundred playing 1/3 per session -- I'm not in Vegas so I can't move to the next tier without sinking a lot of money on a flight and hotel.If your goal is a bit of beer money, it can be a fun hobby, but I wouldn't go into it expecting it to become a full time career.

一场牌局中有多少是基于“解读玩家”而非“计算概率”？我认为关键在于观察个人的打法风格。这里有一个双轴体系：紧凶型与松弱型。活跃型玩家会参与更多翻牌圈，而激进型玩家相比紧手玩家会更频繁地跟注和加注。因此，紧凶型玩家很少入池，但拿到好牌时会下重注——这被视为“优秀”策略。其他人可能采用“紧弱型”策略——他们玩的手牌很少且容易弃牌。这类玩家不会损失大钱，但筹码会慢慢流失。松凶型玩家是桌上最受欢迎的类型——他们频繁下注，常虚张声势，你可以静候时机捕捉破绽。以上属于“解读”玩家，但并非电影《赌王之王》里“哦他刚吃了块奥利奥所以肯定在诈唬”那种层面的解读。

就背景而言，我算中等水平玩家。在1/3盲注局中每场能赢几百美元——我不在拉斯维加斯，若想升级必须投入大量机票酒店费用。如果目标只是赚点酒钱，这可以成为有趣的消遣，但别指望以此发展为全职事业。

comments.author: csa
comments.content: > How much of a session is based on "reading players" vs "playing the odds"?Several good answers here, but I will add my own take.“Playing the odds” is basically playing good, fundamental poker. This is a baseline that most players will use when sitting down at a table of unknown players. This is often called a “balanced” strategy (note some people erroneously call this “GTO strategy, assuming the balance, which is not actually what GTO is).“Reading players” is a thing, but it can be broken up into (at least) two categories: 1) physical tells, and 2) player habits.Physical tells is not a big thing. Some people give off a lot of tells, but some folks are also decent (not good) at giving reverse tells. Honestly, you can be a wildly successful poker player while knowing nothing about physical tells.(Side note: One of the most reliable tells is bet timing tells. This can sometimes even be a tell online, especially when people are taking shots at higher stakes or are deep in a tournament. It can also be faked, but some folks are super reliable with timing tells, and they don’t realize it.)The second kind of tell is player tendencies — things like when players play too many hands or when they play too few (e.g., fold too often).One very reliable way for good players to smooth out their earnings curve is figure out which players fold too often and in which spots. Once they’ve figured that out, they try to set up that spot and basically print low-risk (sometimes even no-risk) chips.Taking advantage of these tendencies is called an “exploitative” strategy (as opposed to the “balanced” strategy mentioned above).Really good players can take rec players on a journey through a series of emotions (and accompanying predictable gameplay) such that the good player can read the rec player like a book. The odds tip heavily in favor of the good player at this point.Pro player and strong amateur players are so far ahead of recs in ways that the recs don’t even realize.
comments.content_cn:
一场牌局中有多少是基于"解读玩家"而非"计算概率"？这里已有不少好答案，但我想补充自己的看法。

"计算概率"本质上是遵循扎实的扑克基本原则。这是大多数玩家在陌生牌桌入座时会采用的基础策略，常被称为"平衡策略"（注意：有人误称其为"GTO策略"，但平衡策略并不等同于真正的博弈论最优策略）。

"解读玩家"确实存在，但至少可划分为两类：1) 肢体马脚，2) 玩家习惯。

肢体马脚并非关键因素。有些人会暴露大量马脚，但也有人擅长制造反向马脚。实际上，即使完全不懂肢体马脚，也能成为非常成功的扑克玩家。

（补充说明：最可靠的马脚之一是下注时机马脚。这在线上扑克中有时也会显现，特别是当玩家尝试更高注额或处于锦标赛深筹码阶段时。这种马脚可以伪装，但有些人的下注时机规律极其稳定，而他们自己并未察觉。）

第二类马脚是玩家倾向性——例如玩家何时过于频繁地参与牌局，或何时过于保守（比如弃牌过多）。

优秀玩家稳定盈利的一个可靠方法是：找出哪些玩家在哪些情境下容易过度弃牌。一旦掌握这点，他们就会刻意制造这种情境，从而几乎零风险（有时甚至完全无风险）地积累筹码。

posts.title: ASCII-Driven Development
posts.author: _hfqa
posts.title_cn: ASCII驱动开发
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了“ASCII驱动开发”这一概念，即利用ASCII字符作为低保真界面布局规范，以优先确定UI结构和流程，避免团队过早陷入高保真视觉细节的争论。作者认为ASCII能强制抽象、快速迭代且易于AI代理解析。

社区讨论中，有人支持这一方法，指出AI代理能有效驱动tmux等工具验证TUI布局，或通过解析文本快照进行测试。也有用户指出类似价值可通过直接处理底层JSON数据实现，虽渲染效果稍弱但仍可读。部分用户对实践可行性存疑，认为高保真设计工具已深入人心，且AI生成的ASCII图表常存在对齐问题（如框线错位），需借助校对工具修正。此外，有用户提到文章示例因显示格式问题影响阅读体验。

共识在于ASCII作为低保真原型具有快速验证结构的优势，但分歧集中在实际落地难度、AI生成内容的准确性以及对现有设计流程的适应性上。

Author here. High-level:- Problem: AI UI generators are high-fidelity by default → teams bikeshed aesthetics before structure is right.- Idea: use ASCII as an intentionally low-fidelity “layout spec” to lock hierarchy/flow first.Why ASCII:
- forces abstraction (no colors/fonts/shadows)- very fast to iterate (seconds)- pasteable anywhere (Slack/Notion/GitHub)- editable by anyoneWorkflow:- describe UI → generate ASCII → iterate on structure/states → feed into v0/Lovable/Bolt/etc → polish visuals lastIt also facilitates discussion:- everyone argues about structure/decisions, not pixels- feedback is concrete (“move this”, “add a section”), not subjectiveMore advanced setups could integrate user/customer support feedback to automatically propose changes to a spec or PRD, enabling downstream tasks to later produce PRs.

作者在此。核心观点如下：
问题：AI界面生成器默认追求高保真度 → 团队容易在结构尚未完善时就陷入美学细节的争论。
思路：使用ASCII作为刻意设计的低保真“布局规范”，优先锁定层级结构与流程。

选用ASCII的原因：
- 强制抽象化（无颜色/字体/阴影）
- 迭代极快（数秒内完成）
- 可粘贴至任意平台（Slack/Notion/GitHub）
- 任何人都能编辑

工作流程：
描述界面 → 生成ASCII → 迭代调整结构与状态 → 导入v0/Lovable/Bolt等工具 → 最后优化视觉效果

这种方式也便于讨论：
- 所有人聚焦于结构/决策的讨论，而非像素细节
- 反馈更具体（如“移动此部分”“增加区块”），减少主观意见

comments.author: rmunn
comments.content: Emojis mixed with ASCII-era characters are hard to get right. Some terminal emulators get it right nearly all the time (e.g. Ghostty, which has had a lot of thought and effort put into getting it right) and yet there are still open issues in the Ghostty repo about inconsistent character width. There are just so many corner cases that it's hard.That said, the edge alignment is, I believe, caused by the fact that LLMs are involved in the process. Because the LLMs never "see" the final visual representation that humans see. Their "view" of the world is text-based, and in the text file, those columns line up because they have the same number of UTF-8 codepoints in the row. So the LLMs do not realize that the right edges are misaligned visually. (And since the workflow described is for an LLM to take that text file as input and produce an output in React/Vue/Svelte/whatever, the visual alignment of the text file needs to stay LLM-oriented for it to work properly. I assume, of course, since I haven't tried this myself).

不过我认为边缘对齐问题是由大语言模型参与流程导致的。因为大语言模型从未"看见"人类所见的最终视觉呈现。它们对世界的"观察"是基于文本的，而在文本文件中，各列之所以对齐是因为每行包含相同数量的UTF-8码点。所以大语言模型无法意识到右侧边缘在视觉上并未对齐。（由于所述工作流程需要大语言模型接收文本文件作为输入，并输出React/Vue/Svelte等框架的代码，文本文件的视觉对齐必须保持以大语言模型为导向才能正常运作。当然这只是我的推测，毕竟我尚未亲自尝试过）。

posts.title: Open Chaos: A self-evolving open-source project
posts.author: stefanvdw1
posts.title_cn: 开放混沌：一个自我演进的开源项目
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕开源项目"Open Chaos"展开，这是一个通过社区投票自主演化的实验性项目。核心话题在于探讨这种"民主化开发"模式的可行性与潜在价值。

多数用户将其类比为"Twitch Plays Pokémon"或"Twitch plays Github"，认为这是一种有趣的社会实验。有人认为项目初期投票多集中于修改投票规则或优化性能等细节，体现了自组织系统的局限性；也有用户指出，若结合LLM自动生成功能并由社区投票，可能引发更大规模的"混沌"。讨论中提到，部分用户对项目最终产出仅为网站表示困惑，认为其实际意义尚不明确。

共识在于社区普遍认可此类实验的创新性，并期待观察其长期发展。主要分歧在于对其潜力的判断：一方认为这可能催生真正的社区协作，另一方则质疑其能否超越琐碎修改，产出实质性创新。

There's a Github App (which may not still work, but if there's interest I'll restart it) and a "run it yourself" python library and CLI you can run from Github Actions[4].1. https://screeps.com/2. https://github.com/ScreepsQuorum/screeps-quorum3. https://www.gitconsensus.com/4. https://pypi.org/project/gitconsensus/

posts.title: “Food JPEGs” in Super Smash Bros. and Kirby Air Riders
posts.author: SethMLarson
posts.title_cn: 《任天堂明星大乱斗》与《星之卡比 空中竞速》中的“食物JPEG”现象
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕《任天堂明星大乱斗》和《星之卡比 空气骑士》游戏中出现的“食物JPEG”图像展开，核心话题是玩家对这些低分辨率食物贴图来源、设计及文化意义的考据兴趣。社区普遍欣赏文章的深度考据风格，认为此类内容体现了互联网的独特价值，并有人幽默建议撰写基于游戏饮食的健康分析。

讨论中主要观点多元：有用户指出这些食物图像可能借鉴了早期街机游戏（如《泡泡龙》）的表现方式；也有用户对图像在游戏中的实际呈现效果表示好奇，希望看到具体截图；同时，有玩家补充指出文章遗漏了《大乱斗X》中“超级辣咖喱”道具的考据。分歧点在于对图像“JPEG质感”的具体理解，以及文章细节的准确性（如配图与列表的食物条目存在出入）。

共识在于社区高度认可这种针对游戏文化细节的考据精神，部分用户甚至以“为高清图像收藏实体卡带”为例，赞叹这种保存数字文化遗产的执着态度。

comments.author: rmunn
comments.content: > In the process I also learned that the cover of Kirby Air Ride changed between the Japanese and international releases. The Japanese cover art features a smiling happy Kirby where the international cover has Kirby with a furrowed brow and serious look.This is not the first Kirby game to have its cover art changed to look more serious and "gritty" for the US release; in fact, TV Tropes named a page after this phenomenon, and Kirby Air Ride is currently the featured page art at https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmericanKirbyIsH... (caution, TV Tropes will consume your free time, only click when you have a few hours to spare).P.S. Since the link chopped off half way through the name of the wiki page, I'll just mention that the page is titled "American Kirby is Hardcore".
comments.content_cn: 在这个过程中我还了解到，《星之卡比：空中滑行》的封面在日本版和国际版之间有所变化。日版封面是卡比开心微笑的形象，而国际版封面上的卡比则眉头紧锁、表情严肃。这并非首款为迎合美国市场而将封面改为更严肃"硬核"风格的卡比游戏；事实上，TV Tropes网站甚至为此现象专门建立了一个页面，目前《星之卡比：空中滑行》正是该页面的展示图（链接：https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmericanKirbyIsH... 注意：TV Tropes极易消耗时间，请确保有数小时空闲再点击浏览）。附注：由于链接截断了维基页面名称的后半部分，特此说明该页面标题为"美国卡比很硬核"。

The industry is very pyramid shaped, and unless you get really lucky or have nepo baby connections, you'll never get the chance to helm a project like that.Tens of thousands of students go to film school every year, yet most of their dreams wither on the vine. That's incredibly sad. We only get a small slice of human creativity, and what we do see is usually pretty generic.We have our Arris - that part has been democratized for a while. We have distribution. But we could never afford a $100 million VFX budget. AI changes the game and gives us so much hope that we can finally tell the stories we really want to tell in the way that we want to tell them.Instead of thinking of AI as "just prompting", think of it as an exoskeleton for practitioners. One analogy is that cameras can be used by anyone to make all kinds of junk - selfies, food pics, "butt dialed" accidental shots. Yet professional photographers are capable of making incredibly captivating art and immortalizing Pulitzer Prize winning moments.There are AI coding assistants for people who can't code (and I think this is awesome for accessibility and letting people act on their dreams - it's a gateway!), and there are AI coding models for full-time engineers. It's a lot like that.I've made a lot of experiments in this space. Huge ComfyUI workflows, custom trained models frankensteined from stitched together modules, a lot of Unreal and Blender-inspired work.I'm currently working on this [1] to enhance my own work. My desire right now is making it really fast to visually mold starting frames (which are like a director and DP blocking out scenes before shooting) and to precisely get the image you want before generating it.This year I'm going to make full AI animations as well as a bunch of rotoscoped human + AI films this year. This stuff is going to be amazing for horror, sci-fi, and fantasy with live human actors. Those low-budget Blumhouse films are about to get real, and we're going to start seeing Lovecraftian horrors and actually good dinosaur movies soon. I'm really excited for this.So I guess to return to my point, please please please don't hate all AI or especially insult people using it. This technology isn't distributed evenly, and in some pockets it's literally the most magical thing to have happened to the space. I wish I had this when I was much younger - my career would have looked a lot different. I'm really happy for the kids that get to grow up using this.--Anyway, I came to this article because I love Smash. It's a fantastic article and the author did an amazing job compiling this. I mostly play "no items", but I did see these on rare occasions. It's funny how nostalgia can be triggered by low resolution billboard textures from Melee.Sakurai, director of the game, is bullish on AI for game development [2]. I think he's thinking the same way we are - this is a creative exoskeleton letting us do more and achieve more of our vision against the friction of constraints.Invariably the comments (probably from non-artist consumers?) is full of hate. Many artists want to use this, yet we're bullied and hated for it.This one, jeez:> Dude's a hack and hasn't made a good game since Melee.This is the same bullshit I'm getting on a daily basis. 
The hate we get online is unreal. You have to see it to believe it. I'm talking death threats on a regularly recurring basis. I should blog about it.So please internalize this plea. Whenever you see attacks like this, please say something to remind the other person that we're all human and that real artists are using these tools to make real art.[1] https://github.com/storytold/artcraft[2] https://www.resetera.com/threads/masahiro-sakurai-believes-g...

posts.title: The Concise TypeScript Book
posts.author: javatuts
posts.title_cn: 《TypeScript 简明教程》
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕《The Concise TypeScript Book》展开，核心话题是如何高效学习TypeScript以及技术文档的呈现方式。社区普遍认同简洁、有针对性的学习材料对开发者更有帮助，许多人认为官方手册内容详尽但过于庞杂，更期待能突出重点的指南。

在文档形式上存在不同需求：有用户指出HTML版本不便追踪阅读进度，强烈建议提供PDF或epub格式以便离线阅读和记录；也有用户推荐配套的在线资源如types.kitlangton.com，认为可视化示例能更直观地说明概念。讨论中提到该电子书部分内容两年未更新，在TypeScript快速演进的背景下可能影响时效性，但仍可作为参考。

关于学习路径，用户分享了TypeScript学习路线图，并引发对官方手册价值的探讨——有人认为它涵盖全面但缺乏重点，另一些用户则主张通过分类文档体系满足不同场景需求。整体上，社区肯定简洁教程的价值，同时强调文档应兼顾结构清晰、形式多样与内容更新。

comments.author: MORPHOICES
comments.content: When reading succinct technical documentation, I see how so many times the documentation attempts to cover everything possible. ~Most developers want guidance instead of exhaustive details. Developers want to know where they should focus their time and where they can afford to skim over the documentation. And they want to know where they should expect to encounter problems and difficulties.A simple framework to use when producing succinct technical documentation is to divide the documentation into three sections.Maps: Identify what type of problems this documentation can assist you withDefaults: Understand what the majority of people will experience and what to do about it.Exceptions: Identify when to deviate from the default recommendations.Succinct documentation does an excellent job of providing clarity by eliminating edge cases. The more clearly the user understands the documentation the more useful the documentation will be during the time where the user is experiencing the most confusion.The danger is the temptation to simplify the information contained within the documentation to such an extent that the user is left with a large amount of missing information and no method for seeking assistance with incomplete information.What situations have you encountered where the information contained within short technical documentation has been more helpful than official technical documentation? ~
comments.content_cn: 阅读简洁的技术文档时，我常注意到文档往往试图涵盖所有可能情况。大多数开发者需要的是指引而非详尽细节。他们想知道应把时间重点放在何处，哪些部分可以快速浏览，以及可能遇到问题和困难的环节。制作简洁技术文档可采用一个简单框架：将内容分为三个部分。地图：明确本文档能协助解决哪些类型的问题；默认路径：了解大多数人的使用场景及应对方法；例外情况：识别何时需要偏离默认建议。简洁文档通过剔除边缘案例，能出色地提供清晰指引。用户对文档理解越透彻，在最为困惑的阶段文档的效用就越大。但需警惕过度简化信息的倾向——若简化到使用户缺失大量关键信息，且无法通过不完整内容寻求帮助，便会造成风险。你在哪些场景中遇到过简短技术文档比官方技术文档更有帮助的情况？

comments.content_cn: 关键在于，文档并非铁板一块——它确实需要细分为对特定项目参与者或使用者有用的子类别：https://diataxis.fr/（最初发布于：https://docs.divio.com/documentation-system/）将文档划分为四种类型：教程、阐释、操作指南和参考。当我按照这种分类方式整理自己的文档时，文档质量得到了显著提升。

comments.content: That does make a huge difference, though I have found you also need to divide by the audiences. There are usually two main audiences that need addressing:1. The new user. They typically know nothing about the product, not even why it exists. The CTO/CIO bought it and now you have to use it. They need lots of hand-holding and needs concrete instruction. Tutorials and explanations are focused on them so they can build accurate mental models of how the software work.2. The experienced user. They have a pretty good idea of how the product works, but business requirements have changed in some way and know needs to make adjustments to their processes. Or just needs reminders of less used features. Good how-tos and reference material is vital.If you don't take care of these things the customer will abandon your product sooner than later.
comments.content_cn:
这确实会产生巨大差异，不过我发现还需要根据受众群体进行区分。通常需要关注两类主要受众：

2. 资深用户。他们已基本掌握产品使用方法，但因业务需求变化需要调整流程，或是需要重温较少使用的功能。优质的实操指南和参考资料对他们至关重要。

若忽视这些需求，客户迟早会放弃使用您的产品。

comments.author: locknitpicker
comments.content: > I show people coming from object oriented backgrounds this page first in order to correct the perception that TypeScript is best used with that programming paradigm.I think you're confusing things. Languages like Java or C# impose an artificial constraint that free functions don't exist and functions can only exist as members of a class. You don't see this constraint in OO languages such as C++.Also, it's a simplistic assertions to claim that classes have no place in TypeScript or aren't idiomatic. That's just nonsense based on specious reasoning. Classes/objects with function members are still the best way to implement some features. I'm seeing too many people writing absurd typescript code who go through great lengths to avoid a class because they think a class is taboo. They pull out convoluted stunts like passing closures as object members, just to avoid the sin of rolling out a class.
comments.content_cn:
我首先向有面向对象背景的人展示这个页面，是为了纠正那种认为TypeScript最适合与那种编程范式结合使用的观念。我认为你混淆了一些概念。像Java或C#这样的语言强加了一个人为的限制，即自由函数不存在，函数只能作为类的成员存在。在C++这样的面向对象语言中，你并不会看到这种限制。

此外，声称类在TypeScript中没有位置或不符习惯，这是一种过于简单的断言。这只是基于似是而非的推理的无稽之谈。带有函数成员的类/对象仍然是实现某些功能的最佳方式。我看到太多人编写荒谬的TypeScript代码，他们竭尽全力避免使用类，因为他们认为类是禁忌。他们采取迂回的手段，比如将闭包作为对象成员传递，只是为了避免使用类的“罪过”。

posts.title: Instagram data breach reportedly exposed the personal info of 17.5M users
posts.author: IvanAchlaqullah
posts.title_cn: 据报道Instagram数据泄露事件暴露了1750万用户的个人信息
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Instagram数据泄露事件的真实性展开。核心争议在于此次事件是否构成真正的数据泄露，还是仅涉及公开信息的滥用。多数用户对媒体报道持怀疑态度，认为这更像是利用公开信息触发密码重置邮件，而非系统被入侵。有用户指出，Instagram的密码重置功能允许通过公开的用户名操作，因此相关邮件可能被误读为泄露证据。讨论中提到，Instagram官方已回应称系统未被入侵，问题已修复。也有用户分享个人经历，认为自己的非活跃账户收到异常邮件，侧面印证了平台可能存在安全漏洞。整体来看，社区普遍质疑媒体对“泄露”的夸大描述，但部分用户仍对平台的数据保护措施表示担忧。

comments.author: pentagrama
comments.content: I looked into this a bit and I am also skeptical about the leak narrative.I just checked, and Instagram’s password reset flow allows requesting a reset using an email address, a phone number, or even the username [1]. The username is public information, so triggering password reset emails is relatively easy. At scale you would need IP rotation and some basic automation, but it is not particularly hard to generate a large volume of reset emails and create confusion.From an attacker’s perspective, this does not grant access to accounts or sensitive data. It mainly causes users to receive unexpected reset emails and possibly panic or change their passwords. That aligns more with nuisance or malice than with a meaningful breach.I do not have definitive proof, but based on this behavior it seems plausible that the reported wave of reset emails could be explained without any large scale data leak.[1] https://www.instagram.com/accounts/password/reset/ (screenshot: https://imgur.com/a/4x5HPLx)
comments.content_cn:
我对此事进行了一些调查，同样对数据泄露的说法持怀疑态度。我刚刚查看了Instagram的密码重置流程，发现它允许通过电子邮件地址、电话号码甚至用户名来申请重置[1]。用户名是公开信息，因此触发密码重置邮件相对容易。大规模操作需要更换IP地址和一些基本的自动化工具，但生成大量重置邮件并制造混乱并不特别困难。

从攻击者的角度来看，这并不能让他们获取账户或敏感数据。这主要是导致用户收到意外的重置邮件，可能引起恐慌或促使用户更改密码。这更像是骚扰或恶意行为，而非有实际意义的数据泄露。

我虽然没有确凿证据，但基于这种行为模式，报道中提及的重置邮件潮很可能无需大规模数据泄露就能解释。
[1] https://www.instagram.com/accounts/password/reset/（截图：https://imgur.com/a/4x5HPLx）

But hey as far as I know, we're now secure™.
comments.content_cn:
从攻击者的角度来看，这并不能让他们访问账户或敏感数据。我认为“安全”领域的江湖骗子们可能正试图将公开可获取的数据归类为某种数据泄露。这大概是因为对安全公司而言，发现这种“泄露”是快速取胜之道——既能制造舆论，又能吓唬那些不懂行的管理层购买他们的解决方案或咨询服务。我记得推特也曾发生过类似的“泄露”事件，结果发现那些都是用户自己放在公开资料页上、被爬虫抓取的数据。

就我个人经历而言，曾有人与我争论，认为披露某个账户是否已注册属于重大安全漏洞，并要求采取“某些措施”来解决，却又拒绝修改注册表单以隐藏这一信息（因为否则我们就得把注册流程改为通过邮件链接进行，要求用户等待确认邮件才能继续，这会严重降低转化率）。最终“措施”倒是实施了，而恶意分子果然立刻转向了注册表单。不过据我所知，我们现在可是安全™了。

posts.title: Max Payne – two decades later – Graphics Critique (2021)
posts.author: davikr
posts.title_cn: 《马克思·佩恩》二十年后的画面技术评析（2021）
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕2021年一篇关于《马克思·佩恩》游戏图形技术的分析文章展开。核心话题是对这款二十年前游戏图形设计的回顾与评价，探讨其技术实现的历史意义与艺术价值。

讨论中，有人认为文章提及的凹凸贴图等技术在当时已是行业标准，如今被描述为“取巧手法”令人感慨技术认知的变迁。也有用户指出，这些技术被开发团队灵活运用以创造艺术效果，造就了许多令人难忘的游戏时刻。多位用户称赞游戏纹理、光影和环境美术的卓越表现，认为其风格与氛围至今仍具魅力。

普遍共识是，《马克思·佩恩》系列在图形艺术和游戏体验上成就突出，至今仍值得游玩。同时，用户提到该系列正由原开发商进行重制，并获Rockstar的AAA级资金支持。

分歧点主要体现在技术认知层面：部分用户认为文中技术分析并无特别深奥之处，现代游戏引擎已能轻松实现相关概念；也有用户反驳称这些技术在当时实属先进，且现代游戏仍存在类似技术局限。讨论中还提及了学习图形编程的书籍资源，以及文章配图中《GTA III》被误标为《GTA VC》的细节纠错。

comments.author: gary_0
comments.content: I feel old because the post talks about these techniques as if they're surprising innovations or compromises for more accurate simulations, but most of these tricks were industry standard for 3D games in the early 2000's. Much of the science about lighting, physics, and rendering we take for granted today was mostly unknown; developers just did the best they could with the basic tech that was available. Back then, just the fact that we could put thousands of hardware accelerated textured polygons on the screen was a miracle to us.While Max Payne was cutting-edge, a lot of what made the visuals appear impressive was due to hand-tweaking by a team of highly skilled artists and designers, who were probably using ridiculously primitive tooling. Pretty much every realistic 3D game of this era had to make do with low-res diffuse textures, prebaked lighting, mostly fixed-function rendering, pre-scripted interactions, and particle dynamics that were basically just a few lines of C++. Other early-2000's games like Serious Sam, Halo, and Metroid Prime also managed to create immersive visuals with very limited tech, using the same techniques as Max Payne.

comments.author: fsloth
comments.content: Graphics is not an academic body of knowledge as such. It's a bag of tricks developed over 50 years, going hand in hand with industrial hardware development.There _is_ deep and rich academic framework around the subject, but I think to understand "why this" you need to program to understand the problem space since it's not really anything you could derive from first principles. I mean you get the rendering equation and so on, but the graphics knowledge portrayed in the article comes from understanding the three pillars of real time rendering.It's about delicate interaction between human visual system (how to fool it), algorithms, and the hardware capabilities.In general you need to program graphics, not read it. I mean I'm in the "reading" category myself and the people who've focused on programming are much better than myself.Real time rendering by Akenine-Möller, Haines et all is the standard entry reference. Now in it's fourth edition. It's really good and dense.If someone wants a simple recipe how to learn real time graphics alone in their cellar, nowadays I would recommend getting Real Time Rendering and going through https://learnopengl.com/.After that you just continue... continue ... continue.There are some people who understand everything about the topic instantly intuitively apparently but that's very, very unique. For the rest of us it's a life long adventure facing our own limitations and trying to get better, one program after another.Speaking as graphics/geometry dev for 20 years now.
comments.content_cn:
图形学并非传统意义上的学术知识体系，它更像是五十年来与工业硬件发展同步积累的一系列实用技巧。这个领域确实存在深厚而丰富的学术框架，但要理解"为什么这样做"，我认为必须通过编程来把握问题空间——因为其中许多内容无法单纯从基本原理推导出来。虽然我们有渲染方程等理论工具，但文章中描述的图形学知识主要源于对实时渲染三大支柱的理解：人类视觉系统（如何欺骗它）、算法与硬件能力之间的精妙互动。

总的来说，学习图形学必须动手编程而非仅仅阅读。我自己就属于"阅读型"学习者，而那些专注于编程实践的人往往比我强得多。《实时渲染》（作者Akenine-Möller、Haines等）是标准的入门参考书，现已更新至第四版，内容详实而密集。

如果有人想在地下室独自学习实时图形学，如今我会推荐先研读《实时渲染》，再配合https://learnopengl.com/进行实践。之后便是持续不断地练习、练习、再练习。确实存在少数能凭直觉瞬间领悟所有知识的天才，但这极为罕见。对我们大多数人而言，这终其一生都是不断突破自身局限、通过一个个程序逐步精进的冒险旅程。
